name <p> <strong>Arizona State University</strong> (also referred to as <strong>ASU</strong>, or <strong>Arizona State</strong>) is the largest <a>public</a> <a>research university</a> in the <a>United States</a>, with a 2010 student enrollment of 70,440.
name In 1945, the school came under control of the <a>Arizona Board of Regents</a> and was renamed &quot;Arizona State College.&quot;&lt;ref&gt;<a>History of ASU</a> Arizona State University&lt;/ref&gt; In 1958, a statewide ballot measure renamed the school &quot;Arizona State University.&quot;

name <p><strong>Brown University</strong> is a <a>private</a> <a>Ivy League</a> <a>university</a> located in <a>Providence, Rhode Island</a>.
name Detail from an oil painting by Cosmo Alexander, 1770; in University Hall, Brown University, Providence, R.I.]] [[Image:BrownUniversity-UniversityHall1795.jpg|thumb|This copper-plate engraving from 1795 is the first known image of Brown.
name The original campus was a single academic building that was later named [[University Hall (Brown University)|University Hall]].]]</p>
name <p>In 1764, Edwards joined several others as an original fellow or trustee for the chartering of the College in the English Colony of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations (the former name for Brown University), the first Baptist college in the original <a>thirteen colonies</a> and one of the <a>Ivy League</a> universities.[<a>http://www.brown.edu/Administration/Corporation/downloads/charter-of-brown-university.pdf</a>]</p>
name In 1804, a year after John Brown's death, the University was renamed Brown University in honor of John's nephew, <a>Nicholas Brown, Jr.</a>, who was a member of the class of 1786 and in 1804 contributed $5,000 toward an endowed professorship.
name <p>Brown began to admit women when it established a <a>Women's College in Brown University</a> in 1891, which was later named <a>Pembroke College in Brown University</a>.
name <p>The language of the Brown University charter has long been interpreted by the university as discouraging the founding of a <a>business school</a> or <a>law school</a>.
name Prior to the march, Brown University served as an encampment site for French troops, and the College Edifice, now University Hall, was turned into a military hospital.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name The <a>curriculum</a> was the result of a paper written by <a>Ira Magaziner</a> and Elliot Maxwell entitled &quot;Draft of a Working Paper for Education at Brown University.&quot;&lt;ref&gt;
name <p><a>thumb|Brown University seal as a detail on a university building</a> As recently as 2006, there has been some debate on reintroducing plus/minus grading to the curriculum.
name <p>As a part of the re-accreditation process, Brown University is undergoing an expansive reevaluation of its undergraduate education offerings through the newly appointed Task Force on Undergraduate Education.

name In 1991, the school was officially renamed the Brown University School of Medicine, then renamed once more to Brown Medical School in October 2000.&lt;ref&gt;<a>History of the Brown Medical School</a>&lt;/ref&gt; In January 2007, self-made entrepreneur Warren Alpert donated $100 million to Brown Medical School on behalf of the Warren Alpert Foundation, tying <a>Sidney Frank</a> for the largest single monetary contribution ever made to the University.
name In recognition of the gift, the faculty of Brown University approved changing the name of the Brown Medical School to The Warren Alpert Medical School of Brown University.

name <p><a>ar:&#x0645;&#x0639;&#x0647;&#x062f; &#x0643;&#x0627;&#x0644;&#x064a;&#x0641;&#x0648;&#x0631;&#x0646;&#x064a;&#x0627; &#x0644;&#x0644;&#x062a;&#x0643;&#x0646;&#x0648;&#x0644;&#x0648;&#x062c;&#x064a;&#x0627;</a> <a>az:Kaliforniya Texnologiya &#x0130;nstitutu</a> <a>bn:&#x0995;&#x09cd;&#x09af;&#x09be;&#x09b2;&#x09bf;&#x09ab;&#x09cb;&#x09b0;&#x09cd;&#x09a8;&#x09bf;&#x09af;&#x09bc;&#x09be; name |name = Columbia University in the City of New York |motto = <em>In lumine Tuo videbimus lumen</em> (<a>Latin</a>) |mottoeng = In Thy light shall we see light (<a>Psalm</a> 36:9) |established = 1754 |type = <a>Private</a> |endowment = <a>US $</a>6.5 <a>billion</a>&lt;ref&gt;As of 2010.
name |logo = <a>center|225px</a> }} <strong>Columbia University in the City of New York</strong> (<strong>Columbia University</strong>) is a private research <a>university</a> in New York City and one of the eight members of the <a>Ivy League</a>.
name <p><a>thumb|Development of the Morningside Heights campus by 1915</a> In 1896, the trustees officially authorized the use of yet another new name, Columbia University, and today the institution is officially known as &quot;Columbia University in the City of New York.&quot;
name   <li>Robert A. McCaughey: <em>Stand, Columbia: A History of Columbia University in the City of New York, 1754&#x2013;2004</em>, Columbia University Press, 2003, ISBN 0231130082</li>
name <p>:<em>Not to be confused with <a>New York University</a>, formerly known as the <strong>University of the City of New York</strong>.</em> :<em>For similar uses, see <a>University of New York (disambiguation)</a>.</em>  The <strong>City University of New York</strong> (<strong>CUNY</strong>), <a>acronym</a> , is the public <a>university system</a> of <a>New York City</a>, with its administrative offices in <a>Yorkville</a> in <a>Manhattan</a>.&lt;ref&gt;&quot;<a>Administrative
name City University of New York.
name It is the largest urban university in the <a>United States</a>, consisting of 23 institutions: 11 senior colleges, six <a>community colleges</a>, the <a>William E. Macaulay Honors College</a> at CUNY, the doctorate-granting <a>Graduate School and University Center</a>, the <a>City University of New York School of Law</a>, <a>CUNY Graduate School of Journalism</a>, and the <a>Sophie Davis School of Biomedical Education</a>.
name Chancellor <a>Matthew Goldstein</a>, who recently championed higher education as critical to the nation's economic recovery efforts, said enrollment at City University of New York is at its highest level in more than three decades.</p>
name <a>&quot;City University of New York&quot;</a> <em>U.S. History Encyclopedia</em>&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>In 1961, Governor Nelson Rockefeller signed the bill that formally created the City University of New York to integrate these institutions, and a new graduate school, together into a coordinate system of higher education for the city, and by 1979, the Board of Higher Education had become the Board of Trustees of the CUNY.&lt;ref
name <a>1986 Memo from Bogdan Denitch to Joseph S. Murphy, Chancellor City University of New York in 1980s</a>.
name <p>In September 2006, The City University of New York received a $30,000,000 gift from philanthropist and <a>City College</a> alumnus, William E. Macaulay, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of <a>First Reserve Corporation</a>.
name   <li><a>Iris Weinshall</a> (B.A. 1975), <a>vice chancellor</a> at the City University of New York and a former commissioner of the <a>New York City Department of Transportation</a></li>
name   <li><a>City University of New York Athletic Conference</a></li>
name <p> <a>Category:Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools</a> <a>Category:Association of Public and Land-Grant Universities</a> <a>Category:American Association of State Colleges and Universities</a> <a>Category:City University of New York</a> <a>Category:Educational institutions established in 1961</a></p>
name <p><a>de:City University of New York</a> <a>es:Universidad de la Ciudad de Nueva York</a> <a>fa:&#x062f;&#x0627;&#x0646;&#x0634;&#x06af;&#x0627;&#x0647; &#x0634;&#x0647;&#x0631;&#x06cc; &#x0646;&#x06cc;&#x0648;&#x06cc;&#x0648;&#x0631;&#x06a9;</a> <a>fr:Universit&#x00e9; de la Ville de New York</a> <a>it:Universit&#x00e0; della Citt&#x00e0; di New York</a> <a>ja:&#x30cb;&#x30e5;&#x30fc;&#x30e8;&#x30fc;&#x30af;&#x5e02;&#x7acb;&#x5927;&#x5b66;</a> <a>no:City University of New York</a> <a>pt:Universidade da Cidade de Nova Iorque</a> <a>uk:&#x041c;&#x0456;&#x0441;&#x044c;&#x043a;&#x0438;&#x0439; &#x0443;&#x043d;&#x0456;&#x0432;&#x0435;&#x0440;&#x0441;&#x0438;&#x0442;&#x0435;&#x0442; &#x041d;&#x044c;&#x044e;-&#x0419;&#x043e;&#x0440;&#x043a;&#x0430;</a> <a>zh:&#x7ebd;&#x7ea6;&#x5e02;&#x7acb;&#x5927;&#x5b66;</a></p>
name <p> <strong>Drexel University</strong> is a <a>private</a> <a>coeducation</a>al <a>university</a> with the main campus located in the <a>University City</a> area within <a>Philadelphia</a>, <a>Pennsylvania</a>, <a>United States</a>.
name <a>right|thumb|A machine testing laboratory at Drexel University, circa 1904.</a>
name Drexel University was founded in 1891 as the Drexel Institute of Art, Science and Industry by Philadelphia financier and philanthropist <a>Anthony J. Drexel</a> to provide educational opportunities in the &#x201c;practical arts and sciences&#x201d; for women and men of all backgrounds.
name Drexel became the Drexel Institute of Technology in 1936, and in 1970 Drexel Institute of Technology gained university status, becoming Drexel University.
name On July 1, 2002, Drexel was officially united with the former MCP Hahnemann University, creating the Drexel University College of Medicine; and in the fall of 2006, Drexel established its School of Law.
name In June 2009, the president of Drexel University, <a>Constantine Papadakis</a>, died of lung cancer.
name Originally added to Drexel University as the Drexel University College of Law, the <a>Earle Mack School of Law</a> was renamed on May 1, 2008 in honor of Drexel alumnus <a>Earle I. Mack</a>.
name <p>Drexel is composed of nine colleges, including the <a>College of Information Science and Technology</a> and the <a>College of Arts and Sciences</a>, two of the oldest colleges within Drexel; and the <a>Drexel University College of Engineering</a>, for which Drexel is perhaps best-known.
name The <a>Drexel University College of Medicine</a> is a recent addition to the university.
name <p>Drexel University is also known for creating the world's first Engineering Degree in <a>Appropriate Technology</a>.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name In the 2006 edition of <a>U.S. News &amp; World Report</a>, Drexel University is ranked the #109 university in the National Universities Doctoral category and the LeBow College of Business is ranked #99.
name <p> Drexel University's campus is divided into three parts: the <a>University City Campus</a>, the Center City Hahnemann Campus, which is comprised mainly of <a>Hahnemann University Hospital</a>, and the <a>Queen Lane College of Medicine Campus</a>.
name <p><a>thumb|The southern portion of Drexel's campus</a> The  University City Main Campus of Drexel University is located just west of the <a>Schuylkill River</a> in the University City district of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.
name The two prominent performing stages at Drexel University are the Mandell Theater and the Main Auditorium.
name Theater at Drexel University</a>&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>The Queen Lane Medical Campus was purchased in 2003 by Drexel University from MCP Hahnemann University.
name <p>On October 29, 2007, a 40-person delegation from Drexel University completed a four-day visit to <a>Placer County, California</a> in preparation for a study on bringing a 6,000-student college campus to <a>Roseville</a>, a suburb in the <a>Sacramento metropolitan area</a>.
name <p>On January 5, 2009, Drexel University opened the Center for Graduate Studies in Sacramento.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; , the Sacramento Center offers a Ed.D. program in Educational Leadership and Management, and master degree programs in:  Business Administration, Higher Education, Human Resource Development, Information Systems, Public Health, Interdepartmental Medical Science, and Library and Information Science&gt;&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;  Drexel awards students at its Sacremento Center fellowships from a $10 million annual budget allocation.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>The Undergraduate Student Government Association of Drexel University works with administrators to solve student problems and tries to promote communication between the students and the administration.</p>
name The student operated station is part of the Paul F. Harron Studios at Drexel University.
name name=&quot;DUArch&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; Other publications include <em>MAYA</em>, the undergraduate student literary and artistic magazine; <em>D&amp;M Magazine</em>, Design &amp; Merchandising students crafted magazine; <em>The Smart Set from Drexel University</em>, an online magazine founded in 2005; and <em>The Drexelist</em> a blog-style news source founded in 2010.</p>
name The Drexel Publishing Group oversees <em>ASK</em> (The Journal of the College of Arts and Sciences at Drexel University), <em>Painted Bride Quarterly</em>, a 36-year-old national literary magazine housed at Drexel; <em>The 33rd</em>, an annual anthology of student and faculty writing at Drexel; <em>DPG Online Magazine</em>, and <em>Maya</em>, the undergraduate literary and artistic magazine.
name Grotto:Most Expensive College Dorms for 2009-2010</a>&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;<a>About Drexel University</a>&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>The Flame of Knowledge, a fountain once located in the main quad (now relocated to the area in front of North Hall), used to be known as the &quot;Drexel Shaft&quot; in the late 70s and early 80s,&lt;ref&gt;{{Cite web|title=Drexel University Digital Collections - Return of the Red-Eye (Satire)|url=<a>http://www.library.drexel.edu/archives/displays/items/show/207</a>|accessdate=2009-05-11}}
name <li>From July through September 2009, the movie, <a>How Do You Know</a>, starring Jack Nicholson, Reese Witherspoon, and Owen Wilson was filmed on the Drexel University main campus inside of the <a>Armory</a>.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</li>
name <p>Drexel University created the annual <a>$100,000 Anthony J. Drexel Exceptional Achievement Award</a> to recognize a faculty member from a U.S. institution whose work transforms both research and the society it serves.

name <p><a>ar:&#x062c;&#x0627;&#x0645;&#x0639;&#x0629; &#x062f;&#x0631;&#x0643;&#x0633;&#x0644;</a> <a>de:Drexel University</a> <a>es:Universidad Drexel</a> <a>fa:&#x062f;&#x0627;&#x0646;&#x0634;&#x06af;&#x0627;&#x0647; &#x062f;&#x0631;&#x06a9;&#x0633;&#x0644;</a> <a>fr:Universit&#x00e9; Drexel</a> <a>is:Drexel-h&#x00e1;sk&#x00f3;li</a> <a>la:Universitas Drexel</a> <a>ja:&#x30c9;&#x30ec;&#x30af;&#x30bb;&#x30eb;&#x5927;&#x5b66;</a> <a>no:Drexel University</a> <a>pt:Universidade Drexel</a> <a>simple:Drexel University</a> <a>vi:&#x0110;&#x1ea1;i h&#x1ecd;c Drexel</a> <a>zh:&#x5353;&#x514b;&#x7d22;&#x5927;&#x5b78;</a></p>
name <p>{{Infobox university |name=Dartmouth College |image_name=Dartmouth College shield.svg
name <p><strong>Dartmouth College</strong> (, ) is a <a>private</a>, <a>Ivy League</a> university, comprising a liberal arts college, <a>Dartmouth Medical School</a>, <a>Thayer School of Engineering</a>, and <a>Tuck School of Business</a>, as well as 19 graduate programs in the arts and sciences.&lt;ref
name Incorporated as &quot;Trustees of Dartmouth College,&quot;&lt;ref name=&quot;irs&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; it is one of the nine <a>Colonial Colleges</a> founded before the American Revolution.&lt;ref
name <p>Dartmouth College was established in 1769 by <a>Congregational</a> minister <a>Eleazar Wheelock</a>.
name news | url = <a>http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D02E0D81F3BF934A35752C1A96F958260</a> | title = A Frat Party Is:; a) Milk and Cookies; b) Beer Pong | first = Randy | last = Kennedy | work =The New York Times | quote = ...at Dartmouth College a place where traditions die hard... | date = 1999-11-07 | accessdate = 2008-08-23 }}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>[[File:Dartmouth College campus 2007-10-02 03 - Charter.jpg.jpg|thumb|upright|The
name Charter of Dartmouth College on display in [[Baker Memorial Library]].
name name=&quot;CricketRauner&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;]] In 1819, Dartmouth College was the subject of the historic <a>Dartmouth College case</a>, in which the State of <a>New Hampshire</a>'s 1816 attempt to amend the College's royal charter to make the school a public university was challenged.
name In 2004, <a>Booz Allen Hamilton</a> selected Dartmouth College as a model of institutional endurance &quot;whose record of endurance has had implications and benefits for all American organizations, both academic and commercial,&quot; citing <em><a>Trustees of Dartmouth College v. Woodward</a></em> and Dartmouth's successful self-reinvention in the late 19th century.&lt;ref&gt;;
name section on Dartmouth College footnoted to John R. Thelin, who also selected the <a>University of Oxford</a> for inclusion as a model of institutional endurance.&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name With these professional schools and graduate programs, conventional American usage would accord Dartmouth the label of &quot;Dartmouth University&quot;;&lt;ref name=&quot;about-dartmouth-facts&quot;/&gt; however, because of historical and nostalgic reasons (such as <em><a>Dartmouth College v. Woodward</a></em>), the school uses the name &quot;Dartmouth College&quot; to refer to the entire institution.&lt;ref
name <p>[[File:BakerLibrary.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Baker Memorial Library]] at Dartmouth College]] Dartmouth functions on a quarter system, operating year-round on four ten-week <a>academic term</a>s.
name The nominees for alumni trustee are determined by a poll of the members of the Association of Alumni of Dartmouth College, selecting from among names put forward by the Alumni Council or by alumni petition.</p>
name <p>Dartmouth College is situated in the rural town of <a>Hanover, New Hampshire</a>, located in the <a>Upper Valley</a> along the <a>Connecticut River</a> in <a>New England</a>.
name [[File:Dartmouth College campus 2007-10-20 09.JPG|thumb|left|A view of the Sherman Fairchild Physical Science Center and Wheeler Hall from the tower of [[Baker Memorial Library]]]] In addition to its nineteen graduate programs in the arts and sciences, Dartmouth is home to three separate graduate schools.
name <p>Dartmouth's nine libraries are all part of the collective Dartmouth College Library, which comprises 2.48 million volumes and 6 million total resources, including videos, maps, sound recordings, and photographs.&lt;ref
name <p>[[File:Dartmouth College campus 2007-06-23 Memorial Field 02.JPG|thumb|right|[[Memorial Field (Dartmouth College)|Memorial Field]]]] Dartmouth's original sports field was <a>the Green</a>, where students played <a>cricket</a> and <a>old division football</a> during the 19th century.&lt;ref
name <p> [[File:Dartmouth College campus 2007-10-03 Robinson Hall.JPG|thumb|right|Robinson Hall houses many of the College's student-run organizations, including the [[Dartmouth Outing Club]].
name Dartmouth College was among the first institutions of higher education to <a>desegregate</a> fraternity houses in the 1950s, and was involved in the movement to create <a>coeducational</a> Greek houses in the 1970s.&lt;ref&gt;
name As of 2007, Dartmouth College fields 34 intercollegiate varsity teams: 16 for men, 16 for women, and coeducational sailing and equestrian programs.
name name=&quot;about-dartmouth-athletics&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; As is mandatory for the members of the Ivy League, Dartmouth College does not offer athletic scholarships.&lt;ref
name <p>It is often pointed out that the charter of Dartmouth College, granted to <a>Eleazar Wheelock</a> in 1769, proclaims that the institution was created &quot;for the education and instruction of Youth of the Indian Tribes in this Land in reading, writing and all parts of Learning ... as well as in all liberal Arts and Sciences; and also of English Youth and any others.&quot;&lt;ref
name The funds for the Charity School for Native Americans that preceded Dartmouth College were raised primarily by the efforts of a Native American named <a>Samson Occom</a>, and at least some of those funds were used to help found the College.&lt;ref
name <p> <a>thumb|upright|left|Seal of Dartmouth College</a></p>

name <p>According to Payscale, Dartmouth College alums have among the highest average starting salaries ($58,200) in the United States, as well as the absolute highest average income ten years after graduation ($129,000).&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>

name }} <strong>Harvey Mudd College</strong> is a private <a>residential</a> <a>liberal arts college</a> of <a>science</a>, <a>engineering</a>, and <a>mathematics</a>, located in <a>Claremont, California</a>.

name Harvey Mudd College was funded by Mudd's friends and family, and named in his honor.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p><a>thumb|left|300px|Harvey Mudd College entrance on Dartmouth Ave</a> Harvey Mudd College's mission is to educate <a>scientist</a>s, <a>engineer</a>s, and <a>mathematician</a>s to be well-versed in the <a>social sciences</a> and <a>humanities</a> so that they better understand the impact of their work on society.
name <p>, Harvey Mudd College is tied for 14th with <a>Grinnell College</a>, <a>United States Military Academy</a>, and <a>Washington and Lee University</a> among liberal arts colleges in the <a>United States</a> as rated by the <a>U.S. News and World Report</a>&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; and as of 2010, is ranked second to <a>Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology</a> in <a>Terre Haute, Indiana</a> as the best undergraduate engineering program at a school whose highest degree is a bachelor's or master's&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|url= <a>http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/spec-engineering</a> |title=America's Best Colleges 2011: Best Undergraduate Engineering Programs (where doctorate not offered)|publisher=<a>U.S. News &amp; World Report</a>|accessdate=2011-01-09}}&lt;/ref&gt; by <a>U.S. News &amp; World Report</a>.
name <p>Harvey Mudd College is said to be one of the few colleges in the US with very low grade inflation.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name <p>In 1997, Harvey Mudd College became the sole American undergraduate-only institution ever to win 1st place in the <a>ACM International Collegiate Programming Contest</a>.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name name=Willard/&gt;  The signature building at Kansas State University, <a>Anderson Hall</a>, developed in three stages between 1877 and 1884.
name <p>Harvey Mudd College, along with <a>Wake Forest University</a>, long held out as the last four-year colleges or universities in the U.S. to accept only <a>SAT</a> and not <a>ACT</a> test scores in their admissions process.&lt;ref
name <p>Graduates of Harvey Mudd College earn the highest salaries among graduates of any college in the United States.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>

name <p><strong>Hunter College</strong>,  established in 1870 by Thomas Hunter, is a public university and one of the constituent colleges of the <a>City University of New York</a> (CUNY) system, located on <a>Manhattan</a>'s <a>Upper East Side</a>.&lt;ref
name name=&quot;Undergraduate Catalog p.3&quot;&gt;Hunter College 2007-2010 Undergraduate Catalog, p.3&lt;/ref&gt; Hunter is a coeducational liberal arts and sciences college that grants undergraduate, graduate, and doctoral degrees in more than 100 fields, and is nationally recognized for its diverse student body and academic excellence.&lt;ref&gt;<a>http://www.hunter.cuny.edu/academics/index.shtml</a>, &quot;Academics at Hunter&quot;, 1/4/08&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;hunter.cuny.edu&quot;&gt;<a>http://www.hunter.cuny.edu/communications/pressroom/news/princeton-review-again-names-hunter-one-of-america2019s-best-colleges</a>&lt;/ref&gt;
name <p><a>thumb|New York Normal College seen from Park Avenue (1874)</a> Hunter College has its origins in the 19th-century movement for <a>normal school</a> training which swept across the <a>United States</a>.
name (Today, the <a>elementary school</a> and the <a>high school</a> still exist at a different location, and are now called the Hunter College Campus Schools.)</p>
name <p><a>thumb|The North Building (left) was added in the 1930's on the previous gardens facing Park Avenue and destroying a large part of the original building (right), today Thomas Hunter Hall</a> <a>thumb|North Building at Park Avenue (2010)</a> In 1914 the Normal College became Hunter College in honor of its first president.
name By 1920, Hunter College had the largest enrollment of women of any municipally financed college in the United States.

name <p>Ithaca College was founded as the Ithaca Conservatory of Music in 1892 when a local violin teacher, William Grant Egbert, rented four rooms and arranged for the instruction of eight students.

name <p><strong>James Madison University</strong> (also known as <strong>JMU</strong>, <strong>Madison</strong>, or <strong>James Madison</strong>) is a <a>public</a> <a>coeducation</a>al <a>research</a> <a>university</a> located in <a>Harrisonburg</a>, <a>Virginia</a>, <a>U.S.</a> Founded in 1908 as the State Normal and Industrial School for Women at Harrisonburg, the university has undergone four name changes until settling with James Madison University.&lt;ref
name In 1976 the university's name was changed to James Madison University.&lt;ref
name <p>James Madison University is considered &quot;More Selective&quot; by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching.
name <p>Currently, James Madison University offers 108 degree programs on the bachelor's, master's, educational specialist and doctoral levels.
name <p>On October 2, 2009, James Madison University was granted a chapter by the <a>Phi Beta Kappa</a> academic honor society.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name Today, the campus of James Madison University has 111 major buildings on .&lt;ref
name <p>Several new construction projects on the campus of James Madison University have been included in Governor Tim Kaine's $1.65 billion higher education bond package.
name <p><a>thumb|200px|right|Students on the James Madison University quad</a></p>
name James Madison University's athletic teams use the name &quot;Dukes&quot; in competition, with the <a>Duke Dog</a>, a gray bulldog dressed in a purple cape and crown, as the school's mascot.
name <p>Most recently, James Madison University has used funds to create a new baseball and softball field complex by Memorial Hall.
name <p><a>de:James Madison University</a> <a>fa:&#x062f;&#x0627;&#x0646;&#x0634;&#x06af;&#x0627;&#x0647; &#x062c;&#x06cc;&#x0645;&#x0632; &#x0645;&#x062f;&#x06cc;&#x0633;&#x0648;&#x0646;</a> <a>ja:&#x30b8;&#x30a7;&#x30fc;&#x30e0;&#x30ba;&#x30fb;&#x30de;&#x30c7;&#x30a3;&#x30b9;&#x30f3;&#x5927;&#x5b66;</a> <a>no:James Madison University</a> <a>fi:James Madisonin yliopisto</a> <a>zh:&#x8a79;&#x59c6;&#x65af;&#x00b7;&#x9ea6;&#x8fea;&#x900a;&#x5927;&#x5b66;</a></p>
name <p>{{Infobox university |name= Kansas State University  |image= <a>210px</a> |motto= Rule by Obeying Nature's Laws |established= 1863 |type= <a>Public</a>, <a>State</a>, <a>Land-grant</a>, <a>University</a> |president= <a>Kirk H. Schulz</a> |city= <a>Manhattan</a> |state= <a>Kansas</a> |country= <a>U.S.</a> |students= 23,588 (Fall 2010)&lt;ref name = Enrollment&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; |undergrad= 18,778&lt;ref name= Factbook&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; |postgrad= 4,366 |faculty= 1,305&lt;ref name= Factbook/&gt; |endowment= <a>$</a>259.8
name |}} <strong>Kansas State University</strong>, commonly shortened to <strong>K-State</strong>, is an institution of higher learning located in <a>Manhattan</a>, <a>Kansas</a>, in the <a>United States</a>.
name <p>Kansas State University, originally named Kansas State Agricultural College, was founded on February 16, 1863, during the <a>American Civil War</a>, as a <a>land-grant institution</a> under the <a>Morrill Act</a>.&lt;ref
name name=Griffin/&gt;  Finally, upon the third attempt on February 16, 1863, the state accepted Manhattan's offer to donate the Blue Mont College building and grounds and established the state's land-grant college at the site &#x2013; the institution that would become Kansas State University.&lt;ref
name In 1959, the name changed again to Kansas State University of Agriculture and Applied Science to reflect a growing number of graduate programs.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name Jon Wefald</a> assumed the presidency of Kansas State University.
name The <a>Konza Prairie</a> is a native tallgrass prairie preserve located south of Manhattan, which is co-owned by <a>The Nature Conservancy</a> and Kansas State University and operated as a field research station by the department of biology.
name <p>Kansas State University offers the Landon Lecture Series for students, faculty and the community.
name Presently, both <a>U.S. Senators from Kansas</a> are graduates of Kansas State University.
name <p>The main campus of Kansas State University in Manhattan covers .
name <p>Kansas State University also offers Army ROTC (Reserve Officers' Training Corps) and Air Force ROTC programs.</p>
name <p><a>Category:Kansas State University</a> <a>Category:Land-grant universities and colleges</a> <a>Category:Association of Public and Land-Grant Universities</a> <a>Category:North Central Association of Colleges and Schools</a> <a>Category:Public universities</a> <a>Category:Riley County, Kansas</a> <a>Category:Universities and colleges in Kansas</a> <a>Category:Educational institutions established in 1863</a></p>
name <p><a>de:Kansas State University</a> <a>es:Universidad Estatal de Kansas</a> <a>fa:&#x062f;&#x0627;&#x0646;&#x0634;&#x06af;&#x0627;&#x0647; &#x0627;&#x06cc;&#x0627;&#x0644;&#x062a;&#x06cc; &#x06a9;&#x0627;&#x0646;&#x0632;&#x0627;&#x0633;</a> <a>fr:Universit&#x00e9; d'&#x00c9;tat du Kansas</a> <a>it:Universit&#x00e0; dello Stato del Kansas</a> <a>ja:&#x30ab;&#x30f3;&#x30b6;&#x30b9;&#x5dde;&#x7acb;&#x5927;&#x5b66;</a> <a>no:Kansas State University</a> <a>simple:Kansas State University</a> <a>ta:&#x0b95;&#x0bc7;&#x0ba9;&#x0bcd;&#x0b9a;&#x0bb8;&#x0bcd; &#x0bae;&#x0bbe;&#x0ba8;&#x0bbf;&#x0bb2;&#x0baa;&#x0bcd; &#x0baa;&#x0bb2;&#x0bcd;&#x0b95;&#x0bb2;&#x0bc8;&#x0b95;&#x0bcd;&#x0b95;&#x0bb4;&#x0b95;&#x0bae;&#x0bcd;</a> <a>th:&#x0e21;&#x0e2b;&#x0e32;&#x0e27;&#x0e34;&#x0e17;&#x0e22;&#x0e32;&#x0e25;&#x0e31;&#x0e22;&#x0e41;&#x0e04;&#x0e19;&#x0e0b;&#x0e31;&#x0e2a;&#x0e2a;&#x0e40;&#x0e15;&#x0e15;</a> <a>tr:Kansas Devlet &#x00dc;niversitesi</a></p>
name <p>{{Infobox university | name           = KAIST | image_name     = Seal of KAIST.png|200px

name <p><strong>KAIST</strong> (formerly the <strong>Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology</strong>), is located in <a>Daedeok Science Town</a>, <a>Daejeon</a>, <a>South Korea</a>.
name KAIST was established by the Korean government in 1971 as the nation's first research oriented science and engineering institution.
name KAIST is one of the nation's most prestigious science and technology institutions.
name The QS-The Times World University Rankings in the year of 2009 placed KAIST 69th in overall ranking and 21st in technology &amp; IT subject field in the world.</p>
name <p>KAIST was founded with government funding and was initially staffed with a number of Korean engineering and science talents educated in the United States.
name KAIST continues to be Korea&#x2019;s foremost center of strategic R&amp;D projects.
name KAIST offers grants and fellowships to international students.</p>
name <p>The President of KAIST,  <a>Nam Pyo Suh</a>, is an authority in axiomatic design technology.
name <p>&lt;!--<a>thumb|left|240px|KAIST Fountain and Students Hall</a>--&gt; The University has for many decades, recruited faculty from overseas.
name The current KAIST President <a>Nam Pyo Suh</a> taught for many years at <a>MIT</a>.
name <p>{| class=&quot;wikitable&quot; |- | February 16, 1971   | Establishment of Korea Advanced Institute of Science (KAIS), Hongneung Campus, Seoul |- | March 5, 1973  | First entrance ceremony for the master&#x2019;s program  |- | August 20, 1975  | First graduation ceremony for the master&#x2019;s program  |- | September 12, 1975  | First entrance ceremony for the doctoral program  |- | August 19, 1978  | First graduation ceremony for the doctoral program  |- | December 31, 1980  | Establishment of Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST) united with KIST  |- | December 31, 1984   | Establishment of Korea Institute of Technology, newly added bachelor degree course  |- | March 3, 1986   | First entrance ceremony for Korea Institute of Technology  |- | June 12, 1989  | KIST separated from KAIST   |- | July 4, 1989   | United with Korea Institute of Technology (move to Daedeok Campus)  |- | December 17, 1990  | First graduation ceremony for bachelor&#x2019;s program  |- | October 1, 1996 | Establishment of <a>Korea Institute of Advanced Study (KIAS)</a>  |- | May 4, 2004  | Foundation of the National Nanofab Center (NNFC) |- | January 1, 2008 | Name change to only <em>KAIST</em>, replacing the spelled-out name |- | March 1, 2009 | <a>Information and Communications University</a> (ICU) was merged into KAIST as <a>KAIST Information Technology Convergence Campus</a> |}</p>
name <p>KAIST was established under the name of Korea Advanced Institute of Science (KAIS) under a special law on February 16, 1971, as the first research oriented graduate school in science and engineering in Korea.
name In 1989, KAIST established the education/research system of special talents in science and engineering fields in bachelor, master and doctoral degrees.
name <p><a>The University of Pennsylvania Band</a> has been a part of student life since 1897.
name statue of [[Jang Young Sil]], a Korean Scientist, in front of science library, Daejeon campus]] KAIST has led other colleges and research institutions in Korea and was verified by the <a>ABET</a> assessment (graduate course is within 10% of top US college level) in 1992, evaluation of nationwide colleges by Joongang Ilbo (1995, 1998&#x2013;2001, 2006, 2008-2010: number one in overall rank, and evaluation of Asian colleges by Asiaweek (1999~2000: Number one in science and technology), Chosun Ilbo evaluation of Asian colleges(2009,overall rank number one in the nation, 7th in Asia, world university ranking of The Times newspaper(2008: 34th of Top 100 world university in Technology) and others.</p>
name <p>Over the past 30 years, KAIST has produced 8,453 bachelors, 17,762 masters, 6,726 doctorate holders (doctors under 30 years of age were 2,920, 43.4%) giving a total of 32,941 alumni.
name The famous scientific publications such as&#x300c;Nature&#x300d; (GB, July 1993) and &#x300c;Science&#x300d; (USA, October 1993) have assessed that, &#x201c;KAIST has the potential to be the world best level education institution.&#x201d;</p>
name <p>It founded the National Nano Lab in 2002 and established the KAIST Institute in 2006.</p>
name <p>The first act of President Suh upon his inauguration in July 2006 was to lay out the KAIST Development Plan.
name The &#x2018;KAIST Development Five-Year Plan&#x2019; was finalized on February 5, 2007 by KAIST Steering Committee after a thorough examination.
name The goals of KAIST set by Suh are to become one of the best science and technology universities in the world, and to become one of the top-10 universities by 2011.</p>
name <p>In January 2008, the university dropped its full name, <em>Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology</em>, and changed its official name to only <em>KAIST</em>.&lt;ref&gt;<a>'KAIST'
name Decides Not to Use Original Full Name</a>, KAIST announcement, January 10, 2008.&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>Governed by a special law, KAIST has an autonomous and flexible academic system.
name <p>KAIST has produced many doctors through the Integrated Master&#x2019;s and Doctoral program and Early Completion System.
name <p>In an endeavor to take the initiative in developing information technology (IT) for the 21st century, KAIST is launching the new College of Information Science and Technology in 2008 by relocating the Departments of Electrical Engineering, Computer Science and Industrial and Systems Engineering from the College of Engineering and establishing the Department of Knowledge Service Engineering.
name In 2009 when ICU merge into KAIST, Department of Information and Communications Engineering at ICU comes into College of Information Science and Technology.</p>
name <p>The KAIST College of Information Science and Technology is aimed at nurturing creative leaders equipped to address the world's complex problems by creating and developing information technologies.
name <p>The interdisciplinary major program at KAIST was founded on September 1, 2003.
name <p>KAIST established the Graduate School of Management in March, 1996.
name In 2006, The Graduate School of Management joined with the Graduate School of Finance and the Graduate School of Information &amp; Media Management to form KAIST Business School.</p>
name <p>&lt;!--<a>thumb|right|240px|KAIST Campus Painting Map</a>--&gt; KAIST is located in the <a>Daedeok Research Complex</a> in the city of <a>Daejeon</a>, 150 kilometers south of the capital <a>Seoul</a>.
name <p>KAIST has two campuses in <a>Daejeon</a> and one campus in Seoul.
name <p>KAIST Daejeon campus (besides Daejeon Expo Park) has total twenty nine dormitories where all students wishing to reside can stay.
name <p>KAIST Daejeon campus (besides Munji-Dong) <a>KAIST Information Technology Convergence Campus</a> has total two dormitories.One for undergraduate students and the other for graduate students.
name <p><a>thumb|left|240px|KAIST Digital Science Library</a> KAIST digital science library was established in 1971 as KAIS library, and it went through a merge and separation process with KIST library.
name <p>KAIST always does its best to provide optimal facilities to create a cozy atmosphere where students can complete their courses satisfactorily.</p>
name <p>Seven KAIST Institutes (KIs) have been set up: the KI for the BioCentury, the KI for Information Technology Convergence, the KI for the Design of Complex Systems, the KI for Entertainment Engineering, the KI for the NanoCentury, the KI for Eco-Energy, and the KI for Urban Space and Systems.
name KAIST is currently conducting research planned by the government and private businesses that are worth mounts as much as 100 billion won.
name In terms of ownership of intellectual property rights, KAIST holds 1,591 domestic patents and 500 international patents so far.</p>
name <p><a>KAIST Institute (KI)</a></p>
name <p>Researchers at the <a>Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology</a> (KAIST) have developed an electric transport system (called <a>Online Electric Vehicle</a>,  OLEV)  where the vehicles get their power needs from cables underneath the surface of the road via <a>non-contact magnetic charging</a>, (where a power source is placed underneath the road surface and power is wirelessly picked up on the vehicle itself.
name In July 2009 the researchers successfully supplied up to 60% power to a bus over a <a>gap</a> of  from a power line embedded in the ground using power supply and pick up technology developed in-house.&lt;ref&gt;<a>http://www.gizmag.com/kaist-olev-electric-vehicle/12557/</a>&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>In 2010 <a>QS World University Rankings</a>&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; ranked KAIST 79th overall in the world, coming 24th in Engineering &amp; IT.
name KAIST was again recognized as a number one University in Korea by Joong Angh Ill Bo Review.
name In the year of 2009, KAIST's department of industrial design has also been listed in the top 30 Design Schools by Business Week.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name KAIST ranked the best university in <a>Republic of Korea</a> and the 7th university in <a>Asia</a> in the Top 100 Asian Universities list, the first regional ranking issued by <a>THE-QS World University Rankings</a>.&lt;ref&gt;<a>In the Top 100 Asian Universities List, HKU won the first, KAIST 7th, SNU 8th(2009 &#xc544;&#xc2dc;&#xc544; &#xb300;&#xd559;&#xd3c9;&#xac00; &#xd64d;&#xcf69;&#xb300; 1&#xc704;, &#xce74;&#xc774;&#xc2a4;&#xd2b8; 7&#xc704;, &#xc11c;&#xc6b8;&#xb300; 8&#xc704;)</a> <a>Chosun Ilbo</a> 2009.5.12.
name The cluster is built around KAIST, Korea's leading technical university, Chungnam University, a group of government research institutes in applied technologies, corporate research centers and more than 900 venture companies.</p>
name <p>The Times-QS World University Rankings 2009 - KAIST 69th overall, 21st in the field of Engineering/Technology &lt;references /&gt; <a>http://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings/world-university-rankings/2009/results</a></p>

name <p><strong>Kent State University</strong> (also known as <strong>Kent</strong>, <strong>Kent State</strong>, and <strong>KSU</strong>) is a <a>public</a> research <a>university</a> located in <a>Kent, Ohio</a>, <a>United States</a>.
name What would become Kent State University was established in 1910 as an institution for training public school teachers.
name journal |last= Johnson|first= Christopher |date= 1 August 2005|title= Liquid Crystal Institute blazes new trails at Kent State|journal= Inside Business|publisher=Great Lakes Publishing |url= <a>http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-160029070.html</a>|accessdate=2009-09-23 |quote= ...the world's No. 1 liquid crystal research center is at Kent State University: the Liquid Crystal Institute (LCI).}}&lt;/ref&gt;
name |work= Kent State University Special Collections and Archives |publisher= Kent State University|accessdate=23 September 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p><a>thumb|left|200px|Kent State Gateway Arch on Kent Campus</a> Kent State University is an eight-campus system in northeastern Ohio, with the main administrative center in <a>Kent</a>.
name Within the Kent State University system, the main campus is officially referred to as the &quot;Kent Campus&quot;.&lt;ref
name The university also operates the 18-hole Kent State Golf Course and Centennial Research Park just east of campus in <a>Franklin Township</a> and the  <a>Kent State University Airport</a> in <a>Stow</a>.</p>
name In addition to the Salem Campus, Kent State University Salem owns and operates the old Salem Middle School called the &quot;City Center&quot; in which administrative offices, classes, and student services are located.</p>
name <p> The Stark Campus is the largest regional campus of Kent State University, serving around 10,300 students each year (5,300 in academic programs, 5,000 in executive and graduate education).
name <p>::<em>See also: <a>Kent State University Airport</a>.</em></p>
name   <li>Kent State University is one of few universities with graduate programs in Information Architecture and Knowledge Management (IAKM [<a>http://iakm.kent.edu/</a>])
name <li><em><a>Fusion Magazine (Kent State University)</a></em> is published twice a year by KSU students in print and on the Internet.
name <a>Fusion Magazine (Kent State University)</a> addresses sexual minority issues within the general population using illustrative photo essays and in-depth feature articles.</li>

name <p>{{Infobox University |native_name= Lunds universitet |name= Lund University |latin_name= Universitas Lundensis <em>or</em> Universitas Gothorum Carolina.
name The lion in Lund University's seal holds a book in one hand, and a sword in the other.&lt;/ref&gt;
name |established= 1666 |type= Public |city=  <a>Lund</a> |country= <a>Sweden</a> |image_name= Lund University seal.svg
name |state= <a>Scania</a> |staff= 5,300 total (including non-scientific)  |students     = 46,000 (<a>FTE</a>, 2009)&lt;ref&gt;<a>Swedish Higher Education Authority (<em>H&#x00f6;gskoleverket</em>) - Annual report 2010 (Swedish), page 106ff</a>&lt;/ref&gt; |undergrad=  |doctoral= 3,200 |website= <a>http://www.lunduniversity.lu.se</a> |affiliations= <a>Universitas 21</a>&lt;br/&gt; <a>LERU</a>&lt;br/&gt; <a>EUA</a>&lt;br/&gt; <a>ASAIHL</a> |head_label=<a>Rector magnificus</a> and <a>Vice Chancellor</a> |head= Prof. <a>Per Eriksson</a> |campus= Urban }} <strong>Lund University</strong> (), located in <a>Lund</a> in the province of <a>Scania</a>, <a>Sweden</a>, is one of northern Europe's most prestigious <a>universities</a>&lt;ref&gt;<a>New Partnership with Swedish University: Lund University</a>&lt;/ref&gt; and one of <a>Scandinavia</a>'s largest institutions for education and research&lt;ref name=&quot;euro-scholars&quot;&gt;<a>Lund University, Sweden</a>, <em>Euro Scholars</em> Website&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;solander&quot;&gt;<a>Lund University</a>, <em>The Solander Program</em> Website&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;oeacademy&quot;&gt;<a>Universities in the &#x00d8;resund Region</a>, <em>&#x00d8;resund Entrepreneurship Academy</em> Website&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;<a>Welcome to Lund University</a>&lt;/ref&gt;, frequently ranked among the world's top 100 universities&lt;ref&gt;<a>Top 200 Universities</a>, Website of <em>QS Top Universities</em>&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;<a>Shanghai Jiao Tong University</a>'s <a>Academic Ranking of World Universities</a> - <a>2007</a>, <a>2006</a>, <a>2005</a>&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;<a>The Complete List: The Top 100 Global Universities</a>&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;[<a>http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/world-university-rankings/2010-2011/top-200.html</a>]&lt;/ref&gt;.
name <p>Lund University has eight <a>faculties</a>&lt;ref&gt;<a>Organisation</a>&lt;/ref&gt;, with additional campuses in the cities of <a>Malm&#x00f6;</a> and <a>Helsingborg</a>, with 27,780 students in more than 274 different programmes and 2000 separate courses.
name <p>After the <a>Treaty of Roskilde</a> in 1658, the <a>Scanian lands</a> came under the possession of the Swedish Crown, which quickly founded the Lund University in 1666 as the means of Swedification.
name The name was in some formal use until the late 19th century, when Lund University became the widespread denomination.</p>
name name=Andersson&gt;<a>Lund University Medical Faculty</a> Hedda Andersson (1861-1950)&lt;/ref&gt; Hilma Borelius was the first woman who finished a doctorate in Lund, in 1910.
name In 1992 <a>Boel Flodgren</a>, Professor of Business Law, was appointed <a>rector magnificus</a> (or, strictly speaking, <em>rectrix magnifica</em>) of Lund University.
name <p>Lund University is internationally known as Scandinavia's largest research university.&lt;ref
name Notable exchangees include United States Supreme Court Justice <a>Ruth Bader Ginsburg</a>, who spent time at Lund University in the 1960s conducting research.&lt;ref&gt;Linda,
name <p>Lund University is also organised into more than 20 institutes and research centres [<a>http://www.lunduniversity.lu.se/o.o.i.s/24893</a>], such as</p>
name <p><a>thumb|University Library</a> Lund University library was established in 1666 at the same time as the university and is one of Sweden's oldest and largest.
name <h2>Notable people connected to Lund University</h2>
name <p> The following is a select list of some of the most notable people who have been affiliated with Lund University as students or academics, please refer to the main article for more information.</p>

name <p><a>ca:Universitat de Lund</a> <a>da:Lunds Universitet</a> <a>de:Universit&#x00e4;t Lund</a> <a>et:Lundi &#x00dc;likool</a> <a>es:Universidad de Lund</a> <a>fr:Universit&#x00e9; de Lund</a> <a>ga:Ollscoil Lund</a> <a>ko:&#xb8ec;&#xb4dc; &#xb300;&#xd559;&#xad50;</a> <a>hi:&#x0932;&#x0941;&#x0902;&#x0921; &#x0935;&#x093f;&#x0936;&#x094d;&#x0935;&#x0935;&#x093f;&#x0926;&#x094d;&#x092f;&#x093e;&#x0932;&#x092f;</a> <a>id:Universitas Lund</a> <a>la:Universitas Lundensis</a> <a>lt:Lundo universitetas</a> <a>arz:&#x062c;&#x0627;&#x0645;&#x0639;&#x0629; &#x0644;&#x0648;&#x0646;&#x062f;</a> <a>nl:Universiteit van Lund</a> <a>ja:&#x30eb;&#x30f3;&#x30c9;&#x5927;&#x5b66;</a> <a>no:Lunds universitet</a> <a>pnb:&#x0644;&#x0646;&#x0688; &#x06cc;&#x0648;&#x0646;&#x06cc;&#x0648;&#x0631;&#x0633;&#x0679;&#x06cc;</a> <a>pl:Uniwersytet w Lund</a> <a>pt:Universidade de Lund</a> <a>ru:&#x041b;&#x0443;&#x043d;&#x0434;&#x0441;&#x043a;&#x0438;&#x0439; &#x0443;&#x043d;&#x0438;&#x0432;&#x0435;&#x0440;&#x0441;&#x0438;&#x0442;&#x0435;&#x0442;</a> <a>simple:Lund University</a> <a>fi:Lundin yliopisto</a> <a>sv:Lunds universitet</a> <a>zh:&#x9686;&#x5fb7;&#x5927;&#x5b66;</a></p>

name <p>  {{Infobox university |name = Massachusetts Institute of Technology |image = <a>200px</a> |motto = <em>Mens et Manus</em> |mottoeng = Mind and Hand&lt;ref name=&quot;seal&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; |established = 1861 (opened 1865) |type = <a>Private</a> |calendar = 4-1-4 |president = <a>Susan Hockfield</a> |chancellor = Phillip Clay |provost = <a>L.
name <a>billion</a>&lt;ref name=&quot;Endowment&quot;/&gt; |logo = <a>center|85px|MIT Logo</a> |affiliations = <a>NEASC</a>, <a>AAU</a>, <a>COFHE</a>, <a>NASULGC</a>}}  The <strong>Massachusetts Institute of Technology</strong> (<strong>MIT</strong>) is a private research institute located in <a>Cambridge</a>, <a>Massachusetts</a>. MIT has five schools and one college, containing a total of 32 academic departments, with a strong emphasis on scientific and technological research.</p>
name In 1861, The Commonwealth of Massachusetts approved a charter for the incorporation of the &quot;Massachusetts Institute of Technology and <a>Boston Society of Natural History</a>&quot; submitted by <a>William Barton Rogers</a>.
name <em>Geology at MIT 1865-1965: A History of the First Hundred Years of Geology at Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

name <p>{{Infobox University |name = Millsaps College |image = <a>Image:Millsaps College.png</a>
name <p><strong>Millsaps College</strong> is a private <a>liberal arts college</a> located in <a>Jackson, Mississippi</a>.
name Millsaps College is featured in Loren Pope&#x2019;s <em>Colleges That Change Lives</em> and is one of only 24 private colleges nationwide named a <em>Best Buy</em> in the 2010 edition of Fiske&#x2019;s <em>Top Financial Finds on the College Tuition Market.</em></p>
name <p><a>thumb|left|Millsaps College campus.</a>
name <p><a>thumb|right|Mausoleum on the campus of Millsaps College, Jackson, Mississippi, containing the graves of Major Reuben Webster Millsaps and his wife.</a></p>
name George Marion Harmon (1978-2000) - After 22 years of leading Millsaps College, Dr. Harmon announced his resignation in the Spring of 1999.
name His last day as president of Millsaps College was June 30, 2000.&lt;ref
name <p> {{Infobox university | name = Macquarie University | motto = <em>And gladly teche</em>&lt;br&gt;from the general Prologue to The Canterbury Tales, Geoffrey Chaucer c.1400 | established = 1964 | type = <a>Public</a> | endowment = AU$563m&lt;br /&gt;&lt;small&gt;(31 December 2008)&lt;/small&gt;&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; | chancellor = <a>The Hon.
name | image = <a>center|The Arms of Macquarie University|170px</a> | coor= | logo = <a>230px</a> }} <strong>Macquarie University</strong> is an <a>Australian</a> <a>public</a> teaching and <a>research university</a> located in <a>Sydney</a>, with its main campus situated in <a>Macquarie Park</a>.
name <p>Macquarie University also has the largest student exchange programme in Australia.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name <p>Also affiliated with the university are several research centres, schools and institutes including the <a>Macquarie Graduate School of Management</a>, Australian Proteome Analysis Facility, the Institute of Human Cognition and Brain Science, the <a>Macquarie University Research Park</a> and the <a>Macquarie University Hospital</a>.</p>
name <p>Macquarie University's linguistics department developed the <a>Macquarie Dictionary</a>, the copyright on which it still owns.</p>
name <p><a>thumb|left|First Students at Macquarie University</a>The idea of founding a third university in Sydney was flagged in the early 1960s when the <a>New South Wales Government</a> formed a committee of enquiry into higher education to deal with a perceived emergency in university enrolments in <a>New South Wales</a>.
name <p>Macquarie University was formally established in 1964 with the passage of the Macquarie University Act 1964 by the New South Wales parliament.
name The fledgling Macquarie University Council decided that planning for the campus would be done within the university, rather than by consultants, and this led to the establishment of the architect-planners office.&lt;ref
name In their book <em>Liberality of Opportunity</em>, Bruce Mansfield and Mark Hutchinson describe the founding of Macquarie University as &#x2018;an act of faith and a great experiment&#x2019;.&lt;ref&gt;Liberality of Opportunity, Mansfield and Hutchinson, p. 317&lt;/ref&gt; An additional topic considered in this book is the <a>science reform movement</a> of the late 1970s that resulted in the introduction of a named science degree, thus facilitating the subsequent inclusion of other named degrees in addition to the traditional BA.&lt;ref&gt;Liberality of Opportunity, Mansfield and Hutchinson, pp.
name The first Vice-Chancellor of Macquarie University was Alexander George Mitchell, who held the position until December 1975, when he was replaced by Edwin Webb, who served until 1986.
name name=&quot;theaust&quot;/&gt;&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;<a>They call her the grand dame of Sydney's Macquarie University but as Di Yerbury left her post as Vice Chancellor, controversy descended.
name <em>Northern Michigan University: The First 75 Years.</em>
name <p>During 2007, Macquarie University faced a restructuring of its student organisation after an audit raised questions about management of hundreds of thousands of dollars in funds by student organisations&lt;ref name=&quot;audit&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; At the centre of the investigation was Victor Ma, president of the Macquarie University Students' Council, who had previously been involved in a high-profile case of student election fixing at the <a>University of Sydney</a>.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name The Federal Court ordered on 23 May 2007 that Macquarie University Union Ltd be wound up.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news |url = <a>http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/cth/federal_ct/2007/844.html</a>
name |title = Macquarie University v Macquarie University Union Limited (No 2) [2007] FCA 844 |date= 2007-05-23 |accessdate = 2008-01-25 |publisher = Commonwealth of Australia and Federal Court of Australia }}&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>Following the dissolution of Macquarie University Union Ltd, the outgoing student organisation was replaced with a new wholly owned subsidiary company of the university, known as U@MQ Ltd.
name The new student organisation originally lacked a true student representative union; however, following a complete review and authorisation from the university Council, a new student union known as Macquarie University Students Association (MUSRA) was established in 2009.&lt;ref&gt;<a>http://www.uatmq.com.au/umqwr/_assets/main/lib90019/musra%20charter_final_24jun09.pdf</a>&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <a>thumb|300px|Macquarie University Lake</a> The university introduced a new curriculum in January 2010 that was intended to broaden the knowledge of graduates and to include study in general education subjects.
name <p>The <a>University Council</a> is the governing authority of the university under the <em>Macquarie University Act 1989</em>.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name <p><a>thumb|left|140px|Information Board at Central Courtyard</a> Macquarie University's main campus is located about  north-west of the <a>Sydney CBD</a> and is set on 126&nbsp;hectares of rolling lawns and natural bushland.
name The university&#x2019;s first architect-planner was <a>Walter Abraham</a>, one of the first six administrators appointed to Macquarie University.
name <p><a>thumb|E4A Building at Entrance to University</a>Today, Macquarie University is served by the <a>Macquarie University railway station</a>, which opened in 2009, as well as a bus interchange within the campus that provides close to 800 bus services daily.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name Apart from its centres of learning, the campus features the <a>Macquarie University Research Park</a>, museums, art galleries, a sculpture park, an observatory, a sport and aquatic centre, a fauna park and also the private <a>Macquarie University Hospital</a>.
name   <li><strong>Macquarie City Campus</strong>: Macquarie City Campus is a teaching campus of Macquarie University which associates with <a>Navitas</a>.
name In mid 2007, the university opened the Macquarie City Campus in the <a>Sydney CBD</a>, offering Macquarie University&#x2019;s foundation studies, selected undergraduate and postgraduate degrees.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name   <li><strong>Macquarie Manly Campus</strong>: In association with Macquarie University, the <a>International College of Management, Sydney</a>, offers a two-year Diploma programme (only in Hospitality, Event and International tourism), an Associate Degree Programme and a three-year Bachelor of Business Administration Degrees specialised in Hospitality, Event, International tourism, Retail, Property, and Sports Management as well as graduate certificates and master programmes.
name Bachelor and master degrees are awarded by Macquarie University and students have access to the university library for study and research.</li>
name Macquarie University showed a significant drop in the 2007 <a>THES - QS World University Rankings</a> (From 2010 two separate rankings will be produced by the <a>Times Higher Education World University Rankings</a> and the <a>QS World University Rankings</a>).
name <p>The <a>Shanghai Jiao Tong University</a>&#x2019;s <a>Academic Ranking of World Universities</a> in 2009 ranked Macquarie University as 7th in Australia (following <a>University of Western Australia</a> and <a>UNSW</a>), while the UK&#x2019;s <em><a>Times Higher Education Supplement</a></em> World University Rankings published in October 2009 ranked Macquarie 9th in Australia (behind the <a>University of Adelaide</a> and the <a>University of Western Australia</a>).&lt;ref
name &lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; Macquarie University teachers also have received numerous awards and citations from the Carrick Institute for Learning and Teaching in Higher Education since it was established in 2004.&lt;ref&gt;<a>Macquarie
name <p><a>thumb|Macquarie University Library</a> The <a>Macquarie University Library</a> was opened in 1967 and contains over 1.8 million items.
name <p>Located on the western side of the campus is the <a>Macquarie University Sport and Aquatic Centre</a>.
name <p>The <a>Macquarie University Research Park</a> offers opportunities for collaboration with leading companies.
name <p>The Macquarie University Observatory was originally constructed in 1978 as a research facility but, since 1997, has been accessible to the public through its Public Observing Program.&lt;ref&gt;<a>The
name Macquarie University Observatory</a>&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>The <a>Macquarie University Hospital</a> was completed in 2010 and is the most advanced medical facility in Australia.
name <p>Macquarie University has two residential colleges on its campus, <a>Dunmore Lang College</a> and <a>Robert Menzies College</a>, both founded in 1972.
name In addition to these residential colleges is the <a>Macquarie University Village</a> which contains over 890 rooms inside multiple two storey townhouses and apartment block.</p>
name Marquette, Michigan: Northern Michigan University Press, 1975.
name <p> <a>thumb|Campus Hub</a> ;Campus Experience :Campus Experience was officially launched in January 2008 under the name of U@MQ, and is the new organisation that manages Macquarie University&#x2019;s non-academic services of food and retail, sport and recreation, student groups, child care, and entertainment.
name <p>;2SER :Macquarie University has its own community radio station on campus, <a>2SER FM</a>.
name The station is jointly owned by Macquarie University and <a>UTS</a> and broadcasts its programmes on the frequency 107.3 FM.</p>
name <p>;Conception Day :Macquarie University students celebrate Conception Day each year to &#x2013; according to legend - commemorate the date of conception of Lachlan Macquarie, as his birthday fell at the wrong time of year for a celebration.

name <p>{{Infobox University |name          = Northern Michigan University |image         =<a>200px|Northern Michigan University Seal</a>  |motto         = Northern.
name <p><strong>Northern Michigan University</strong> is a 4 year college <a>public university</a> established in 1899 located in <a>Marquette</a>, in <a>Michigan</a>'s <a>Upper Peninsula</a>.
name With a population of nearly 10,000 undergraduate and graduate students, Northern Michigan University is the Upper Peninsula's largest university.</p>
name <p>Northern Michigan University, NMU for short, was established in 1899 by the <a>Michigan Legislature</a> as Northern State Normal School with the original purpose of providing teacher preparation programs in Michigan's then-wild and sparsely populated <a>Upper Peninsula</a>.
name   <li>Northern's multi-purpose student events center, funded in part by a $2 million donation by 1971 alumnus John Berry, opened in 1999 and is the home of the Northern Michigan University hockey and men's and women's basketball teams.
name <p><a>thumb|right|250px|University Center</a> Northern Michigan University is accredited by the <a>North Central Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools</a>.&lt;ref&gt;[<a>http://www.ncahlc.org/index.php?option=com_frontpage&amp;Itemid=113</a> &lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>Northern Michigan University's vision for education in the 21st century is a learning environment that embraces technology to enhance student access, promote the development of independent learners and encourage greater student-faculty communication and collaboration.
name <p>The <a>United States Olympic Education Center</a> on the campus of Northern Michigan University is one of four Olympic training centers in the country and the only one located on a college campus.
name The Superior Edge encompasses a wide range of in- and out-of-classroom experiences that will provide Northern Michigan University students with a distinct advantage by better preparing them for careers, lifelong learning, graduate school, and life as engaged citizens.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>The North Wind began in 1972 as Northern Michigan University's first independent, student newspaper.
name <p><a>WUPX</a> is Northern Michigan University's non-commercial, student run, radio station.
name <p>The Associated Students of Northern Michigan University (ASNMU) is made up of three distinct branches: Executive, Legislative and Judicial.

name <p> {{Infobox university |name         =Ohio State University |image_name   = Seal of the Ohio State University.png
name <p><strong>Ohio State University</strong>, commonly referred to as <strong>Ohio State</strong> or <strong>OSU</strong>, is a <a>public</a> research university located in <a>Columbus, Ohio</a>.
name It also includes regional campuses in [[Ohio State University, Lima Campus|Lima]], [[Ohio State University, Mansfield Campus|Mansfield]], [[Ohio State University, Marion Campus|Marion]], [[Ohio State University, Newark Campus|Newark]], and [[Ohio State University Agricultural Technical Institute|Wooster]].</pre>
name <p> Ohio State University was founded in 1870 as a <a>land-grant university</a> in accordance with the <a>Morrill Act of 1862</a> under the name of Ohio Agricultural and Mechanical College.
name In 1878, and in light of its expanded focus, the college permanently changed its name to the now-familiar &quot;Ohio State University&quot;, with &quot;The&quot; as part of its official name,&lt;ref&gt;<a>Ohio State University Timeline 1870 TO 1899</a>, Ohio State University Archives&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;Ohio 3335&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; although the state code that declares the &quot;The&quot; neglects it in sections&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; including in the title of the section that originally declares it.&lt;ref
name <p>Internationally, in 2010 <a>QS World University Rankings</a>&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; ranked Ohio State University 124th in the world, and 40th in the United States.

name <p><strong>Oberlin College</strong> is a selective private <a>liberal arts</a> college in <a>Oberlin, Ohio</a>, noteworthy for having been the first American institution of higher learning to regularly admit female and black students.

name The experiment was a success, and now all but one of Oberlin College's dormitories are coed.

name <p><a>Oberlin College Library</a> system is one of the largest and finest undergraduate libraries in the nation.
name Bot generated title --&gt;</a>&lt;/ref&gt;   In addition to the breadth of its holdings, the Oberlin College Library is recognized for its quality: it received the <a>Association of College and Research Libraries Excellence in Academic Libraries Award</a> in 2002, and in 2006 Director of Libraries Ray English was named the <a>ACRL</a>'s <a>Academic-Research Librarian</a> of the Year.
name The entirely student-run Oberlin College Marching Band (OCMB), founded in 1998, performs at various sporting events including football games, women's rugby, and pep rallies throughout the year.

name <p><strong>Occidental College</strong> is a selective, <a>private</a>, <a>coeducational</a> <a>liberal arts college</a> located in the <a>Eagle Rock</a> neighborhood of <a>Los Angeles, California</a>.
name Founded in 1887, Occidental College, or &quot;<strong>Oxy</strong>&quot; as it is called by students and <a>alumni</a>, is one of the oldest liberal arts colleges on the <a>West Coast</a>.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;

name <p> {{Infobox university |name           = Purdue University |image_name     = Purdue University Seal.svg |image_size     = 150px |motto          = &lt;!--

name <p><strong>Purdue University</strong>, located in <a>West Lafayette</a>, <a>Indiana</a>, <a>U.S.</a>, is the <a>flagship university</a> of the six-campus <a>Purdue University System</a>.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name Purdue established the first <a>college credit</a> offered in <a>flight training</a>, the first four-year <a>bachelor's degree</a> in <a>aviation</a>, and the first university <a>airport</a> (<a>Purdue University Airport</a>).
name On May 6, 1869, it was decided that the college would be founded near the city of <a>Lafayette</a> and legislators established the institution as Purdue University, in the name of the institution&#x2019;s principal benefactor.&lt;ref
name <p>Purdue University is well known for its diverse majors in <a>aerospace</a>.
name The <a>Purdue University Airport</a> was the first university-owned airport in the United States.
name <p>In 2010, Purdue University received a $1.35 million grant from the <a>United States Air Force</a> to develop alternative fuels and test aircraft engines at a new facility.
name <p>In 1930 Purdue became the first university in the country to offer college credit for flight training, and later became the first university to open its own airport, the <a>Purdue University Airport</a>.
name <p>At one point, Purdue University owned and operated a <a>charter airline</a> operation under <a>FAR</a> part 121 simply called &quot;Purdue Airlines&quot;.
name In fact, <a>Hugh Hefner</a>'s famous <a>Playboy</a> <a>DC-9</a> aircraft was leased from Purdue, and its permanent storage was at Purdue University.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>[[File:Purdue Engineering Fountain, angle.JPG|thumb|right|The [[Engineering Fountain]] at Purdue]] The Purdue Mall is the central quad of Purdue University.
name Also near the Purdue Mall is Felix Haas Hall, which was constructed in 1909 as Memorial Gymnasium in memory of the 17 Purdue University football players, coaches, alumni, and fans who perished in the <a>Purdue Wreck</a> railroad accident on October 31, 1903.
name <p>{| class=&quot;wikitable&quot; style=&quot;font-size:90%; width:100%; border:0; text-align:center; line-height:120%;&quot; |+ <strong>Colleges of Purdue University</strong> |- |<a>College of Agriculture</a>&lt;br/&gt;1869 |<a>College of Education</a>&lt;br /&gt;1908 |<a>College of Engineering</a>&lt;br/&gt;1876 |<a>College of Health and Human Sciences</a>&lt;br/&gt;1905 |<a>College of Liberal Arts</a>&lt;br/&gt;1953 |<a>College of Pharmacy</a>&lt;br/&gt;1884 |<a>College of Science</a>&lt;br/&gt;1907 |<a>College of Technology</a>&lt;br/&gt;1964 |} {| class=&quot;wikitable&quot; style=&quot;font-size:90%; width:100%; border:0; text-align:center; line-height:120%;&quot; |+ <strong>Engineering Schools of Purdue University</strong> |- |<a>School of Aeronautics and Astronautics</a> |Agricultural and Biological Engineering |<a>Weldon School of Biomedical Engineering</a> |School of Chemical Engineering |School of Civil Engineering |<a>School of Electrical and Computer Engineering</a> |- |School of Engineering Education |School of Industrial Engineering |School of Materials Engineering |School of Mechanical Engineering |School of Nuclear Engineering |Division of Construction Engineering and Management |Division of Environmental and Ecological Engineering |} {| class=&quot;wikitable&quot; style=&quot;font-size:90%; width:100%; border:0; text-align:center; line-height:120%;&quot; |+ <strong>Other Schools of Purdue University</strong> |- |<a>Krannert School of Management</a>* |School of Health Sciences |School of Nursing |<a>School of Veterinary Medicine</a>* |}</p>

name <p>Purdue University generated a record $333.4 million in sponsored research funding during the 2007&#x2013;08 fiscal year with participation from <a>National Science Foundation</a>, <a>National Aeronautics and Space Administration</a>, and the U.S. departments of <a>Agriculture</a>, <a>Defense</a>, <a>Energy</a>, and <a>Health and Human Services</a>.&lt;ref

name <p><a>thumb|left|Cary Quad and Spitzer Court at Purdue University</a> Purdue University operates fifteen separate <a>residence hall</a>s for its undergraduate and graduate students, including: Cary Quadrangle, <a>Earhart</a> Hall, First Street Towers, <a>Harrison</a> Hall, Hawkins Hall, Hillenbrand Hall, Hilltop Apartments, <a>McCutcheon</a> Hall, Meredith Hall, Owen Hall, Purdue Village, Shreve Hall, <a>Tarkington</a> Hall, <a>Wiley</a> Hall, and Windsor Halls.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name All cooperative houses are governed under the Purdue Cooperative Council which is led by Purdue University students who live in these houses.
name <p>Purdue University hosts the nation's third largest <a>Greek community</a>, with approximately 5,000 students participating in one of the 46 men's fraternities or 29 women's sororities.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name <p><a>WBAA</a> is a <a>radio station</a> owned by Purdue University.

name <p><a>thumb|200px|Purdue Pete &#x2013; one of the most recognized symbols of Purdue University</a>  The moniker for the University's athletics teams has become a popular reference for all things Purdue.
name Special]] - the official mascot of Purdue University]] --&gt; In the more than 130 years since the founding of the university, several mascots have emerged in support of the Boilermaker athletic teams, including: The <a>Boilermaker Special</a>, <a>Purdue Pete</a>, and more recently, Rowdy.</p>
name <p>The <a>Boilermaker Special</a> has been the official mascot of Purdue University since 1940.
name <p>As the unofficial mascot of Purdue Athletics, <a>Purdue Pete</a> is one of the most recognized symbols of Purdue University.</p>

name <p> The official <a>fight song</a> of Purdue University, &quot;<a>Hail Purdue!</a>&quot;, was composed in 1912 by alumni Edward Wotawa (music) and James Morrison (lyrics) as the &quot;Purdue War Song&quot;.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;

name <p>{{Infobox University |name = Reed College |image = <a>120px|Reed Griffin</a> |caption = Mascot of Reed College |established = 1908 |type = <a>Private</a> <a>liberal arts college</a> |president = <a>Colin Diver</a> |city = <a>Portland</a> |state = <a>Oregon</a> |country = <a>United States</a> |coor=  |mascot=<a>Griffin</a> |undergrad = 1,442 (1,402 full-time; 40 part-time)&lt;ref name=&quot;Headcount&quot; &gt;{{cite web | title = Historical Enrollment (Fall Census Headcount) | publisher = Institutional Research, Reed College | url = <a>http://web.reed.edu/ir/enrollment_hist.html</a> }}&lt;/ref&gt; |postgrad = 29  |faculty = 135 |endowment = $311.1 million (June 2009)&lt;ref&gt;National Association of College and University Business Officers (NACUBO), 2010.
name <p><strong>Reed College</strong> is a <a>private</a>, <a>independent</a>, <a>liberal arts college</a> located in southeast <a>Portland, Oregon</a>.
name <p><a>right|thumb|Reed College's Eliot Hall on a rare snowy day.</a>
name The <strong>Reed Institute</strong> (the legal name of the college) was founded in 1908, and Reed College held its first classes in 1911.
name <p>Reed has no fraternities or <a>sororities</a>, and few <a>NCAA</a> sports teams,&lt;ref&gt;One NCAA sports team at Reed has been the Reed College Ski Team, which as early as 1937, and as late as 1988, competed with the <a>University of Oregon</a> and other regional schools.
name <p><a>right|thumb|The Reed College campus</a></p>
name <p>{{main|Criticism of college and university rankings (North America)}} In 1995 Reed College refused to participate in the <a>U.S. News and World Report</a> &quot;best colleges&quot; rankings, making it the first educational institution in the United States to refuse to participate in college rankings.
name According to an article in the college's alumni magazine, &quot;because of the decisive support expressed by Reed's faculty, students, and alumni for the three besieged teachers and for the principle of academic freedom, Reed College's experience with McCarthyism stands apart from that of most other American colleges and universities.
name news | author=Munk, Michael | title=Oregon Tests Academic Freedom in (Cold) Wartime: The Reed College Trustees versus Stanley Moore | work=The Oregon Historical Quarterly | year=1996 }}&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name E. Doyle's 1920 Master Plan</a> The Reed College campus was established on a southeast <a>Portland</a> tract of land known in 1910 as Crystal Springs Farm, a part of the Ladd Estate, formed in the 1870s from original land claims.
name At the same time the Willard House (donated to Reed in 1964), across from the college's main entrance at SE Woodstock and SE Reed College Place, was converted from faculty housing to administrative use.
name <p><a>thumb|The Blue Bridge</a> The Reed College Canyon, a natural area and national wildlife preserve, bisects the campus, separating the academic buildings from many of the residence halls (the so called <em>cross-canyon halls</em>).
name <p>The Reed College Co-op is a theme residence located in Garden House, after many years on the first floor of MacNaughton Hall.
name The griffin was featured on the coat-of-arms of founder Simeon Reed&lt;ref name=&quot;coat-of-arms&quot; /&gt; and is now on the official seal of Reed College.</p>
name The most common examples of &quot;Richmond Rose&quot; are the satin tapes securing the degree certificate inside a Reed College diploma.</p>
name <p>An unofficial <a>motto</a> of Reed is &quot;Communism, Atheism, Free Love&quot;, and can be found in the Reed College Bookstore on sweaters, t-shirts, etc.
name <p>Every year's <em>Reed College Student Handbook</em> (a manual on student life written by students, not to be confused with the <em>College Handbook</em>, which is written by college officials) contains a test called the &quot;Reed College Immorality Quotient&quot; that tests an individual's <a>immorality</a> on topics such as <a>sex</a>, <a>theft</a>, and <a>drug use</a>.</p>

name <p>{{Infobox university |image_name= CardSeal-1.gif |image_size= 165px |caption = Seal of Stanford University |name =Stanford University |native_name =Leland Stanford Junior University |motto = &lt;br /&gt; (<a>German</a>)&lt;ref name=&quot;casper&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; |mottoeng = The wind of freedom blows&lt;ref name=&quot;casper&quot; /&gt; |established = 1891&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; |type = <a>Private</a> |calendar= Quarter |president = <a>John L. name |logo = <a>center|225px</a> }} The <strong>Leland Stanford Junior University</strong>, commonly referred to as <strong>Stanford University</strong> or <strong>Stanford</strong>, is a <a>private research university</a> located in <a>Stanford, California</a>, United States with a strong emphasis on scientific, technological and social science research.
name <p>The motto of Stanford University, selected by President Jordan, is &quot;<em>Die Luft der Freiheit weht.</em>&quot;
name While some colleges dropped football entirely, a few, such as the University of California and Stanford University, replaced it with English rugby.
name J.; Vettel,  &quot;The Protean Nature of Stanford University's Biological Sciences, 1946-1972&quot;, <em>Historical Studies in the Physical &amp; Biological Sciences; 2004 35(1): 95-113&lt;/ref&gt;</em></p>
name During 1955-85, solid state technology research and development at Stanford University followed three waves of industrial innovation made possible by support from private corporations, mainly Bell Telephone Laboratories, Shockley Semiconductor, Fairchild Semiconductor, and Xerox PARC.
name In the College of Arts and Sciences, Seattle University's graduate program in psychology is notable as one of the few schools in the country to focus on <a>existential phenomenology</a> as a therapeutic method.&lt;ref&gt;<a>http://www.seattleu.edu/artsci/</a>&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>[[Image:Stanford Campus Aerial Photo.JPG|300px|thumb|right|An [[aerial photography|aerial photograph]] of the Stanford University campus]] Stanford University is located on an &lt;ref name=&quot;stanford_tours&quot;/&gt; campus on the <a>San Francisco Peninsula</a>, in the northwest part of the <a>Santa Clara Valley</a> (<a>Silicon Valley</a>) approximately  southeast of <a>San Francisco</a> and approximately  northwest of <a>San Jose</a>.
name <p>Stanford University owns , which makes it the second largest university in the world in terms of contiguous area.
name <p>Stanford University is actually its own <a>census-designated place</a> within <a>unincorporated</a> <a>Santa Clara County</a>, although some of the university land (including the <a>Stanford Shopping Center</a> and the <a>Stanford Research Park</a>) is within the city limits of Palo Alto.
name <p> Contemporary campus landmarks include the <a>Main Quad</a> and <a>Memorial Church</a>, the <a>Cantor Center for Visual Arts</a> and <a>art gallery</a>, the <a>Stanford Mausoleum</a> and the <a>Angel of Grief</a>, <a>Hoover Tower</a>, the <a>Rodin</a> sculpture garden, the <a>Papua New Guinea Sculpture Garden</a>, the <a>Arizona Cactus Garden</a>, the <a>Stanford University Arboretum</a>, <a>Green Library</a> and <a>the Dish</a>.
