name And in 2009, the Sustainable Endowments Institute awarded Stanford University a grade of A- in its annual College Sustainability Report Card, making it one of the top fifteen of the 300 colleges and universities in the U.S. and Canada reviewed.
name <p>Stanford University is a tax-exempt <a>corporate trust</a> owned and governed by a privately appointed 35-member <a>Board of Trustees</a>.&lt;ref
name The Stanford trustees also oversee the <a>Stanford Research Park</a>, the <a>Stanford Shopping Center</a>, the <a>Cantor Center for Visual Arts</a>, <a>Stanford University Medical Center</a>, and many associated medical facilities (including the <a>Lucile Packard Children's Hospital</a>).&lt;ref name=&quot;FG facts&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>The university is organized into seven schools: <a>School of Humanities and Sciences</a>, <a>School of Engineering</a>, <a>School of Earth Sciences</a>, <a>School of Education</a>, <a>Graduate School of Business</a>, <a>Stanford Law School</a> and the <a>Stanford University School of Medicine</a>.&lt;ref
name <p>The <a>Associated Students of Stanford University</a> (ASSU) is the student government for Stanford University and all registered students are members.&lt;ref

name <p>The Stanford University Libraries hold a collection of more than eight million volumes.

name <p>}} <strong>Seattle University (SU)</strong> is a Jesuit Catholic university located in the <a>First Hill</a> neighborhood of <a>Seattle</a>, <a>Washington</a>, USA.&lt;ref&gt;<a>http://www.law.seattleu.edu/Office_and_Administration/Admission/Seattle_Living/Housing.xml</a> &quot;<strong>First Hill</strong>.
name <a>U.S. News &amp; World Report</a>, in its &quot;Best Colleges 2011,&quot; ranked Seattle University 6th out of schools in the West that offer a full range of master's and undergraduate programs.&lt;ref&gt;<a>http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/seattle-wa/seattle-university-3790</a>&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>In 1948, Seattle College changed its name to Seattle University under Father Albert A. Lemieux, S.J.
name In 1993, the <a>Seattle University School of Law</a> was established through purchase of the Law School from the <a>University of Puget Sound</a> in <a>Tacoma, Washington</a>.
name [[Image:Seattle U St Ignatius 11.jpg|thumb|left|Interior, Chapel of St. Ignatius, Seattle University|Chapel of St. Ignatius, designed by [[Steven Holl]].]]
name The Seattle University campus is  and is located on First Hill, near downtown Seattle, Wash.
name Pastier, <a>Seattle University's Chapel of St. Ignatius</a>, HistoryLink.org
name Accessed online 28 February 2007.&lt;/ref&gt;&#x2014;and a large glass sculpture in the PACCAR Atrium of Piggot Hall by <a>Tacoma, Washington</a> artist <a>Dale Chihuly</a>,&lt;ref name=Potterf&gt;Tina Potterf, <a>Home Is Where the Art Is</a>, <em>Seattle University Magazine</em> article reproduced on the Seattle University web site.
name <p>Seattle University offers 61 bachelor's degree programs, 31 graduate degree programs and 27 certificate programs, plus a <a>law school</a> and a doctoral program in education.
name A Seattle University education is estimated to cost $150,000, although much of this is covered by financial aid.&lt;ref&gt;<a>King 5 News</a>, King 5 News.
name <p>Service-learning and social justice are components of the educational experience at Seattle University, which strives to &quot;empower leaders for a just and humane world.&quot;
name <p>Seattle University's Albers School of Business and Economics, started in 1945, was named after the Albers family.
name <p> <a>The Seattle University College of Arts and Sciences in</a> <a>Seattle</a>, <a>Washington</a> is the oldest undergraduate and graduate college affiliated with Seattle University, the Northwest's largest independent university.
name <p>The vision of Seattle University is to be the premier independent university of the Northwest in academic quality, Jesuit Catholic inspiration, and service to society.</p>
name <p>Between 1950 and 1971, Seattle University competed as a Division I independent school.
name In the 1950s, the basketball team was a powerhouse with brothers Johnny and Eddie O&#x2019;Brien, who led Seattle University as the only team in history to defeat the world famous <a>Harlem Globetrotters</a>.&lt;ref&gt;<a>Fifty years ago tonight, Seattle U. upset the mighty Globetrotters</a>, accessed January 24, 2008&lt;/ref&gt; In 1958, future <a>NBA Hall of Fame</a>r <a>Elgin Baylor</a> paced a men&#x2019;s basketball team that advanced to the <a>Final Four</a> and defeated top-ranked <a>Kansas State University</a> before losing to the <a>University of Kentucky</a>.
name Seattle University was also a leader in the area of racial diversity, with an integrated squad known as &#x201c;the United Nations team.&#x201d;</p>
name In the course of the 1960s, Seattle University produced more NBA players than any other school.
name Seattle University would like to re-join the West Coast Conference, which is made up of other small, private, religiously affiliated institutions.&lt;ref&gt;<a>http://www2.seattleu.edu/d1/display.aspx?id=1558#5</a>&lt;/ref&gt; </p>

name <p>}} <strong>Syracuse University</strong> (also referred to as <strong>SU</strong>) is a private research university located in <a>Syracuse</a>, <a>New York</a>, <a>United States</a>.
name Brief Report of Church Relatedness</em>: Syracuse University - INCORPORATION AND THE METHODIST CHURCH&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;William Joseph Whalen - Hospitals &amp; Universities&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;IAMSCU&quot;&gt;{{cite web|url = <a>http://public.gbhem.org/iamscu/search_results.asp?act=search_gen&amp;search_txt=Syracuse+University&amp;type=schools&amp;submit=GO</a>| title = Syracuse University |publisher = International Association of Methodist Schools, Colleges, and Universities (IAMSCU)|accessdate = 2007-06-30}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;SU &amp; UMC&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; Syracuse was elected to the <a>Association of American Universities</a> in 1966.</p>
name <p>Syracuse University athletic teams, known as the <a>Orange</a>, participate in 20 intercollegiate sports.
name <p><a>thumb|left|400px|First Annual Class of Syracuse University.</a>
name name=&quot;PioneerYears&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;Greene&quot;/&gt; White pressed that the university should locate on the hill in <a>Syracuse</a> (the current location of Syracuse University) due to the city's attractive transportation hub, which would ease the recruitment of faculty, students, and other persons of note.
name name=&quot;Greene&quot;&gt;{{cite book |author=Greene, John Edward |title=The Hill: an illustrated biography of Syracuse University (SU), 1870-present |publisher=Syracuse University Press |location=Syracuse |year=2000 |isbn=0-8156-0648-6}}&lt;/ref&gt; Rev. Daniel Steele, a former Genesee College president, served as the first administrative leader of Syracuse until its Chancellor was appointed.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name Comstock intended Syracuse University and the hill to develop as an integrated whole; a contemporary account described the latter as &quot;a beautiful town ... springing up on the hillside and a community of refined and cultivated membership ... established near the spot which will soon be the center of a great and beneficent educational institution.&quot;&lt;ref
name Dr. <a>Erastus Otis Haven</a>, Syracuse University chancellor and former president of the <a>University of Michigan</a> and <a>Northwestern University</a>, maintained that women should receive the advantages of higher education.
name <p>The growth of Syracuse University from a small liberal arts college into a major comprehensive university were due to the efforts of two men, Chancellor <a>James Day</a> and <a>John Archbold</a>.
name <p>John Dustin Archbold was a capitalist, philanthropist, and President of the Board of Trustees at Syracuse University.
name He was a close friend of Syracuse University Chancellor James R. Day, and gave almost $6&nbsp;million to the University over his lifetime.&lt;ref
name Archbold&#x2019;s ... is the president of the board of trustees of Syracuse University, an institution which has prospered so remarkably since his connection with it that its student roll has increased from hundreds to over 4,000, including 1,500 young women, placing it in the ranks of the foremost institutions of learning in the United States.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>After World War II, Syracuse University began to transform into a major research institution.
name <p>[[Image:Library hc.JPG|thumb|250px|right|[[Hiram College Library]], designed to resemble a <a>Lake freighter</a>.
name <p>From the early 1950s through the 1960s, Syracuse University added programs and staff that continued the transformation of the school into a research university.
name In 1966, Syracuse University was admitted to the <a>Association of American Universities</a>, an <a>organization</a> of leading research <a>universities</a> devoted to maintaining a strong system of academic <a>research</a> and education.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>

name <p><a>thumb|200px|right|SU's Flight 103 Memorial</a>  On December 21, 1988, 35 Syracuse University students were among the fatalities in the terrorist bombing of <a>Pan Am Flight 103</a> over <a>Lockerbie</a>, <a>Scotland</a>.
name <p>That evening, Syracuse University went on with a <a>basketball</a> game just hours after the attack, for which it was severely criticized.&lt;ref

name <p>The  College of Environmental Science and Forestry (ESF) operates its main academic campus immediately adjacent to Syracuse University.
name ESF was founded in 1911 as the <a>New York State College of Forestry</a> at Syracuse University, under the leadership of Syracuse University Trustee <a>Louis Marshall</a>, with the active support of Syracuse University Chancellor Day.
name The two schools share a common Schedule of Classes; students at both institutions may take courses at the other, and degrees from ESF bear the Syracuse University seal along with the State University of New York.

name <p> The Syracuse University <a>fraternity</a> and <a>sorority</a> system offers organizations that are members of the <a>Panhellenic Council</a> (NPC), the <a>Interfraternity Council</a> (IFC), the <a>National Association of Latino Fraternal Organizations</a>, the <a>National Multicultural Greek Council</a>, and the <a>National Pan-Hellenic Council</a> (NPHC).

name <p>  The <strong>University of Michigan, Ann Arbor</strong> (commonly referred to as <strong>Michigan</strong>, <strong>U-M</strong>, <strong>UMich</strong>, or <strong>U of M</strong>) is a <a>public</a> research <a>university</a> located in the <a>state</a> of <a>Michigan</a> in the <a>United States</a>.&lt;ref name=&quot;Carnegie&quot; /&gt; It is the state's oldest university and the flagship campus of the University of Michigan.
name <p>The university was founded in 1817 in <a>Detroit</a> as the <em>Catholepistemiad</em>, or University of Michigania, about 20 years before the <a>Michigan Territory</a> officially became a state.&lt;ref
name | title=The Central Forty and The Diag (1837) | year=2006 | publisher=University of Michigan History and Traditions Committee | accessdate=April 29, 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt; Since its establishment in Ann Arbor, the university has physically expanded to include more than 584 major buildings with a combined area of more than 31 million gross square feet (712&nbsp;acres or 2.38&nbsp;km&#x00b2;),&lt;ref name=&quot;campus size&quot; /&gt; and transformed its academic program from a strictly classical curriculum to one that includes science and research.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name When presidential candidate <a>John F. Kennedy</a> visited the University on October 14, 1960, he gave an impromptu speech on the steps of the <a>Michigan Union</a> that led to a University of Michigan student movement which contributed to the establishment of the <a>Peace Corps</a>.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name name=alumni&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; U-M owns the <a>University of Michigan Health System</a>&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; and has one of the largest research expenditures of any American university, passing the $1.14 billion dollar mark during the 2009-2010 academic year.&lt;ref
name <p> [[File:JasperCropseyUniversityOfMichigan.jpg|thumb|<em>University of Michigan</em> (1855) by [[Jasper Francis Cropsey]]|alt=Painting of a rolling green landscape with trees with a row of white buildings in the background]] The University of Michigan was  established in Detroit in 1817 as the <em>Catholepistemiad</em>, or University of Michigania, by the governor and judges of <a>Michigan Territory</a>.
name book | title=The Michiganensian Yearbook (Class of 1984) | publisher=University of Michigan | date=1984-1985 | page=164}}&lt;/ref&gt; During the 1980s and 1990s, the university devoted substantial resources to renovating its massive hospital complex and improving the academic facilities on the North Campus.
name There is also leased space in buildings scattered throughout the city, many occupied by organizations affiliated with the University of Michigan Health System.
name The University of Michigan's largest residence hall, Bursley Hall, is located on North Campus.</p>
name The University of Michigan Golf Course was included in a listing of top holes designed by what <em><a>Sports Illustrated</a></em> calls &#x201c;golf&#x2019;s greatest course architect.&#x201d;
name Alfred Taubman College of Architecture &amp; Urban Planning</a> || 1906 |- | Horace H. Rackham School of Graduate Studies || 1912 |- | <a>Gerald R. Ford School of Public Policy</a> || 1914 |- | <a>School of Education</a> || 1921 |- | <a>Stephen M. Ross School of Business</a> || 1924 |- | <a>School of Natural Resources &amp; Environment</a> || 1927 |- | School of Public Health ||1941 |- | School of Social Work || 1951 |- | <a>School of Information</a> || 1969 |- | <a>School of Art &amp; Design</a> || 1974 |- | <a>School of Kinesiology</a> || 1984 |} The University of Michigan consists of a flagship campus in Ann Arbor, with two regional campuses in <a>Dearborn</a> and <a>Flint</a>.
name &lt;/ref&gt; Between the establishment of the University of Michigan in 1837 and 1850, the Board of Regents ran the university directly; although they were, by law, supposed to appoint a Chancellor to administer the university, they never did.
name <p>The President of the University of Michigan is the principal executive officer of the university.
name The office was created by the <a>Michigan Constitution</a> of 1850, which also specified that the president was to be appointed by the Regents of the University of Michigan and preside at their meetings, but without a vote.&lt;ref
name name=&quot;size&quot; /&gt; The Medical School is partnered with the <a>University of Michigan Health System</a>, which comprises the university's three hospitals, dozens of outpatient clinics, and many centers for medical care, research, and education.</p>
name | title=2009 Financial Report - The Michigan Difference {Campaign Summary} | publisher=The Regents of the University of Michigan | year=2009 | accessdate=August 31, 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; Like nearly all colleges and universities, U-M suffered significant realized and unrealized losses in its endowment during the second half of 2008.
name The two largest colleges at the University of Michigan are the College of Literature, Science, and the Arts (LS&amp;A) and the <a>College of Engineering</a>.
name The University of Michigan Engineering Council (UMEC) manages undergraduate student government affairs for the College of Engineering.
name In addition, the students that live in the residence halls are represented by the University of Michigan Residence Halls Association.</p>
name <p> The University of Michigan is a large, four-year, residential research university accredited by the <a>North Central Association of Colleges and Schools</a>.&lt;ref
name | title=Academic Year Tuition and Fees for Full-Time Students (1) By Degree Level, Academic Unit, and Residency | date=June 18, 2010 | publisher=University of Michigan Office of Budget &amp; Planning | accessdate=August 31, 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; U-M provides financial aid in the form of need-based loans, grants, scholarships, work study, and non-need based scholarships, with 77% of undergraduates in 2007 receiving financial aid.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | url=<a>http://provost.umich.edu/college_portrait/2009/page2.html</a>
name | title=The University of Michigan - Financial Aid Awarded to Undergraduates (Fall 2007) | year=2009 | publisher=U-M Provost's Office | accessdate=August 31, 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; 8% were eligible for <a>Pell Grant</a>s.&lt;ref name=&quot;Student debt&quot;&gt; &lt;/ref&gt; For undergraduates in 2008, 46% graduated with about $25,586 of debt in 2008.&lt;ref
name | title=University of Michigan-Enrollment by School and College, Gender, and Class Level For Term 1760 (Fall 2009) | publisher=University of Michigan Office of Budget &amp; Planning | date=September 28, 2009 | accessdate=January 3, 2010|format=PDF}}&lt;/ref&gt; in 600 academic programs, and each year about 5,400 new students are enrolled out of almost 30,000 applicants, of which almost 42% are admitted.&lt;ref
name <p>U-M is home to the <a>National Election Studies</a> and the <a>University of Michigan Consumer Sentiment Index</a>.
name The University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute and the Life Sciences Institute are located at the university.
name The <a>University of Michigan Press</a> is also a part of the U-M library system.</p>
name <p> <a>thumb|Mosher-Jordan Residence Hall|alt=Red brick facade with white stone fronts and angled roof</a> The University of Michigan's campus housing system can accommodate up to 10,900 people, or nearly 30 percent of the total student population at the university.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name The residence halls are organized into three distinct groups: Central Campus, Hill Area (between Central Campus and the University of Michigan Medical Center) and North Campus.
name There are also several engineering projects teams, including the <a>University of Michigan Solar Car Team</a>, which placed first in the <a>North American Solar Challenge</a> five times and third in the <a>World Solar Challenge</a> three times.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name <p>The university also showcases many community service organizations and charitable projects, including <a>Foundation for International Medical Relief of Children</a>, Dance Marathon at the University of Michigan,&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; <a>The Detroit Partnership</a>, <a>Relay For Life</a>, U-M Stars for the Make-A-Wish Foundation, InnoWorks at the University of Michigan, SERVE, Letters to Success, PROVIDES, Circle K, <a>Habitat for Humanity</a>,&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; and Ann Arbor Reaching Out.
name A large percentage of the students involved in the University of Michigan Greek Life are from out of state.
name The student-run and led <a>University of Michigan Pops Orchestra</a> is another musical ensemble that attracts students from all academic backgrounds.
name The <a>University of Michigan Men's Glee Club</a>, founded in 1859, is a men's chorus with over 100 members.
name Its eight member subset <a>a cappella</a> group, the <a>University of Michigan Friars</a>, which was founded in 1955, is the oldest currently running <em>a cappella</em> group on campus.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name Other student publications at the university include the conservative <em><a>The Michigan Review</a></em>, the progressive <em>Michigan Independent</em>, the <em><a>Michigan Journal of Political Science</a></em>, the <em>Michigan Journal of International Affairs</em>, <em><a>The Michigan Journal of Business</a></em>, the <em>University of Michigan Undergraduate Research Journal (UMURJ)</em>, <em><a>Michigan Journal of History</a></em>, and the humor publications <em><a>The Michigan Every Three Weekly</a></em> and the <em><a>Gargoyle</a></em>.
name <p> [[File:MichiganStadium2010UConn.JPG|thumb|A football game at [[Michigan Stadium]]|alt=Crowded stadium with yellow-colored &quot;Michigan&quot; written on a green field]] The University of Michigan's sports teams are called the <a>Wolverines</a>.
name <p>The University of Michigan's <a>fight song</a>, <em><a>The Victors</a></em>, was written by student <a>Louis Elbel</a> in 1898 following the last-minute football victory over the <a>University of Chicago</a> that won a league championship.
name The creators of <a><em>A Very Potter Musical</em></a>, known as <a>Team StarKid</a>, also graduated from the University of Michigan.</p>
name |title=The Wallenberg Story | publisher=The Wallenberg Foundation (University of Michigan) | year=2008 | accessdate=February 14, 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt; and <a>Benjamin D. Pritchard</a>, the Civil War general who captured <a>Jefferson Davis</a>.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name name=&quot;Heisman&quot; /&gt; Professional golfer <a>John Schroeder</a> and Olympic swimmer <a>Michael Phelps</a> also attended the University of Michigan, with the latter studying Sports Marketing and Management.

name <pre>|name              = University of Washington
name |image_name        = University of Washington Seal.png
name |former_names      = The Territorial University of Washington
name <p>The <strong>University of Washington</strong> (<strong>UW</strong>, commonly called <strong>U-Dub</strong>) is a public research <a>university</a>, founded in 1861 in <a>Seattle, Washington</a>, <a>United States</a>.
name name=&quot;UW Annual Report&quot;&gt;<a>University of Washington Annual Report (January 2006)</a>.&lt;/ref&gt;
name The UW occupies over 500 buildings, with over 20 million gross square footage of space, including the latest <a>University of Washington Plaza</a> consisting 325&nbsp;ft- 22 story UW Tower &amp; conference center.</p>
name <p>In 2010, the University of Washington was ranked 16th worldwide by the <em><a>Academic Ranking of World Universities</a></em>,&lt;ref name=&quot;top 500&quot;&gt;<a>Top 500 World Universities (2008)</a> <em>Institute of Higher Education, Shanghai Jiao Tong University</em>&lt;/ref&gt; 23rd worldwide by the <a>Times Higher Education World University Rankings</a>&lt;ref name=&quot;timeshighereducation1&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; and 55th worldwide by the <a>QS World University Rankings</a>.&lt;ref
name <p>UW opened officially on November 4, 1861, as the <strong>Territorial University of Washington</strong>.
name It would eventually grow into the <a>University of Washington Medical Center</a>, now ranked by <em><a>U.S. News and World Report</a></em> among the top ten hospitals in the <a>United States</a>.
name It was during this era in University of Washington history in which many Japanese Americans were sent away from the university to <a>internment camps</a> along the West-coast of the United States as part of <a>Executive Order 9066</a> following the attacks on <a>Pearl Harbor</a>.
name As a result, many Japanese American &quot;soon-to-be&quot; graduates were unable to receive their diplomas and be recognized for their accomplishment at the university until the University of Washington's commemoration ceremony for the <a>Japanese Americans</a> entitled <a>The Long Journey Home</a> held on May 18, 2008 at the main campus.</p>
name <p>In the early 1950s, the University of Washington Police Department was established.
name It currently has jurisdiction over the University of Washington campus and University-owned housing, except for the Radford Court apartments in <a>Sand Point</a>.</p>
name Additionally, Washington <a>senators</a>, <a>Henry M. Jackson</a> and <a>Warren G. Magnuson</a> used their political clout to funnel federal research monies to the University of Washington and to this day, UW is among the top recipients of federal research funds in the United States.
name <p>The University of Washington, Seattle campus is situated on the shores of <a>Union</a> and <a>Portage Bay</a>s, with views of the <a>Cascade Range</a> to the east and the <a>Olympic Mountains</a> to the west.
name South Campus occupies the land between Pacific Street and the <a>Lake Washington Ship Canal</a> which used to be a <a>golf course</a> and is given over to the <a>health sciences</a>, <a>oceanography</a>, <a>fisheries</a>, and the <a>University of Washington Medical Center</a>.
name <p> The current president of the University of Washington is Phyllis M. Wise, who had previously served as Provost and Executive Vice President.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name The undergraduate student government is the <a>Associated Students of the University of Washington</a> (ASUW) and the graduate student government is the <a>Graduate and Professional Student Senate</a> (GPSS).</p>
name <p>In 2006, the University of Washington research budget passed the $1 billion milestone.&lt;ref
name <p>In 2009, the University of Washington admitted 61% of applicants.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name University of Washington.&lt;/ref&gt;
name University of Washington.&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name Library]] reading room]] The <a>University of Washington library system</a> is among the largest academic libraries in the <a>United States</a>, with holdings of more than 7.3 million volumes.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name name=&quot;Inside HigherEd Husky Promise&quot;&gt;<a>Inside HigherEd Husky Promise</a>&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;UW Husky Promise&quot;&gt;<a>UW Husky Promise</a>&lt;/ref&gt; &quot;Last year, the University of Washington moved to a more comprehensive approach [to admissions], in which the admissions staff reads the entire application and looks at grades within the context of the individual high school, rather than relying on computerized cutoffs.&quot;&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name Recognized as one of the most prestigious early university entrance programs in the nation, this program facilitates early entry to the University of Washington for a carefully selected group of sixteen highly-capable young students younger than fifteen (15) years old.
name Students apply to the UW Academy during their 10th grade year, and if accepted, withdraw from high school at the end of 10th grade to enroll as freshmen at the University of Washington.&quot;
name <p>In 2010, the University of Washington was ranked 16th worldwide by the <em><a>Academic Ranking of World Universities</a></em>,&lt;ref name=&quot;top 500&quot;&gt;<a>Top 500 World Universities (2008)</a> <em>Institute of Higher Education, Shanghai Jiao Tong University</em>&lt;/ref&gt; 23rd worldwide by the <a>Times Higher Education World University Rankings</a>&lt;ref name=&quot;timeshighereducation1&quot;/&gt; and 55th worldwide by the <a>QS World University Rankings</a>.&lt;ref
name <p>In 2006, the University of Washington ranked 22nd internationally by <em><a>Newsweek</a></em> &quot;Top 100 Global Universities&quot;.&lt;ref
name <p>The Faculty Scholarly Productivity Index created by Academic Analytics ranks University of Washington overall at #19.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>Global Language Monitor, produced at Austin that ranks college based on media presence, placed University of Washington at #16 in the nation.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>University of Washington ranks #1 in <a>Peace Corps</a> volunteers in 2007 and #3 throughout the years.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>Kiplinger&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; ranked the University of Washington #7 of the top 100 colleges in early 2009 as one of the Best values in Public Colleges.</p>
name <p>The student newspaper is <em><a>The Daily of the University of Washington</a></em>, usually referred to as simply <em>The Daily</em>.
name PACCAR Hall is one of two new state-of-the-art buildings being developed as part of an expanded campus for the University of Washington Michael G. <a>Foster School of Business</a>, designed by LMN Architects of Seattle.
name <p>Many of the sustainable changes at the University of Washington have resulted from campus activism.
name <p>The University of Washington Husky <a>Marching Band</a> performs at many Husky sporting events including all <a>football</a> games.
name The University of Washington's mascot is <a>Harry the Husky</a>.
name The University of Washington has hosted a long line of <a>Alaskan Malamute</a>s as mascots.
name The University of Washington was one of only six universities to receive the highest grade on the Sustainable Endowments Institute's College Sustainability Report Card 2008, an &quot;A-&quot;.&lt;ref

name <p>The <strong>University of Pennsylvania</strong> (commonly referred to as <strong>Penn</strong> or <strong>UPenn</strong>) is a <a>private</a> <a>Ivy League</a> <a>research university</a> located in <a>Philadelphia</a>, <a>Pennsylvania</a>, <a>USA</a>.
name <p>Incorporated as <em>The Trustees of the University of Pennsylvania</em>, Penn is one of 14 founding members of the <a>Association of American Universities</a>.</p>
name <em>History of the University of Pennsylvania 1740&#x2013;1940</em> University of Pennsylvania Press, Philadelphia.
name In 1791 the legislature issued a new charter, merging the two institutions into the <strong>University of Pennsylvania</strong> with twelve men from each institution on the new board of trustees.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name <p>Penn's educational innovations include: the nation's first medical school in 1765; the first university teaching hospital in 1874; the <a>Wharton School</a>, the world's first collegiate school of business, in 1881; the first American student union building, <a>Houston Hall</a>, in 1896;&lt;ref&gt;<em>Building America's First University: An Historical and Architectural Guide to the University of Pennsylvania</em> George E. Thomas, David Bruce Brownlee, p3&lt;/ref&gt; the country's second school of veterinary medicine; and the home of <a>ENIAC</a>, the world's first electronic, large-scale, general-purpose digital computer in 1946.
name The present core campus covers over  in a contiguous area of <a>West Philadelphia</a>'s <a>University City</a> district; the older heart of the campus comprises the <a>University of Pennsylvania Campus Historic District</a>.
name <p>The University of Pennsylvania has four undergraduate schools:<a>250px|right|thumb|Lower Quad in Winter, from Riepe College House</a></p>
name <p>The following schools offer graduate programs:<a>thumb|300px|right|University of Pennsylvania Dental School</a></p>
name Penn has worked to address these issues by pooling its schools (as well as several hospitals and clinical practices) into the University of Pennsylvania Health System, thereby pooling resources for greater efficiencies and research impact.</p>
name <p>The University of Pennsylvania's undergraduate business program at Wharton has retained its #1 ranking in U.S. News for many years.
name According to MINE ParisTech rankings in 2008, University of Pennsylvania is one of the top five universities in the world, just behind <a>Tokyo University</a>, <a>Harvard University</a>, <a>Stanford University</a>, and <a>Keio University</a>.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name Penn's <a>Law School</a> is ranked 7th, and its <a>School of Education</a> and University of Pennsylvania School of Social Policy &amp; Practice (SP2)|School of Social Policy &amp; Practice (SP2) are ranked in the top 10 (see <em>U.S. News</em>).
name <a>The University of Pennsylvania Glee Club</a>, founded in 1862, is one of the oldest continually operating collegiate choruses in the United States.
name   <p>&quot;Such is the devotion to English rugby football on the part of University of Pennsylvania's students from New Zealand, Australia, and England that they meet on Franklin Field at 7 o'clock every morning and practice the game.
name Dan</a> (1985) &quot;Fight On, Pennsylvania&quot; Trustees of University of Pennsylvania pg.
name Dan</a> (1985) &quot;Fight On, Pennsylvania&quot; Trustees of University of Pennsylvania pg. 28, 33&#x2013;34.&lt;/ref&gt;
name <p>The <a>Olympic Boycott Games</a> of 1980 were held at the University of Pennsylvania in response to <a>Moscow</a>'s hosting of the <a>1980 Summer Olympics</a> following the <a>Soviet incursion in Afghanistan</a>.
name <p>Notable University of Pennsylvania alumni include eight signers of the <a>Declaration of Independence</a>: <a>George Clymer</a>, <a>Francis Hopkinson</a>, <a>Thomas McKean</a>, <a>Robert Morris</a>, <a>William Paca</a>, <a>George Ross</a>, <a>Benjamin Rush</a>, and <a>James Wilson</a>; nine signers of the <a>Constitution</a>: <a>George Clymer</a>, <a>Thomas Fitzsimons</a>, <a>Jared Ingersoll</a>, <a>Rufus King</a>, <a>Thomas Mifflin</a>, <a>Gouverneur Morris</a>, Robert Morris, <a>Hugh Williamson</a>, and <a>James Wilson</a>; three <a>United States Supreme Court</a> justices: <a>William J. Brennan, Jr.</a>, <a>Owen Roberts</a>, and James Wilson; and one president of the United States: <a>William Henry Harrison</a>.&lt;ref&gt;William
name Henry Harrison, Ohio History Central Online Encyclopedia [<a>http://www.ohiohistorycentral.org/entry.php?rec=190</a>]: &quot;At his father&#x2019;s insistence, [he] studied medicine from 1790 to 1791 at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia.
name <p><a>ar:&#x062c;&#x0627;&#x0645;&#x0639;&#x0629; &#x0628;&#x0646;&#x0633;&#x0644;&#x0641;&#x0627;&#x0646;&#x064a;&#x0627;</a> <a>az:Pensilvaniya Universiteti</a> <a>bn:&#x09aa;&#x09c7;&#x09a8;&#x09cd;&#x09b8;&#x09bf;&#x09b2;&#x09cd;&#x200c;&#x09ad;&#x09c7;&#x09a8;&#x09bf;&#x09af;&#x09bc;&#x09be; name <p>  {{Infobox university |name = University of Oxford |latin_name = Universitas Oxoniensis |image_name = Oxford University.svg&lt;!--Official
name |image_size = 170px |caption = University of Oxford <a>seal</a> |motto = <em>Dominus Illuminatio Mea</em> (<a>Latin</a>) |mottoeng = The Lord is my Light |established = Unknown, teaching existed since &lt;ref name=&quot;Oxford&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; |endowment = <a>&#x00a3;</a>3.0
name <a>Lord Patten of Barnes</a> |vice_chancellor = <a>Andrew Hamilton</a> |city = <a>Oxford</a> |state = |country = <a>England</a>, <a>UK</a> |students = 20,330&lt;ref name=&quot;OXFACT&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;OXSTATS&quot; /&gt; |undergrad = 11,766&lt;ref name=&quot;OXFACT&quot; /&gt; |postgrad = 8,701&lt;ref name=&quot;OXFACT&quot; /&gt; |other = 461&lt;ref name=&quot;OXSTATS&quot;&gt; &lt;/ref&gt;&lt;!-- Visiting and Recognised students (VRO)--&gt; |colours = Oxford Blue&lt;ref&gt;from &lt;/ref&gt;  |type = <a>Public</a> |affiliations = <a>IARU</a>&lt;br /&gt;<a>Russell Group</a>&lt;br /&gt;<a>Coimbra Group</a>&lt;br /&gt;<a>Europaeum</a>&lt;br /&gt;<a>EUA</a>&lt;br /&gt;<a>G5</a>&lt;br /&gt;<a>LERU</a> |website = <a>www.ox.ac.uk</a> }} The <strong>University of Oxford</strong> (informally <strong>Oxford University</strong>, or simply <strong>Oxford</strong>) is a <a>university</a> located in <a>Oxford</a>, <a>United Kingdom</a>.
name name=&quot;oxhist&quot;&gt;  &lt;/ref&gt; In <a>post-nominals</a> the University of Oxford was historically abbreviated as <strong>Oxon.</strong>
name [[Arms of the University of Oxford|coat of arms]] of the University of Oxford.]]</p>
name <p>The University of Oxford does not have a clear date of foundation.
name From the mid-18th century onward, however, the University of Oxford took little part in political conflicts.
name <p>The list of distinguished scholars at the University of Oxford is long and includes many who have made major contributions to <a>British politics</a>, the sciences, medicine, and literature.
name More than forty Nobel laureates and more than fifty <a>world leaders</a> have been affiliated with the University of Oxford.&lt;ref
name <a>Lady Margaret Hall</a> (1878&lt;ref&gt;<a>&quot;History&quot;,</a> Lady Margaret Hall, University of Oxford&lt;/ref&gt;) was followed by <a>Somerville College</a> in 1879;&lt;ref&gt;<a>&quot;History&quot;,</a> Somerville College, University of Oxford&lt;/ref&gt; the first 21 students from Somerville and LMH attended lectures in rooms above an Oxford baker's shop.&lt;ref
name name=&quot;Lannon&quot;/&gt; The first two colleges for women were followed by <a>St Hugh's</a> (1886&lt;ref&gt;<a>&quot;History of the College&quot;,</a> St Hugh's College, University of Oxford&lt;/ref&gt;), <a>St Hilda's</a> (1893&lt;ref&gt;<a>&quot;Constitutional History&quot;,</a> St Hilda's College, University of Oxford&lt;/ref&gt;) and <a>St Anne's College</a> (1952&lt;ref&gt;<a>&quot;St Anne's History&quot;,</a> St Anne's College, University of Oxford&lt;/ref&gt;). Oxford though was long considered a bastion of male privilege,&lt;ref&gt;Joyce S. Pedersen <a>Book review,</a> H-Albion, May 1996, reprinted on H-Net Review website&lt;/ref&gt; and a quota of female students was instituted by the Universities dons in 1927 fixing the admission of women at about a quarter of the total, a ruling not abolished until 1957.&lt;ref
name - <em>Handbook to the University of Oxford</em>.
name - University of Oxford.
name This was changed in 1925, and the first woman to hold a professorial chair at Uppsala University was <a>Gerd Enequist</a>, appointed professor of human geography in 1949.</p>
name at Oxford&quot;,</a> University of Oxford&lt;/ref&gt; By 1988, 40% of undergraduates at Oxford were female;&lt;ref&gt;Jenifer Hart <a>&quot;Women at Oxford since the Advent of Mixed Colleges&quot;,</a> <em>Oxford Review of Education</em>, 15:3, 1989, p.217&lt;/ref&gt; the ratio is now about 48:52 in men's favour.</p>
name The collection of University Professors is called the Statutory Professors of the University of Oxford.
name College]], one of the constituent colleges of the University of Oxford]] There are 38 <a>colleges of the University of Oxford</a> and 6 <a>Permanent Private Hall</a>s, each with its own internal structure and activities.&lt;ref
name <p><a>Academic dress</a> is still commonly seen at Oxford; until the 1960s students wore it at all times (see <a>Academic dress of the University of Oxford</a>).
name <p>The University also launched a fundraising campaign in May 2008, called <em>Oxford Thinking - The Campaign for the University of Oxford</em>.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name <p>Despite the University's claims that its admissions policies avoid bias against candidates of certain socioeconomic or educational backgrounds,&lt;ref name=&quot;Working with Schools and Colleges&quot;&gt;<a>Working with Schools and Colleges</a>, University of Oxford Gazette, 2006.
name name=&quot;Admissions Statistics 2006&quot;&gt;<a>Admissions Statistics 2006</a>, University of Oxford Gazette, 2007.
name About half of applications come from the state sector,&lt;ref name=&quot;Admissions Statistics 2006&quot;/&gt; and the University of Oxford funds many initiatives to attract applicants from this sector, including the new UNIQ Summer Schools, Oxford Young Ambassadors, Target Schools, and the FE Access Initiative.&lt;ref name=&quot;Working with Schools and Colleges&quot;/&gt; Most colleges also run their own access schemes and initiatives.
name <p>In 2002, the University of Oxford commissioned a research project&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; under the auspices of Professor Anthony Heath.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite
name <p>:<em>See:</em> <a>Departments of the University of Oxford</a></p>
name These include <a>Oxford Brookes University</a>; <a>Ruskin College, Oxford</a> - an <a>adult education</a> college - which, although not part of the University of Oxford, has close links with it; and the former Lady Spencer Churchill teaching college (now the Wheatley campus of <a>Oxford Brookes</a>).</p>
name <p>The University of Oxford is an Educational Alliance Partner of the <a>Meade 4M Community</a> which supports the University's 'Project Jetwatch' program.</p>

name <p>{{Infobox university | name         =University of Bergen | native_name  =Universitetet i Bergen | latin_name   =Universitas Bergensis | image        =<a>225px|Seal of the University of Bergen</a> | motto        = | established  =1946 (1825) | type         =<a>Public University</a> | rector       =<a>Sigmund Gr&#x00f8;nmo</a> | students     =14,500 (2008) | staff        =3,200 (2007) | city         =<a>Bergen</a> | country      =<a>Norway</a> | campus       = | affiliations =<a>EUA</a>;<a>WUN</a>&lt;br /&gt; <a>Coimbra Group</a>, <a>Utrecht Network</a> | website      =<a>www.uib.no</a>
name <p>The <strong>University of Bergen</strong> ()  is located in <a>Bergen</a>, <a>Norway</a>.
name <p>[[Image:Faculty of Law in Bergen.JPG|thumb|The Faculty of Law at the University of Bergen, seen from [[Magnus VI of Norway|Magnus Lagab&#x00f8;te]]s plass.]]</p>
name <p>The University of Bergen is the only institution in the Nordic countries where the study of <a>psychology</a> has been assigned to its own faculty.
name <p> <a>Category:University of Bergen</a> <a>University of Bergen</a> <a>Category:Coimbra Group</a> <a>Category:Educational institutions established in 1946</a> <a>Category:Public universities</a></p>
name <p>{{Infobox university |name          = Uppsala University |native_name   = Uppsala universitet |latin_name    = Universitas Regia Upsaliensis<em>, also </em>Academia Regia Upsaliensis |image_name    = Uppsala University logo.svg
name <p>[[Image:Entrance hall of Uppsala University main building.jpg|thumb|right|The
name <p><strong>Uppsala University</strong> () is a research <a>university</a> in <a>Uppsala</a> and is the oldest university in <a>Scandinavia</a>, founded in 1477.&lt;ref&gt;Ridder-Symoens,
name Sten, <em>A history of Uppsala University 1477-1977</em> (Almqvist &amp; Wiksell 1976)]&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>Architecturally, Uppsala University has traditionally had a strong presence in the area around <a>the cathedral</a> on the western side of the <a>River Fyris</a>.
name <p>As with most medieval universities, Uppsala University initially grew out of an ecclesiastical center.
name The first woman in Sweden to complete a doctoral degree was <a>Ellen Fries</a> (1855&#x2013;1900), who entered Uppsala university in 1877 and became a Ph.D. in history in 1883.
name <h3>Uppsala University Hospital</h3>
name <p> <a>thumb|The old main building of the Uppsala University Hospital, photograph from <em>c.</em> 1920</a> The Uppsala Academic Hospital or <em>Akademiska sjukhuset</em>, which functions as a teaching hospital for the Faculty of Medicine and the Nursing School, is run by the <a>Uppsala County Council</a> in cooperation with the university.
name <p><a>thumb|The University Hall during a light exhibition, fall 2008</a> <a>thumb|Uppsala University Botanical Garden</a> <a>thumb|Main building at Campus Pollax</a> Buildings and locations where the university has activities or which are significantly connected to its history.

name   <li><a>Uppsala University Hospital</a></li>
name nation]]]] Students at Uppsala University are obliged to become members of one of the <a>nation</a>s, corporations of students traditionally according to province of origin (not strictly upheld now, for practical reasons).
name <p>Nations at Uppsala University: {| style=&quot;background-color: transparent; width: {}&quot; | width=&quot;{}&quot; align=&quot;{}&quot; valign=&quot;{}&quot; |</p>
name Affiliated with the University are three choirs, the mixed <a>Uppsala University Choir</a> (<em>Allm&#x00e4;nna S&#x00e5;ngen</em>), founded in 1830, the male choir <a>Orphei Dr&#x00e4;ngar</a>, founded in 1853, and the <a>Academy Chamber Choir of Uppsala</a>, founded in 1957.
name In honour of Ericson, the <a>F&#x00f6;reningsSparbanken</a> endowed the Eric Ericson Chair in Choral Directing, and the Uppsala University Choral Centre was inaugurated in 2000.
name <p>Uppsala University has signed student exchange agreements with about 500 universities across all parts of the world.&lt;ref&gt;<a>Uppsala
name University international office (Swedish)</a>&lt;/ref&gt; It takes part in the <a>Erasmus programme</a> programme and the Nordplus programme.Uppsala University has signed university-wide student exchange programmes with the following universities (selection)&lt;ref&gt;<a>Uppsala University International Office, 2009</a>&lt;/ref&gt;:</p>
name <p>Uppsala University is a member of the <a>Coimbra Group</a> of universities.</p>
name <p>Uppsala University places well in many rankings.&lt;ref&gt;<a>QS
name <p>Uppsala University is associated with 8 <a>Nobel Prize</a> laureates,&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; and numerous royalty, academics and public figures.</p>
name <p>As the dominant academic institution in Sweden for several centuries, Uppsala University has ever since its first period of expansion in the early part of the 17th century educated a large proportion of Swedish politicians and civil servants, from 17th century Chancellor of the Realm (<em>rikskansler</em>) <a>Johan Oxenstierna</a> (1611&#x2013;1657) and Lord Chief Justice (<em>riksdrots</em>) <a>Magnus Gabriel De la Gardie</a> (1622&#x2013;1686) to the first Social Democratic <a>Prime Minister of Sweden</a>, <a>Hjalmar Branting</a> (1860&#x2013;1925) and many later politicians.
name <a>Niklas Zennstr&#x00f6;m</a>, co-founder of <a>KaZaA</a> and <a>Skype</a> is also a former student at Uppsala University.
name On August 15, 2008 Zennstr&#x00f6;m donated 15 million <a>SEK</a> to Uppsala University for climate research.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <h2>Uppsala University in fiction and popular culture</h2>
name Specifically, Uppsala University has appeared notably in <em>M&#x00e4;n som hatar kvinnor</em> or <em>The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo</em> by Steig Larsson.</p>
name <p>The Norwegian pop singer <a>Kirsti Sparboe</a> dedicated one of her biggest successes to Uppsala University, publishing in 1969 the song &quot;Ein Student aus Uppsala&quot;.&lt;ref&gt;<a>Youtube, &quot;Ein Student aus Uppsala&quot;, by [[Kirsti Sparboe]]</a>&lt;/ref&gt; The song, originally written in German, lasted 14 weeks in the German charts.

name <p>{{Infobox university |image_name=University of Rochester logo.svg
name |image_size=220px |name=University of Rochester |motto=<em><a>Meliora</a></em> (<a>Latin</a>) |mottoeng=Always Better (also, Ever Better) |established=1850 |type=<a>Private</a>, secular |calendar=  Semester |president=<a>Joel Seligman</a> |city = <a>Rochester</a> |state=<a>New York</a> |country=<a>U.S.</a> |undergrad=4,606 |postgrad=4,357 |staff=1,225 |free_label      = Annual Fees |free            = $52,690 (2009&ndash;2010) |campus=<a>Suburb</a>an/<a>Urban</a>,&lt;ref&gt;The <a>Eastman School</a> campus is in downtown Rochester (urban), while the majority of the university is located in a more suburban environment.&lt;/ref&gt;
name <p>The <strong>University of Rochester</strong> (<strong>U of R</strong>, <strong>UR</strong>, or URoc) is a <a>private</a>, nonsectarian, research university located in <a>Rochester, New York</a>.
name The University of Rochester, along with its affiliated Strong Health System, is the largest employer in the Greater Rochester area and the sixth largest employer in New York.&lt;ref&gt;<a>State.NY.us</a>,
name <p>The University of Rochester was founded in 1850 as a Baptist-sponsored institution.
name <p>The university uses Dandelion Yellow and a shade of blue (Rochester blue) as its official colors, which are the prominent colors on the official regalia.&lt;ref&gt;<a>University of Rochester Colors</a>&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name The impetus to form the university came primarily from the town of <a>Hamilton, New York</a>, which has been home to <a>Colgate University</a> since 1819.&lt;ref&gt;<a>History of the University of Rochester</a>&lt;/ref&gt; In 1848, the Baptist Education Society planned to move Colgate University (then known as Madison University) to the city of Rochester, but was halted by legal action.
name Dissenting Colgate trustees, faculty, and students founded the University of Rochester, receiving a charter from the <a>Regents of the University of the State of New York</a> on January 31, 1850.
name Arthur J. (1977) <em>A History of the University of Rochester</em>, Princeton: <a>Princeton University</a>&lt;/ref&gt; <a>thumb|Inside of the Great Hall of Rush Rhees.</a>
name The University of Rochester's campus was originally in downtown Rochester at the United States Hotel, which was located on Buffalo Street near Elizabeth Street, which today is West Main Street near the <a>I-490</a> overpass.
name name=&quot;May, Arthur J. 1977&quot;&gt;May, Arthur J. (1977) <em>A History of the university of Rochester</em>, Princeton: Princeton University&lt;/ref&gt; UR would remain on this campus until the current River Campus was constructed in 1930, and the university continues to own a small part of the University Avenue campus (where the university-owned Memorial Art Gallery is located).
name In 1958, three new schools were created in <a>engineering</a>, <a>business administration</a>, and <a>education</a>.&lt;ref&gt;<a>University of Rochester:</a> History and Distinctions&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name The university is headed by a board of trustees, with Edmund A. Hajim being the chairman.&lt;ref&gt;<a>University of Rochester News Release:</a> University Names New Trustees and New Chairman&lt;/ref&gt; The board appoints the president of the university, currently <a>Joel Seligman</a>, who replaced <a>Thomas H. Jackson</a> on July 1, 2005.</p>

name   <li><strong>University of Rochester Medical Center</strong></li>
name <p> <a>thumb|The School of Medicine and Dentistry at the University of Rochester's Medical Center.</a>
name The <strong>University of Rochester Medical Center (URMC)</strong> is the primary campus for the university's medical education and research as well as the main patient care facility.
name <p>University of Rochester's <a>undergraduate</a> enrollment consists of about 4,500 full-time and about 100 part-time students from across the U.S. and over 90 countries.&lt;ref&gt;<a>Diversity
name <p>The University of Rochester is known for its several unique 5th year programs.
name <p>U.S. News and World Report, in their popular National University Rankings, placed the University of Rochester 35th in the nation for 2008, 2009, and 2010.&lt;ref&gt;<a>USNews.com:
name Bot generated title --&gt;</a>&lt;/ref&gt; In 2007, the London Times rated the University of Rochester 48th among the best universities in the world and 21st among American educational institutions.
name The University of Rochester also placed 21st on The Washington Monthly College Rankings list.
name University of Rochester places within the top 10 for the staff-to-student ratio.&lt;ref&gt;<a>Times
name <p><strong>Internationally</strong>, in 2010 <a>QS World University Rankings</a>&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; ranked the University of Rochester joint 127th alongside <a>Case Western Reserve University</a>, making it joint 41st in the United States.</p>
name <p>Rush Rhees Library at The University of Rochester was featured on the cover of the &quot;Princeton Review 373 Best Colleges 2011 Edition&quot;.
name <p>For more information on University of Rochester's history and distinctions, please go to: <a>http://www.rochester.edu/aboutus/history.html</a></p>
name UR consistently ranks among the top 40 colleges and universities nationwide in federally financed <a>science</a>, <a>engineering</a>, <a>medical</a>, and other research, with a total research budget of around $350 million spread across many departments and research centers, including the <a>Laboratory for Laser Energetics</a>, a laser-based <a>nuclear fusion</a> facility, and the extensive research facilities at the <a>University of Rochester Medical Center</a>.
name WeBWorK, a web-based system for checking homework and providing immediate feedback for students, was developed by University of Rochester professors Gage and Pizer.
name <p>Academics at the University of Rochester are generally organized and administered by school.
name Flaum Atrium between the School of Medicine and Dentistry and the [[Arthur Kornberg]] buildings in the <a>University of Rochester Medical Center</a>.]]</p>
name The school is located in the <a>University of Rochester Medical Center</a>.</p>
name <p>:The university also includes an accredited <strong>School of Nursing</strong>, located on the campus of the <a>University of Rochester Medical Center</a>.</p>
name UR's official symbol is the seal of the university, which features a book, representing <a>arts and sciences</a>, a lyre symbolizing music, and a modified <a>symbol of medicine</a>.&lt;ref&gt;<a>University of Rochester Seal</a>&lt;/ref&gt; The official flower of the university is the <a>dandelion</a>, purportedly prolific on the cow pasture that became the university's first campus.&lt;ref&gt;<a>University of Rochester: Dandelion</a>&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name However, when the university re-designed the mascot during the 2007-2008 academic year, a new name was chosen and as of February 1, 2008, the school's mascot is now known as &quot;Rocky&quot;.&lt;ref&gt;<a>University of Rochester Mascot: The Yellowjackets</a>&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;<a>New University of Rochester Yellowjacket to debut Feb. 1</a>&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>The image of <a>Rush Rhees Library</a>'s main dome serves as an additional icon for the University of Rochester.</p>
name Although less frequently used, the university also has an official <a>Alma Mater</a>, <em>The Dandelion Yellow</em>.&lt;ref&gt;<a>Songs of the University of Rochester</a>&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name Past speakers include <a>Anderson Cooper</a>, <a>Stephen Colbert</a>, <a>Colin Powell</a>, and <a>United States Secretary of Energy</a> and University of Rochester alumnus <a>Steven Chu</a>.</li>
name <p>The student body at the University of Rochester is both ethnically and socioeconomically diverse.
name The campus also hosts a volunteer EMT squad (The University of Rochester MERT) which provides free New York State certified Basic Life Support services to the River Campus community.
name The University of Rochester is also home to its own radio station, <a>WRUR</a>.</p>
name Housing is provided at multiple locations spread across the several campuses.&lt;ref&gt;<a>University of Rochester Residential Life</a>&lt;/ref&gt;</p>

name <p>{{Infobox university | name        = University of California | image       = <a>220px</a> | motto       = <em>Fiat lux</em> (<a>Latin</a>) | mottoeng    = <a>Let there be light</a> | established = 1868 | type        = <a>Public</a> <a>university system</a> | endowment   = $4.9 billion [<a>http://www.nacubo.org/Documents/research/2009_NCSE_Public_Tables_Endowment_Market_Values.pdf</a>]
name <p>The <strong>University of California</strong> (<strong>UC</strong>) is a <a>public university</a> <a>system</a> in the <a>state</a> of <a>California</a>.
name Under the <a>California Master Plan for Higher Education</a>, the University of California is a part of the state's three-tier public <a>higher education</a> system, which also includes the <a>California State University</a> system and the <a>California Community Colleges</a> system.</p>
name <p>The University of California has a combined <a>student</a> body of more than 191,000 students and over 1,340,000 living <a>alumni</a>.</p>
name In addition, the independently administered <a>UC Hastings</a>&lt;ref&gt;Hastings has a unique relationship with the University of California.
name In 1878, when Justice Serranus Clinton Hastings gave $100,000 to the University of California to start the law school bearing his name, he imposed two conditions: (1) the school must remain in San Francisco near the courts and (2) it could not be governed by the <a>Regents of the University of California</a>.
name See: <a>University of California, Hastings College of the Law#History</a>.
name <p>The University of California's campuses boast large numbers of distinguished <a>faculty</a> in almost every field and is widely regarded as one of the top public university systems in the world.
name <p>[[File:Berkeley glade afternoon.jpg|thumb|[[University of California, Berkeley|Berkeley]] (1868)]] [[File:UC Davis Mondavi Center.jpg|thumb|[[University of California, Davis|Davis]] (1908)]] [[File:RHall.JPG|thumb|[[University of California, Los Angeles|Los Angeles]] (1919)]] [[File:Ucsbuniversitycenterandstorketower.jpg|thumb|[[University of California, Santa Barbara|Santa Barbara]] (1944)]] [[File:Ucr-belltower.jpg|thumb|[[University of California, Riverside|Riverside]] (1954)]] [[File:Geisel library.jpg|thumb|[[University of California, San Diego|San Diego]] (1960)]] [[File:Uc irvine8300001.jpg|thumb|[[University of California, Irvine|Irvine]] (1965)]] [[File:Cowell College.jpg|thumb|[[University of California, Santa Cruz|Santa Cruz]] (1965)]] [[File:Ucmercedscienceandengineeringbuilding.jpg|thumb|[[University of California, Merced|Merced]] (2005)]] [[File:Mission Bay, UCSF.jpg|thumb|[[University of California, San Francisco|San Francisco]] (1873)]] [[File:Universityofcaliforniaofficeofthepresident.jpg|thumb|right|UC
name <p>Governor <a>Frederick Low</a> favored the establishment of a state university based upon the <a>University of Michigan</a> plan, and thus in one sense may be regarded as the founder of the University of California.
name Accordingly, the Organic Act, establishing the University of California, was signed into law by Governor <a>Henry H. Haight</a> (Low's successor) on March 23, 1868.&lt;ref&gt;Harvey
name Helfand, <em>University of California, Berkeley: An Architectural Tour and Photographs,</em> (New York: Princeton Architectural Press, 2002), 6.&lt;/ref&gt;   </p>
name <p>The University of California's second president, <a>Daniel Coit Gilman</a>, opened the <a>Berkeley</a> campus in September 1873.
name In 1944, the former Santa Barbara State College&#x2014;renamed <a>UC Santa Barbara</a>--became the third general-education campus of the University of California system.</p>
name <p>In 1932, <a>Will Keith Kellogg</a> donated his Arabian horse ranch in <a>Pomona, California</a> to the University of California system.
name [[University of California, Davis, Arboretum|Davis Arboretum]] walkway and garden on The Waterway.]]
name UC researchers create 3 new inventions per day.&lt;ref&gt;University of California, Office of the President, Press Release, September 28, 2005.[<a>http://www.universityofcalifornia.edu/news/2005/sep28.html</a>]&lt;/ref&gt;  </p>
name <p>The University of California and most of its campuses are members of the <a>Association of American Universities (AAU)</a>.
name <p> At 34 million items,&lt;ref&gt;<a>University of California Cultural Resources Libraries</a>.
name Accessed January 26, 2008.&lt;/ref&gt; the University of California <a>library</a> system contains one of the largest collections in the world.
name <p>The University of California is governed by the <a>Regents of the University of California</a>, as required by the current <a>Constitution of the State of California</a>.
name Today, the UC Office of the President and the Office of the Secretary of the Regents of the University of California share an office building in downtown Oakland which serves as the UC system's <a>headquarters</a>.</p>

name <p>The First District Court of Appeal in San Francisco recently ruled that the University of California owes nearly US$40 million dollars in refunds to about 40,000 students who were promised that their tuition fees would be held steady but were hit with increases when the state ran short of money in 2003.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>

name <p>The University of California has a long tradition of involvement in many enterprises that are often geographically or organizationally separate from its general campuses, including national laboratories, observatories, hospitals, continuing education programs, hotels, conference centers, an airport, and an art institute.</p>
name The University of California directly manages and operates one <a>United States Department of Energy National Laboratory</a>:</p>
name They also have much deeper ties to the university than the Los Alamos Lab, a fact seen in their respective original names; the University of California Berkeley Radiation Laboratory and the University of California Radiation Laboratory at Livermore.</p>
name <p>The University of California's ties to the labs have so far outlasted all periods of internal controversy.
name <p>On June 1, 2006, the University of California ended its direct involvement in operating Los Alamos National Laboratory, and management control of the laboratory was taken over by <a>Los Alamos National Security, LLC</a>.
name <p>On October 1, 2007, the University of California ended its direct involvement in operating the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory.
name Management control of the laboratory was taken over by Lawrence Livermore National Security, LLC, a limited liability company whose members are Bechtel National, the University of California, Babcock and Wilcox, the Washington Division of URS Corporation, Battelle Memorial Institute, and The Texas A&amp;M University System.</p>
name <p>The University of California is a founding and charter member of <a>CENIC</a>, the Corporation for Education Network Initiatives in California, the nonprofit organization which provides extremely high-performance Internet-based networking to California's K-20 research and education community.</p>
name <p>The University of California also works with the <a>NASA Ames Research Center</a> at <a>Moffett Federal Airfield</a> in California.
name <a>UC Santa Cruz</a> manages the UARC for the University of California, with the goal of increasing the science output, safety, and effectiveness of <a>NASA</a>'s missions through new technologies and scientific techniques.
name Since 2002, the <a>NSF</a>-funded <a>San Diego Supercomputer Center</a> at <a>UC San Diego</a> has been managed by the University of California, taking over for the previous manager, <a>General Atomics</a>.</p>
name <p>The University of California manages two <a>observatories</a> as a multi-campus research unit headquartered at <a>UC Santa Cruz</a>.</p>

name <p>{{Infobox university |name            = University of California, Berkeley |motto           =  |mottoeng        = <a>Let There be Light</a> |image_name      = University of California Seal.svg |image_size      = 200px |caption         = <a>Seal</a> of the University of California, Berkeley |established     = March 23, 1868 |type            = <a>Public</a> |calendar        = Semester |endowment       = <a>USD $</a>2.34

name <p>The <strong>University of California, Berkeley</strong> (also referred to as <strong>Cal</strong>, <strong>California</strong>, <strong>Berkeley</strong> and <strong>UC Berkeley</strong>) is a <a>public research university</a> located in <a>Berkeley, California</a>, <a>United States</a>, in the San Francisco Bay Area.
name Today <em>University of California</em> refers to a statewide school system and the official name is <em>University of California, Berkeley</em>, frequently shortened to <em>UC Berkeley</em>, <em>Berkeley</em>, <em>Cal.</em>
name {{cite web|url=<a>http://www.haas.berkeley.edu/groups/pubs/calbusiness/current/alumni05.html</a>|title=Obituaries - Business Visionary Don Fisher, BS 51|date=2009 (Fall)|publisher=University of California, Berkeley's Haas School of Business}}&lt;/ref&gt;  <a>MySpace</a>,&lt;ref name=&quot;MySpaceByAnderson&quot;&gt;<a>MySpace</a> was co-founded by <a>Tom Anderson</a>(BA 1998).
name Litwack's last stand|date=2007-05-08|author=Cathy Cockrell|publisher=UC Berkeley NewsCenter (University of California, Berkeley)}}&lt;/ref&gt; <a>three other</a> UC Berkeley professors have also received the Pulitzer Prize.
name   <li><a>A Brief History of the University of California, Berkeley</a></li>
name Students of Environmental Horticulture and other botanical sciences have many acres of campus farmland and the <a>University of California, Davis, Arboretum</a> at their disposal.
name The Zona Zoo program is co-owned by the Associated Students of the University of Arizona (ASUA) and Arizona Athletics, the program is run by a team of spirited individuals called the Zona Zoo Crew.
name <p>There are currently (2005) 44 <a>fraternity and sorority</a> chapters that are recognized by the University of Arizona.

name <p><a>ar:&#x062c;&#x0627;&#x0645;&#x0639;&#x0629; &#x0643;&#x0627;&#x0644;&#x064a;&#x0641;&#x0648;&#x0631;&#x0646;&#x064a;&#x0627;&#x060c; &#x0628;&#x0631;&#x0643;&#x0644;&#x064a;</a> <a>bg:&#x041a;&#x0430;&#x043b;&#x0438;&#x0444;&#x043e;&#x0440;&#x043d;&#x0438;&#x0439;&#x0441;&#x043a;&#x0438; name <p> {{Infobox University |name =University of California, Santa Cruz |motto = <em>Fiat lux</em> (<a>Latin</a>) |mottoeng = <a>Let there be light</a> |tagline =&#x2022; Thinking at the Edge&lt;br /&gt;&#x2022; Fiat Slug (unofficial) |image_name =Ucsc fiatslug.png
name |logo =<a>245px</a> }} The <strong>University of California, Santa Cruz</strong>, also known as <strong>UC Santa Cruz</strong> or <strong>UCSC</strong>, is a <a>public</a>, <a>collegiate</a> <a>university</a>; one of ten campuses in the <a>University of California</a>.
name &lt;ref&gt; {{cite web |title=University of California, Santa Cruz (Statistics) |work=The Princeton Review |url=<a>http://www.princetonreview.com/college/research/profiles/academics.asp?listing=1023551&amp;ltid=1&amp;intbucketid=</a> |accessdate=2006-06-29 }} (Note: Registration required) &lt;/ref&gt; Interdisciplinary programs, such as Feminist Studies, American Studies, Environmental Studies, Digital Arts and New Media, and the unique <a>History of Consciousness</a> Department are also hosted alongside UCSC's more traditional academic departments.</p>

name <p><a>bn:&#x0987;&#x0989;&#x09a8;&#x09bf;&#x09ad;&#x09be;&#x09b0;&#x09cd;&#x09b8;&#x09bf;&#x099f;&#x09bf; &#x0985;&#x09ab; &#x0995;&#x09cd;&#x09af;&#x09be;&#x09b2;&#x09bf;&#x09ab;&#x09cb;&#x09b0;&#x09cd;&#x09a8;&#x09bf;&#x09af;&#x09bc;&#x09be;, &#x09b8;&#x09be;&#x09a8;&#x09cd;&#x099f;&#x09be; &#x0995;&#x09cd;&#x09b0;&#x09c1;&#x099c;</a> <a>bg:&#x041a;&#x0430;&#x043b;&#x0438;&#x0444;&#x043e;&#x0440;&#x043d;&#x0438;&#x0439;&#x0441;&#x043a;&#x0438; &#x0443;&#x043d;&#x0438;&#x0432;&#x0435;&#x0440;&#x0441;&#x0438;&#x0442;&#x0435;&#x0442;, &#x0421;&#x0430;&#x043d;&#x0442;&#x0430; &#x041a;&#x0440;&#x0443;&#x0437;</a> <a>cs:University of California, Santa Cruz</a> <a>de:University of California, Santa Cruz</a> <a>es:Universidad de California en Santa Cruz</a> <a>eo:Universitato de Kalifornio en Santa Cruz</a> <a>fa:&#x062f;&#x0627;&#x0646;&#x0634;&#x06af;&#x0627;&#x0647; &#x06a9;&#x0627;&#x0644;&#x06cc;&#x0641;&#x0631;&#x0646;&#x06cc;&#x0627;&#x060c; &#x0633;&#x0627;&#x0646;&#x062a;&#x0627; &#x06a9;&#x0631;&#x0648;&#x0632;</a> <a>fr:Universit&#x00e9; de Californie &#x00e0; Santa Cruz</a> <a>is:Kaliforn&#x00ed;uh&#x00e1;sk&#x00f3;li &#x00ed; Santa Cruz</a> <a>ja:&#x30ab;&#x30ea;&#x30d5;&#x30a9;&#x30eb;&#x30cb;&#x30a2;&#x5927;&#x5b66;&#x30b5;&#x30f3;&#x30bf;&#x30af;&#x30eb;&#x30fc;&#x30ba;&#x6821;</a></p>
name <p>{{Infobox university | name         = University of California, Davis | motto        = Fiat lux (<a>Latin</a>) | mottoeng     = <a>Let there be light</a> | image_name   = UniversityofCalifornia,Davis.JPG | image_size   = 200px | established  = 1905 as the University Farm (of UC Berkeley)&lt;br /&gt;1959  established as a general UC campus | type         = <a>Public</a>, <a>Land-grant</a>, <a>Space-grant</a> | calendar     = Quarter | endowment    = US$540 <a>million</a> (June 30, 2009) &lt;ref&gt;<a>UC Annual Endowment Report</a> <em>Office of the Treasurer of The Regents'.' Retrieved March 31, 2010.&lt;/ref&gt;</em>
name <p>The <strong>University of California, Davis, (UC Davis)</strong> is a <a>public</a> research university located in <a>Davis, California</a>, and one of ten campuses in the <a>University of California</a> system.
name <p>The University of California, Davis campus is the largest campus in the UC system, spanning over  across two counties: <a>Yolo</a> and <a>Solano</a>.
name <p><a>thumb|left|University of California, Davis Fire Department|UC Davis fire engine</a> Towards the northeast end of campus is the Quad, a large rectangular field which sits adjacent to Freeborn Hall and the Memorial Union, which houses various establishments such as the UC Davis Bookstore, ASUCD Coffee House, food courts, Post Office, Sky Room, and the MU Games Area.
name <p> <a>Category:University of California, Davis</a> <a>Davis</a> <a>Category:Davis, California</a> <a>California Davis, University of</a> <a>California Davis, University of</a> <a>Category:Association of Public and Land-Grant Universities</a> <a>California Davis, University of</a> <a>California Davis, University of</a> <a>Category:Agricultural universities and colleges</a> <a>Category:Schools accredited by the Western Association of Schools and Colleges</a> <a>Category:Central Valley of California</a> <a>Category:Universities and colleges in Yolo County, California</a></p>
name <p><a>bg:&#x041a;&#x0430;&#x043b;&#x0438;&#x0444;&#x043e;&#x0440;&#x043d;&#x0438;&#x0439;&#x0441;&#x043a;&#x0438; &#x0443;&#x043d;&#x0438;&#x0432;&#x0435;&#x0440;&#x0441;&#x0438;&#x0442;&#x0435;&#x0442;, &#x0414;&#x0435;&#x0439;&#x0432;&#x0438;&#x0441;</a> <a>de:University of California, Davis</a> <a>es:Universidad de California en Davis</a> <a>fa:&#x062f;&#x0627;&#x0646;&#x0634;&#x06af;&#x0627;&#x0647; &#xb300;&#xd559;&#xad50; &#xb370;&#xc774;&#xbe44;&#xc2a4;</a> <a>is:Kaliforn&#x00ed;uh&#x00e1;sk&#x00f3;li &#x00ed; Davis</a> <a>it:Universit&#x00e0; della California, Davis</a> <a>he:&#x05d0;&#x05d5;&#x05e0;&#x05d9;&#x05d1;&#x05e8;&#x05e1;&#x05d9;&#x05d8;&#x05ea; &#x05e7;&#x05dc;&#x05d9;&#x05e4;&#x05d5;&#x05e8;&#x05e0;&#x05d9;&#x05d4; &#x05d1;&#x05d3;&#x05d9;&#x05d9;&#x05d5;&#x05d5;&#x05d9;&#x05e1;</a> <a>la:Universitas Californiensis (Davis)</a> <a>ja:&#x30ab;&#x30ea;&#x30d5;&#x30a9;&#x30eb;&#x30cb;&#x30a2;&#x5927;&#x5b66;&#x30c7;&#x30fc;&#x30d3;&#x30b9;&#x6821;</a> <a>no:University of California, Davis</a> <a>pnb:&#x06cc;&#x0648;&#x0646;&#x06cc;&#x0648;&#x0631;&#x0633;&#x0679;&#x06cc; &#x0622;&#x0641; &#x06a9;&#x06cc;&#x0644;&#x06cc;&#x0648;&#x0641;&#x0648;&#x0631;&#x0646;&#x06cc;&#x0627; &#x0688;&#x06cc;&#x0648;&#x0633;</a> <a>ru:&#x041a;&#x0430;&#x043b;&#x0438;&#x0444;&#x043e;&#x0440;&#x043d;&#x0438;&#x0439;&#x0441;&#x043a;&#x0438;&#x0439; name <p>{{Infobox university | name            = The University of Sydney | motto           = <em>Sidere mens eadem mutato</em> (<a>Latin</a>) | mottoeng        = <a>Literal</a>: &quot;Though the constellations change, the mind is universal&quot; &lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;<a>Meaning</a>: The traditions of the older universities of the Northern Hemisphere are continued here in the Southern | latin_name        = Universitas Sidneiensis | established     = 1850 | type            = <a>Public</a> | endowment       = AU$937m&lt;br /&gt;&lt;small&gt;(31 December 2009)&lt;/small&gt;&lt;ref&gt;<a>INVESTMENT AND CAPITAL MANAGEMENT REPORT&quot;</a>&lt;/ref&gt; | chancellor      = <a>Her Excellency Professor Marie Bashir AC, CVO</a>&lt;ref&gt;<a>Faculty alumna elected University Chancellor</a>, Retrieved on 2007-06-02.&lt;/ref&gt;
name <p><strong>The University of Sydney</strong> (informally <strong>Sydney University</strong> or <strong>USyd</strong>) is a university located in <a>Sydney</a>, <a>Australia</a>.
name <p>The University of Sydney is a member of Australia's <a>Group of Eight</a>, Academic Consortium 21, the <a>Association of Pacific Rim Universities</a> (APRU) and the <a>Worldwide Universities Network</a>.</p>
name <p>The university was established via the passage of the University of Sydney Act,&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; which was signed on 1 October 1850.
name On 27 February 1858 the university received its <a>Royal Charter</a> from <a>Queen Victoria</a>, giving degrees conferred by the university rank and recognition equal to those given by universities in the UK.&lt;ref name=&quot;royal_charter&quot;&gt;<a>Royal Charter of the University of Sydney</a>&lt;/ref&gt;  By 1859, the university had moved to its current site in the Sydney suburb of <a>Camperdown</a>.</p>
name <p>The New England University College was founded as part of the University of Sydney in 1938, and separated to become the University of New England in 1954.</p>
name <p>During the late 1960s, the University of Sydney was at the centre of rows to introduce courses on <a>Marxism</a> and <a>feminism</a> at the major Australian universities.
name <p><a>thumb|250px|Front lawns</a> The <a>Orange Agricultural College</a> (OAC) was originally transferred to the <a>University of New England</a> under the Act, but then transferred to the University of Sydney in 1994, as part of the reforms to the University of New England undertaken by the University of New England Act 1993&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; and the Southern Cross University Act 1993.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name In January 2005, the University of Sydney transferred the OAC to <a>Charles Sturt University</a>.</p>
name <p>In 2010, the <a>Times Higher Education World University Rankings</a> placed the University of Sydney 184st in the world and 3rd in Australia behind the <a>University of Melbourne</a> (36th) and the Macquarie University (43rd).&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p><a>QS World University Rankings</a> 2010 placed the University of Sydney 48th in the world and 2nd in Australia ahead of the University of Melbourne (38th).&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name The University of Sydney currently has financial endowments totaling $829 million.
name <p>Latest figures show that the University of Sydney has received the highest amount of research grants, which may demonstrate its research competitiveness and the size of its students and staff body.&lt;ref
name name=&quot;usyd_facts&quot;/&gt; The University of Sydney also has the second largest (behind <a>Monash University</a>) body of students and researchers among Australian universities.</p>
name <p>The University of Sydney secured more than $46 million in funding in the 2007 round of National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) Project Grant, Capacity Building and Fellowship awards, the largest allocation to any university in the state.
