name <p>The <strong>University of Arizona</strong> (also referred to as <strong>UA</strong>, <strong>U of A</strong>, or <strong>Arizona</strong>) is a <a>land-grant</a> and <a>space-grant</a> <a>public</a> institution of <a>higher education</a> and <a>research</a> located in <a>Tucson, Arizona</a>, United States.
name The University of Arizona was the first <a>university</a> in the state of <a>Arizona</a>, founded in 1885 (twenty-seven years before the Arizona Territory achieved statehood).
name The university includes the <a>University of Arizona College of Medicine</a> which is one of three medical schools and the only <a>MD</a> granting medical school in Arizona.
name name=&quot;Fact Book&quot;/&gt; The University of Arizona is governed by the <a>Arizona Board of Regents</a>.
name The mission of the University of Arizona is, &quot;To discover, educate, serve, and inspire.&quot;&lt;ref
name <p><a>right|thumb|200px|Old Main, the oldest building on the University of Arizona campus</a> The University of Arizona was approved by the Arizona Territory's &quot;<a>Thieving Thirteenth</a>&quot; Legislature in 1885.
name <a>thumb|left|University of Arizona Mall</a> <a>thumb|right|Wildcat Family Statue</a></p>
name <p>The University of Arizona offers 334 fields of study leading to bachelor's, master's, doctoral, and professional degrees.
name The University of Arizona is the only remaining <a>Pac-10</a> conference school to not award plus and minus grades for courses.
name <p>The <a>James E. Rogers College of Law</a> was ranked 42nd nationally by U.S. News &amp; World Report in for 2011.&lt;ref&gt;<a>University of Arizona (Rogers) - Law -Best Graduate Schools - Education - US News and World Report&lt;!-- Bot generated title --&gt;</a>&lt;/ref&gt; The Systems and <a>Industrial Engineering</a> (SIE) Department is ranked 10th in the 'America's Best Graduate Schools 2009' by US News and World Report.
name name=&quot;Highlights and rankings 22&quot;/&gt; The <a>Doctor of Pharmacy</a> program at the <a>University of Arizona College of Pharmacy</a> is ranked 4th nationally by U.S. News &amp; World Report in 2005.&lt;ref
name Internationally, the 2010 <a>Times Higher Education World University Rankings</a>&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; ranked University of Arizona 95th in the world and the 2010 <a>QS World University Rankings</a>&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; ranked this university 160th.
name <p>The libraries at University of Arizona are expecting a 15 percent budget cut for the 2009 fiscal year.
name <p><a>The University of Arizona Poetry Center</a> is among the nation&#x2019;s finest and most extensive collections of contemporary poetry.
name <p>The University of Arizona generates renewable energy with solar panels that have been installed on campus buildings.
name <p>The University of Arizona, like its sister institutions <a>Arizona State University</a> and <a>Northern Arizona University</a>, is governed by the <a>Arizona Board of Regents</a> or the ABOR, a 12-member body.
name name=&quot;Swedlund&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; Notable past UA presidents include Likins, Manuel Pacheco (the first person of <a>Hispanic</a> descent to lead the university and for whom the <a>Integrated Learning Center</a> is named), <a>Homer L. Shantz</a>, Henry Koffler, John Schaefer, and Richard Harvill.&lt;ref&gt;<a>&quot;Past Presidents of The University of Arizona&quot;, from UA Office of the President website.
name <p> &lt;!-- Image with inadequate rationale removed: <a>thumb|right|200px|University of Arizona &quot;A&quot; Logo</a> --&gt; Like many large public universities in the U.S., sports are a major activity on campus, and receive a large operating budget.
name name=&quot;History 8&quot;&gt; &lt;/ref&gt;  The University of Arizona participates in the <a>NCAA</a>'s Division I-A in the <a>Pacific-10 Conference</a>, which it joined in 1978.</p>
name <p> <a>thumb|Arizona Stadium</a> The <a>football</a> team began at The University of Arizona in 1899 under the nickname &quot;Varsity&quot; (a name kept until the 1914 season when the team was deemed the &quot;Wildcats&quot;).&lt;ref
name Although surprising to some, the University of Arizona has a noteworthy history in <a>ice hockey</a>.
name <p>A strong athletic rivalry exists between the University of Arizona and <a>Arizona State University</a> located in <a>Tempe</a>.
name <p> <strong>The Official Student Section and Student Ticketing Program for University of Arizona Athletics</strong></p>
name <p>Officially implemented in 2003, Zona Zoo is the official student section and student ticketing program for the University of Arizona Athletics.
name The University of Arizona is home to more than 500 philanthropic, multi-cultural, social, athletic, academic, and student clubs and campus organizations.
name Through funding from the CSIL and the Associated Students of the University of Arizona, clubs are given the resources and encouragement to explore unusual interests.</p>
name <p>In 2008 University of Arizona students started <a>their own branch</a> (reinstated as of April 21, 2010&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;) of the <a>Arizona Students for Life (ASFL)</a> <a>pro-life</a> association, whose goal is to help pregnant college women and raise awareness about <a>elective abortion</a>, of which college women are half all those affected.</p>
name <p>The University of Arizona is also home to one of the oldest <a>Model United Nations</a> organizations in the United States, which each year hosts several hundred students high school students in a bilingual simulation of the <a>United Nations</a> and other international bodies.</p>
name <p>The campus comedy group, <a>Comedy Corner</a> is a sketch and improv comedy group at the University of Arizona.
name <p>The University of Arizona <a>marching band</a>, named <a>The Pride of Arizona</a>, played at the halftime of the first <a>Super Bowl</a>.
name --&gt; Overall, students at the University of Arizona have been represented by the Associated Students of the University of Arizona (ASUA) since 1913.
name Each of the 10 Senators and all Administrative Officers also are appointed to serve on the various University of Arizona Faculty and Administrative Committees.</p>
name Much like ASUA, the GPSC appoints representatives to serve on various University of Arizona Faculty and Administrative Committees and 1 Director to serve on the Arizona Students' Association.</p>
name <p>The University of Arizona Residence Hall Association has hosted 3 regional IACURH Residence Hall Conferences, which were hosted in 1961, 1997, and 2004.
name In 2005, the University of Arizona's Residence Hall Association was voted by <a>NACURH</a> (National Association of College and University Residence Halls) as the National School of the Year out of over 400 schools across the United States.
name In May 2009, the University of Arizona hosted the NACURH National Residence Hall Conference (also hosted in 1963), bringing more than 2,200 on-campus residents from over 250 schools across the United States and Canada for 3 days of school spirit and learning how to become more sustainable and socially just.
name The film <em><a>Revenge of the Nerds</a></em> (1984) was filmed at the University of Arizona.
name The film <em><a>Eating Out</a></em> was shot around the University of Arizona campus in Tucson.
name <p>The University has also been the setting for portions of <a>David Foster Wallace</a>'s novel <em><a>Infinite Jest</a></em> takes place at the University of Arizona campus, including a scene in the administration building satirizing the school's <a>bureaucracy</a>.

name <p>The University of Tulsa was founded in <a>Muskogee, Oklahoma</a>, as the Presbyterian School for Indian Girls in 1882 under the leadership of <a>Alice Mary Robertson</a>, but was re-chartered as the <strong>Henry Kendall College</strong> in 1894 under the auspices of the Presbyterian Women's Board of Home Missions.
name A university was formed in 1920 when the college merged with the proposed <a>McFarlin College</a> to become the University of Tulsa.</p>
name <p>The University of Tulsa is noted for having one of the world's premier programs in <a>petroleum engineering</a>, and has distinguished programs in <a>English</a>, <a>computer science</a>, <a>natural sciences</a>, <a>Clinical and Industrial/Organizational Psychology</a>, and several <a>engineering</a> disciplines.
name The University of Tulsa College of Law Review ranks in the top 15% of most cited legal periodicals as ranked by <a>Washington and Lee University</a>.[<a>http://law.wlu.edu/library/mostcited/index.asp</a>]

name In the 2006 edition, the university was described as follows: &#x201c;The University of Tulsa is one of the sleeper gems of the <a>Great Plains</a>, a private school large enough to house numerous top-flight programs but small enough to facilitate one-on-one instruction provided in a homey atmosphere.&#x201d;</p>

name <p> {{Infobox university |name              = Upper Iowa University |image = <a>220px|The Arch marks the west entrance to the Fayette campus, a gift from the graduating Class of 1909.</a>
name }} Established in 1857, <strong>Upper Iowa University</strong> (UIU) is a <a>private</a> <a>institution of higher education</a> with its residential <a>campus</a> located in northeast <a>Iowa</a> near the <a>Volga River of Iowa</a> in the rural community of <a>Fayette, Iowa</a>, where around 900 students are enrolled.
name <p>Upper Iowa University is fully accredited by the <a>Higher Learning Commission</a> of the <a>North Central Association of Colleges and Schools</a>.</p>
name The Pioneering spirit: <em>Upper Iowa University celebrating 150 Years 1857-2007</em>.
name <p>Upper Iowa University participates in the <a>North Central Association</a> (NCA) Academic Quality Improvement Program (AQIP), has a UIU chapter of the <a>Alpha Chi National College Honor Society</a>, and 165 student athletes were honored in 2010 for academic excellence.&lt;ref&gt;<a>http://www.upperiowaathletics.com/</a>&lt;/ref&gt;  Average ACT is 22; average high school grade point average is 2.94; tuition for 2009-2010 is $22,350, with 100 percent of UIU students receiving need- and/or merit-based financial aid.&lt;ref&gt;<a>http://www.petersons.com/collegeprofiles/Profile.aspx?inunid=9488&amp;reprjid=12&amp;sponsor=1&amp;tabid=10002</a>&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p><a>thumb|right|200px|Upper Iowa University's <em>Team Peacock</em> has raised $350,000 to date riding RAGBRAI for student scholarships</a> UIU is recognized for being a military-friendly college by these publications--Military Advanced Education (MAE) magazine&#x2019;s &#x201c;3rd Annual Guide to Military-Friendly Colleges and Universities&#x201d; and the 2010 list for top-military friendly schools published by G.I. Jobs online magazine.&lt;ref&gt;Military
name <p>Upper Iowa University awards more than $100,000 each year in merit-based scholarships to its current students.&lt;ref&gt;<a>2009
name <p>Upper Iowa University has three international education centers located in the Pacific Rim. UIU offers undergraduate programs in business, communication and psychology to learners in Hong Kong, Malaysia and Singapore.

name <p>The <strong>University of Utah</strong>, also known as <strong>the U</strong> or <strong>the U of U</strong>, is a <a>public</a>, <a>coeducational</a> <a>research university</a> in <a>Salt Lake City</a>, <a>Utah</a>, United States.
name In 1892, the school's name was changed to the University of Utah, and <a>John R. Park</a> began arranging to obtain land belonging to the U.S. Army's <a>Fort Douglas</a> on the east bench of the <a>Salt Lake Valley</a>, where the university moved permanently in 1900.
name health sciences complex and [[Utah Transit Authority|UTA]] <a>TRAX</a>]]The health sciences complex, at the northeast end of campus, includes the <a>University of Utah Medical Center</a>, <a>Primary Children's Medical Center</a>,&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; the <a>Huntsman Cancer Institute</a>, the <a>Moran Eye Center</a>, and the Spencer Eccles Health Sciences Library.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name   <li><a>California State University Emeritus and Retired Faculty Association</a></li>

name <p>The University of Utah has the only accredited <a>architecture</a> program in Utah,&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; as well as the only <a>medical school</a>.&lt;ref

name The University of Utah was one of the original four nodes of <a>ARPANET</a>, the world's first <a>packet-switching</a> computer network and embryo of the current worldwide <a>Internet</a>.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;

name The University of Utah has a <a>dry campus</a>, meaning that alcohol is banned on campus.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name The University of Utah tried to uphold its gun ban but the <a>Utah Supreme Court</a> rejected the ban in 2006.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>The <a>University of Utah Press</a>, the oldest press in Utah and now part of the <a>J.
name <p><a>Utah, University of</a> <a>Category:Association of Public and Land-Grant Universities</a> <a>Category:University of Utah</a> <a>Utah, University of</a> <a>Utah, University of</a> <a>Category:Economy of Salt Lake City, Utah</a> <a>Category:Education in Salt Lake City, Utah</a> <a>Category:Universities and colleges accredited by the Northwest Commission on Colleges and Universities</a></p>
name <p><a>de:University of Utah</a> <a>es:Universidad de Utah</a> <a>eo:Universitato de Utaho</a> <a>fa:&#x062f;&#x0627;&#x0646;&#x0634;&#x06af;&#x0627;&#x0647; &#x06cc;&#x0648;&#x062a;&#x0627;</a> <a>fr:Universit&#x00e9; d'Utah</a> <a>gl:Universidade de Utah</a> <a>ko:&#xc720;&#xd0c0; &#xb300;&#xd559;&#xad50;</a> <a>hi:&#x092f;&#x0942;&#x091f;&#x093e; &#x0935;&#x093f;&#x0936;&#x094d;&#x0935;&#x0935;&#x093f;&#x0926;&#x094d;&#x092f;&#x093e;&#x0932;&#x092f;</a> <a>ja:&#x30e6;&#x30bf;&#x5927;&#x5b66;</a> <a>no:University of Utah</a> <a>pnb:&#x06cc;&#x0648;&#x0646;&#x06cc;&#x0648;&#x0631;&#x0633;&#x0679;&#x06cc; &#x0622;&#x0641; &#x06cc;&#x0648;&#x0679;&#x0627;&#x06c1;</a> <a>pt:Universidade de Utah</a> <a>ru:&#x0423;&#x043d;&#x0438;&#x0432;&#x0435;&#x0440;&#x0441;&#x0438;&#x0442;&#x0435;&#x0442; &#x042e;&#x0442;&#x044b;</a> <a>simple:University of Utah</a> <a>fi:Utahin yliopisto</a> <a>sv:University of Utah</a> <a>ta:&#x0baf;&#x0bc2;&#x0b9f;&#x0bcd;&#x0b9f;&#x0bbe; &#x0baa;&#x0bb2;&#x0bcd;&#x0b95;&#x0bb2;&#x0bc8;&#x0b95;&#x0bcd;&#x0b95;&#x0bb4;&#x0b95;&#x0bae;&#x0bcd;</a> <a>zh:&#x72b9;&#x4ed6;&#x5927;&#x5b66;</a></p>
name <p>{{Infobox university |name              = University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology (UMIST) |native_name       =  |image_name        = umist-logo.png

name <p> {{Infobox university |image_name=University_of_Chicago_Modern_Etched_Seal 1.svg |image_size=256px |image_alt=The seal of the University of Chicago.
name |name=University of Chicago |motto=<em>Crescat scientia; vita excolatur</em> (<a>Latin</a>) |mottoeng=Let knowledge grow from more to more; and so be human life enriched&lt;ref name=&quot;Motto Translation&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; |established=1890 |type=<a>Private</a> nondenominational coeducational |calendar= Quarter |president=<a>Robert Zimmer</a> |city=<a>Chicago</a> |state=<a>Illinois</a> |campus=<a>Urban</a>, 211&nbsp;acres (85&nbsp;ha)&lt;ref name=&quot;ffj&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; |undergrad=5,134&lt;ref name=&quot;tcf&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; |postgrad=10,304&lt;ref name=&quot;tcf&quot; /&gt; |faculty=2,168&lt;ref name=&quot;ffj&quot; /&gt; |staff=14,772 (including employees of the <a>University of Chicago Medical Center</a>)&lt;ref name=&quot;ffj&quot; /&gt; |athletics = <a>NCAA</a> <a>Division III</a> <a>UAA</a> |nickname=<a>Maroons</a> |mascot=<a>Phoenix</a>&lt;ref name=&quot;traditions&quot;/&gt; |affiliations = <a>Association of American Universities</a> <a>Committee on Institutional Cooperation</a> |endowment=<a>US $</a>5.578
name &lt;/ref&gt; |nobel_laureates = 84&lt;ref&gt;<a>University of Chicago Nobel Laureates</a>, University of Chicago Nobel Laureates&lt;/ref&gt; |website=<a>www.uchicago.edu</a>
name |colors=Maroon  White &lt;ref name=&quot;traditions&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; |logo= <a>260px|The University of Chicago Logo</a> |mascot=Phoenix |}} The <strong>University of Chicago</strong> (<strong>U of C</strong>, <strong>UC</strong>, or simply <strong>UChicago</strong>) is a <a>private</a>, <a>research university</a> in <a>Chicago</a>, <a>Illinois</a>, <a>USA</a>.
name name=&quot;ucsmp&quot;&gt;{{cite web | title=The University of Chicago School Mathematics Project (UCSMP) | publisher=The University of Chicago | url=<a>http://socialsciences.uchicago.edu/ucsmp/</a>
name It has a reputation of devotion to academic scholarship and <a>intellectualism</a>&lt;ref name=&quot;columbia&quot;&gt;{{cite web | title=The University of Chicago | publisher=The Fathom Archive (Columbia University) | url=<a>http://www.fathom.com/partners/uchic/index.html</a> | accessdate=July 30, 2006}} &quot;The University of Chicago was founded in 1892, and within a short time became internationally recognized as one of the world's great centers of scholarship, research, and teaching.&quot;&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref
name <p>The University consists of the <a>College of the University of Chicago</a>, various graduate programs and interdisciplinary committees organized into four divisions, six <a>professional school</a>s, and a school of <a>continuing education</a>.
name name=&quot;nsf&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; University of Chicago scholars have played a role in the development of the <a>Chicago School of economics</a>, the <a>Chicago School of sociology</a>, the <a>law and economics</a> movement in legal analysis,&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; and the physics leading to <a>the world's first man-made, self-sustaining</a> <a>nuclear reaction</a>.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name px|An early [[convocation]] ceremony at the University of Chicago]]</p>
name <p>The University of Chicago was created and <a>incorporated</a> as a <a>coeducational</a>,&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; secular institution in 1890 by the <a>American Baptist Education Society</a> and a donation from oil magnate and philanthropist <a>John D. Rockefeller</a>.
name name=&quot;hutchins&quot; /&gt; In 1933, Hutchins proposed an unsuccessful plan to merge the University of Chicago and <a>Northwestern University</a> into a single university.&lt;ref
name name=&quot;merger&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; During his term, the University of Chicago Hospitals (now called the <a>University of Chicago Medical Center</a>) finished construction and enrolled its first medical students,&lt;ref name=&quot;hospitalhistory&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; and the <a>Committee on Social Thought</a> was created.</p>
name <p>[[File:ChicagoPileTeam.png|left|thumb|350px|The University of Chicago team that worked on the production of the world's first man-made, self-sustaining nuclear reaction, including [[Enrico Fermi]] in the front row|alt=A group of people in suits standing in three rows on the steps in front of a stone building.]]
name <p>In 1978, <a>Hanna Holborn Gray</a>, then the provost and acting president of <a>Yale University</a>, became President of the University of Chicago, in which capacity she served for 15 years.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name In 2008, the University of Chicago announced plans to establish the <a>Milton Friedman Institute</a>.
name Current construction projects include: the Jules and Gwen Knapp Center for Biomedical Discovery, a ten-story medical research center, as well as further additions to the medical campus of the <a>University of Chicago Medical Center</a>.&lt;ref
name older buildings of the University of Chicago employ [[Collegiate Gothic]] architecture like that of the <a>University of Oxford</a>.
name <p>The main campus of the University of Chicago consists of  in the Chicago neighborhoods of <a>Hyde Park</a> and <a>Woodlawn</a>, seven miles (11&nbsp;km) south of <a>downtown Chicago</a>.
name <p>The first buildings of the University of Chicago campus, which make up what is now known as the Main Quadrangles, were part of a &quot;master plan&quot; conceived by two University of Chicago trustees and plotted by Chicago architect <a>Henry Ives Cobb</a>.&lt;ref
name <p>The University of Chicago also maintains facilities apart from its main campus.
name The University of Chicago also opened a new center in Beijing in fall 2010.</p>
name <p>The University of Chicago is governed by a board of trustees.
name <p>The academic bodies of the University of Chicago consist of the <a>College</a>, four divisions of graduate research, six professional schools, and the Graham School of General Studies (a <a>continuing education</a> school).
name The University also contains a library system, the <a>University of Chicago Press</a>, the <a>University of Chicago Laboratory Schools</a>, and the <a>University of Chicago Medical Center</a>, and holds ties with a number of independent academic institutions, including <a>Fermilab</a> and <a>Argonne National Laboratory</a>.
name Regulations and Procedures|accessdate=August 13, 2009|format=PDF|publisher=The University of Chicago|quote=Students register for three or four courses per quarter.
name <p> The College of the University of Chicago grants <a>Bachelor of Arts</a> and <a>Bachelor of Science</a> degrees in 49 <a>academic major</a>s and 22 minors.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name <p><a>thumb|left|200px|The University of Chicago Lab Schools, a private day school run by the University</a> The University runs a number of academic institutions and programs apart from its undergraduate and postgraduate schools.
name It operates the <a>University of Chicago Laboratory Schools</a> (a private <a>day school</a> for K-12 students and <a>day care</a>),&lt;ref name=&quot;lab&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; the <a>Sonia Shankman Orthogenic School</a> (a residential treatment program for those with behavioral and emotional problems),&lt;ref&gt; &lt;/ref&gt; and four public <a>charter school</a>s on the <a>South Side</a> of Chicago administered by the university's Urban Education Institute.&lt;ref
name name=&quot;charter&quot;&gt; &lt;/ref&gt; In addition,  the Hyde Park Day School, a school for students with learning disabilities, maintains a location on the University of Chicago campus.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite
name With two Illinois locations on the University of Chicago campus in Chicago and north suburban Northfield, HPDS is the only school of its kind in the Chicago area.|accessdate=September
name 9, 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt; Since 1983, the University of Chicago has maintained the <a>University of Chicago School Mathematics Project</a>, a mathematics program used in urban primary and secondary schools.&lt;ref
name name=CAS&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; The University also operates the <a>University of Chicago Press</a>, the largest <a>university press</a> in the United States.&lt;ref
name <p>The <a>University of Chicago Library</a> system encompasses six libraries&lt;ref name=&quot;libabout&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; that contain a total of 8.5&nbsp;million volumes, the 12th most among library systems in the United States.&lt;ref
name <p>[[Image:Fermilab.jpg|thumb|left|225px|Aerial view of [[Fermilab]], one of the science research laboratories partially operated by the University of Chicago]]</p>
name <p>In fiscal year 2006, the University of Chicago spent US$305,301,000 on scientific research.&lt;ref
name <p>The University of Chicago has been the site of some important experiments and academic movements.
name <p> There have been 85&nbsp;Nobel Laureates affiliated with the University of Chicago,&lt;ref name=&quot;uchicago1&quot;/&gt; 17 of whom were pursuing research or on faculty at the University at the time of the award announcement.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>In the 2009 Spring Quarter, the University of Chicago enrolled 4,920 students in the College, 3,633 students in its four graduate divisions, 5,088 students in its professional schools, and 14,000 students overall.&lt;ref&gt;
name <p>In 2004, the University of Chicago claimed 133,155 living alumni.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>The University of Chicago hosts 19 varsity sports teams: 10 men's teams and 9 women's teams,&lt;ref name=&quot;sportsfacts&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; all called the <a>Maroons</a>, with 585 students participating in the 2008&#x2013;2009 school year.&lt;ref
name --&gt; Students at the University of Chicago run over 400 clubs and organizations known as Recognized Student Organizations (RSOs).&lt;ref
name name=&quot;rsodatabase&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; Among notable RSOs are the renowned improvisational comedy troupe <a>Off-Off Campus</a>, organizing committee for the <a>University of Chicago Scavenger Hunt</a>, the twice-weekly student newspaper <em><a>The Chicago Maroon</a></em>, and the University-owned radio station <a>WHPK-FM</a>.</p>
name <p>There are fourteen <a>fraternities</a> and six <a>sororities</a> at the University of Chicago,&lt;ref name=&quot;Greek&quot; /&gt; as well as one co-ed community service fraternity, <a>Alpha Phi Omega</a>.&lt;ref&gt;
name &lt;/ref&gt; Three of the sororities are members of the <a>National Panhellenic Conference</a>,&lt;ref name=&quot;frats&quot; /&gt; and ten of the fraternities form the University of Chicago Interfraternity Council.&lt;ref
name <p> On-campus undergraduate students at the University of Chicago participate in a <a>house system</a> in which each student is assigned to one of the university's 10 <a>residence hall</a> buildings and to a smaller community within their residence hall called a &quot;house&quot;.
name <p>[[Image:Scavrace1.jpg|thumb|180px|right|Qwazy Quad Rally, [[University of Chicago Scavenger Hunt|Scav Hunt]] 2005, item #38]]</p>
name --&gt; {{Main|Doc Films|Summer Breeze (concert)|University of Chicago Scavenger Hunt}}</p>
name <p>Every May since 1987, the University of Chicago has held the <a>University of Chicago Scavenger Hunt</a>, in which large teams of students compete to obtain notoriously esoteric items from a list.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name   <li><a>Scientific Research Activity at University of Chicago</a></li>

name {{Infobox University  |name           = University of Canterbury |native_name    = Te Whare W&#x0101;nanga o Waitaha |image_name     = Canterbury uni arms.jpg
name <p>The <strong>University of Canterbury</strong> (; postnominal abbreviation <strong><em><a>Cantuar</a>.</em></strong> or <strong><em>Cant.</em></strong>
name <p><a>thumb|left|The James Hight building at the University of Canterbury</a></p>
name Outside the Central Library, University of Canterbury, New Zealand</a> --&gt;</p>
name <p>In 2010 <a>QS World University Rankings</a>&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; ranked the University of Canterbury 189th overall in the world, making it the third highest ranked university in New Zealand.
name <p>The <a>University of Canterbury Students' Association</a> (UCSA)&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; operates on campus with its own radio station (<a>RDU</a>) and magazine (<a><em>Canta</em></a>).
name The most prominent of these include the <a>University of Canterbury Engineering Society (ENSOC)</a>, the Law Society (LAWSOC), the Commerce Society (UCom), as well as the largest non-faculty clubs such as BYCSOC (Backyard Cricket Society), CUBA (<a>Canterbury University Boardriders' Association</a>), CurrySoc, <a>The Gentlemen's Club</a>, and <a>KAOS</a> (Killing As Organised Sport).
name The <a>University of Canterbury Drama Society</a> (Dramasoc) achieved fame for its 1942-1969 Shakespeare productions under Dame <a>Ngaio Marsh</a>, but regularly performs as an active student- and alumni-run arts fixture in the small Christchurch theatre-scene.
name <p>[[File:Arts Center Christchurch.JPG|thumb|right|Former University of Canterbury campus in the city centre, today the [[Christchurch Arts Centre]]]]</p>
name In 1957 the name changed again to the present <em>University of Canterbury</em>.</p>
name That year saw the dissolution of the federal system of tertiary education in New Zealand, and the University of Canterbury became an independent University awarding its own degrees.
name Upon the UNZ's demise, <a>Canterbury Agricultural College</a> became a constituent college of the University of Canterbury, as <em>Lincoln College</em>.&lt;ref&gt;[<a>http://www.lincoln.ac.nz/story_images/952_LincolnUniversity_s3422.pdf</a> &lt;/ref&gt; Lincoln College became independent in 1990 as a full university in its own right.</p>
name <p>With the dissolution of the University of New Zealand, the newly independent University of Canterbury devised its own coat of arms, <a>blazoned</a>: :<em>&quot;murrey a fleece argent, in base a plough or, and on a chief wavy or an open book proper bound murrey, edged and clasped or between a pall azure charged with four crosses formy fitchy or and a cross flory azure.&quot;</em>
name   <li><strong><a>University of Canterbury</a></strong></li>
name <p> <a>Category:University of Canterbury</a> <a>Canterbury</a> <a>Category:Film schools in New Zealand</a> <a>Category:Educational institutions established in 1873</a> <a>Category:Association of Commonwealth Universities</a></p>
name <p>{{Infobox University  |name           = Victoria University |image          = <a>130px</a> |latin_name     =  |motto          = <em>Abeunt studia in mores</em>  |mottoeng       = Studies pass into character |established    = October 12, 1836 |affiliation    =  |type           = <a>Federated college</a> of the <a>University of Toronto</a> (1890&#x2013;) |endowment      = C$114 million&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; |chancellor     = Wendy Cecil |president      = Paul W. Gooch |principal      = David Cook |undergrad      = 3,351 |former_names   = Upper Canada Academy (1836&#x2013;1841); Victoria College (1841&#x2013;1884)  |city           = <a>Toronto</a>  |province       = <a>Ontario</a>  |country        = <a>Canada</a>  |campus         = <a>Urban</a> |website        = <a>vicu.utoronto.ca</a>
name }} <strong>Victoria University</strong> is a <a>federated school</a> of the <a>University of Toronto</a>, consisting of Victoria College and <a>Emmanuel College</a>.
name Victoria University is somewhat separated from the rest of the university geographically, bordering <a>Queen's Park</a>, and being located on the eastern portion of the campus along with <a>St.
name <p>Victoria University was formed in 1884 when Victoria College and <a>Albert University</a> federated with each other.
name In 1890, Victoria University federated with the University of Toronto.
name In 1892, Victoria University moved from Cobourg to its current campus on Queen's Park Crescent, south of <a>Bloor Street</a> (at Charles Street West), in Toronto.
name <p>Built in 1961 and located at the south end of the quadrangle, the <strong>E.J. Pratt Library</strong> the main library of Victoria University, with some 250,000 volumes.
name <p><a>thumb|left|Northrop Frye Hall</a> Victoria University is governed bicamerally by the Victoria University Board of Regents and the Victoria University Senate.
name Victoria's governing charter was most recently amended in 1981, with the enactment of the Victoria University Act.&lt;ref&gt;
name Victoria University Act www.vicu.utoronto.ca/about/senate/bylaws.htm&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name Recently, the administration of Victoria University has been actively promoting international experiences as a part of the undergraduate student experience.[<a>http://www.vicu.utoronto.ca/Assets/Alumni/vicreports/Winter+07/President$!27s+Page.pdf?method=1</a>]</p>
name <p>Centre for Reformation and Renaissance Studies (CRRS) is a research and teaching centre in Victoria University devoted to the study of the period from approximately 1350 to 1700.
name Victoria College has both clubs and levy receivers, which are overseen by the Victoria University Students' Administrative Council (VUSAC)[<a>http://www.vusac.ca/</a>].
name Over the past few years the theatre has been used as a lecture hall for University of Toronto students, an active learning space for Victoria University students groups, numerous concerts, theatrical productions, film screenings, and conferences.</p>
name <p><a>thumb|Stephenson House</a>  <a>Stephenson House</a> is a community involvement residence at Victoria University, hosting ten undergraduate students per year.
name   <li><a>Norman Jewison</a> &#x2013; Current Chancellor of Victoria University and Filmmaker</li>
name   <li><a>Kenneth D. Taylor</a> - Former Chancellor of Victoria University and Former Canadian Ambassador to Iran</li>
name   <li>Neil Semple 'Faithful Intellect: Samuel S. Nelles And Victoria University' (Montreal: McGill-Queen's University Press, September 1, 2004)</li>
name B. Sissons 'A History of Victoria University'.
name   <li><a>Victoria University</a></li>
name <p>{{about|an Australian university|other universities with 'Victoria' in their name|Victoria University (disambiguation)}}</p>
name <p>{{Infobox University | name            =  Victoria University | image_name      =  Logo_vu.gif
name | established     =  1916 | type            =  <a>Public</a> | endowment       =   | chancellor      =  George Pappas | vice_chancellor =  Professor Elizabeth Harman | city            =  Melbourne | state           =  | country         =  Australia | undergrad       =  23,999 (2008) &lt;ref name=&quot;AnnualReport08&quot;&gt;<a>Victoria University Annual Report 2008</a>&lt;/ref&gt; | postgrad        =  4,568 (2008) &lt;ref name=&quot;AnnualReport08&quot; /&gt; | other           =  28,587 TAFE (2008) &lt;ref name=&quot;AnnualReport08&quot; /&gt; | staff           =  2,854 (2008) &lt;ref name=&quot;AnnualReport08&quot; /&gt; | campus          =  Urban | affiliations    =  <a>ASAIHL</a> | website         =  <a>www.vu.edu.au</a>
name <p><strong>Victoria University</strong> (VU) is a multi-sector tertiary institution (higher education and <a>TAFE</a>) based in Melbourne, Australia with 10 campuses.</p>
name <p>Victoria University's Faculty o&#x2202; Business and Law is one of the largest and prestigious business schools in Australia, with over 10,000 students studying at campuses spread across the city's west, as well as two city campuses.
name <p>All graduates of Victoria University and its forerunner institutions are alumni of VU.
name <p>Victoria University emphasises research and research training that is of relevance to the community,industry and government &#x2013; both nationally and internationally, but particularly in the western region of Melbourne.
name <a>Victoria University has five research centres</a> four institutes and two research groups.</p>
name <p>Victoria University campuses are located across Melbourne's western suburbs and the city centre.
name <p>Victoria University courses are also delivered by a number of affiliates in Asia.
name &lt;ref&gt;<a>Victoria University Performance 2006</a>&lt;/ref&gt;  Two of the largest affiliates are <a>Sunway University College</a> in <a>Malaysia</a> and <a>Liaoning University</a> in China.</p>
name <p><a>|thumb|left|200px|Victoria University City Campus in Queens Street</a> The City Queen Campus occupies two heritage buildings in the heart of Melbourne's legal precinct.
name 295 Queen Street houses the University's School of Law, the Law Library, The Sir Zelman Cowen Centre for Continuing Legal Education, and Victoria University's Judicial Administration and Justice Studies Institute.
name <p>Victoria University (VU) was founded in 1916 as Footscray Technical School.
name After successive mergers with TAFE colleges in Melbourne&#x2019;s western suburbs, Victoria University of Technology was established by legislation of the Victorian Parliament in 1990.
name It was renamed Victoria University in 2005.</p>
name   <li><a>Victoria University</a></li>
name   <li><a>Friends of Victoria University</a></li>
name <p><a>de:Victoria University</a> <a>it:Universit&#x00e0; di Victoria</a> <a>ja:&#x30d3;&#x30af;&#x30c8;&#x30ea;&#x30a2;&#x5927;&#x5b66; (&#x30aa;&#x30fc;&#x30b9;&#x30c8;&#x30e9;&#x30ea;&#x30a2;)</a> <a>pt:Victoria University</a> <a>ta:&#x0bb5;&#x0bbf;&#x0b95;&#x0bcd;&#x0b9f;&#x0bcb;&#x0bb0;&#x0bbf;&#x0baf;&#x0bbe; &#x0baa;&#x0bb2;&#x0bcd;&#x0b95;&#x0bb2;&#x0bc8;&#x0b95;&#x0bcd;&#x0b95;&#x0bb4;&#x0b95;&#x0bae;&#x0bcd;</a> <a>zh:&#x7dad;&#x591a;&#x5229;&#x4e9e;&#x5927;&#x5b78; (&#x6fb3;&#x5927;&#x5229;&#x4e9e;)</a></p>
name <p>{{About|the New Zealand university|other universities with &quot;Victoria&quot; in their name|Victoria University (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox university |name           = Victoria University of Wellington |native_name    = Te Whare W&#x0101;nanga o Te &#x016a;poko o te Ika a M&#x0101;ui |image_name     = Vuw-logo.jpg

name The original name was <a>Victoria University College</a>, but on the dissolution of the <a>University of New Zealand</a> in 1961 Victoria or &quot;Vic&quot; became the independent Victoria University of Wellington, conferring its own degrees.</p>
name <p>The Victoria University of Wellington Library &lt;ref&gt;<a>the Victoria University of Wellington Library</a>&lt;/ref&gt; was established in 1899.
name <p>Victoria University of Wellington has more than 40 research centres and institutes, including</p>

name <p>{{Infobox university |name=Wabash College |image= |motto=Wabash Always Fights |type=<a>private</a> all-male |endowment=$272.2
name }} <strong>Wabash College</strong> is a small, private, <a>liberal arts college</a> for <a>men</a>, located in <a>Crawfordsville, Indiana</a>.
name <p>Wabash College was founded in 1832 by a number of men including several <a>Dartmouth College</a> graduates.
name <p>Joseph F. Tuttle, after whom Tuttle Grade School in Crawfordsville was named in 1906, (and Tuttle Middle School in 1960), became President of Wabash College in 1862 and served for 30&nbsp;years.
name <p>According to <a>Forbes magazine's</a> 2010 ranking for academic institutions, <em>America's Best Colleges</em>, Wabash College ranked 42nd.[<a>http://www.forbes.com/lists/2010/94/best-colleges-10_Americas-Best-Colleges_Rank_2.html</a>]
name [<a>http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/liberal-arts-rankings/page+3</a>] Wabash College is also listed in <a>Loren Pope</a>'s <em><a>Colleges That Change Lives</a></em>.</p>
name <p>The <a>student government</a>, referred to collectively as the Student Body of Wabash College, comprises <a>executive</a> and <a>legislative</a> branches.
name <p>The Student Senate of Wabash College is the legislative authority, consisting of <a>senators</a> from each residence hall and fraternity, four <a>representatives</a> from each of the three underclasses, and the chairmen of the Senate's standing committees.
name <p>The Senior Council of Wabash College is a special quasi-legislative body comprising the presidents of certain student organizations and self-selected at-large councilmen.
name Power to interpret the Constitution of the Student Body of Wabash College is vested in the legislature; questions of interpretation are generally delegated to the Constitution, Bylaw, and Policy Review Committee.</p>
name Every year since 1911, Wabash College has played rival <a>DePauw University</a> in a football game called the <a>Monon Bell</a> Classic.
name Wabash College is a member of the <a>North Coast Athletic Conference</a>.
name The rallying cheer of Wabash College athletics is &quot;Wabash always fights.&quot;
name Wabash College competes in Men's Intercollegiate Baseball, Basketball, Tennis, Cross Country, Track and Field, Golf, Football, Soccer, Swimming &amp; Diving and Wrestling.</p>
name <p>:<em>See also: <a>Monon Bell Classic</a></em> Voted &quot;Indiana's Best College Sports Rivalry&quot; by viewers of <a>ESPN</a> in 2005, DePauw University and Wabash College play each November &#x2014; in the last regular season football game of the year for both teams &#x2014; for the right to keep or reclaim the Monon Bell.
name <p>Wabash College has, despite its small size, been referred to in several cultural contexts:</p>
name See the reference link---&gt; play <em>The College Widow</em> on a fictionalized version of the Wabash College campus.
name I think if he works really hard, he can get an academic scholarship to Wabash College and can get out of this place.&quot;</li>
name As you look, you can see the torch which they handed down to us.&quot; &lt;br/&gt;&#x2014; Byron K. Trippet '30, Ninth President of Wabash College</li>
name &lt;br/&gt;&#x2014; Byron K. Trippet '30, Ninth President of Wabash College</li>
name   <li>Gronert, Theodore G., <em>Sugar Creek Saga: A History and Development of Montgomery County</em>, Wabash College, 1958.</li>

di Yale</a> <a>he:&#x05d0;&#x05d5;&#x05e0;&#x05d9;&#x05d1;&#x05e8;&#x05e1;&#x05d9;&#x05d8;&#x05ea; &#x05d9;&#x05d9;&#x05dc;</a> <a>ka:&#x10d8;&#x10d4;&#x10da;&#x10d8;&#x10e1; &#x10e3;&#x10dc;&#x10d8;&#x10d5;&#x10d4;&#x10e0;&#x10e1;&#x10d8;&#x10e2;&#x10d4;&#x10e2;&#x10d8;</a> <a>sw:Chuo Kikuu cha Yale</a> <a>la:Universitas Yalensis</a> <a>lt:Jeilio universitetas</a> <a>my:&#x101a;&#x1031;&#x1038;&#x101c;&#x103a;&#x1010;&#x1000;&#x1039;&#x1000;&#x101e;&#x102d;&#x102f;&#x101c;&#x103a;</a> <a>nl:Yale-universiteit</a> <a>ja:&#x30a4;&#x30a7;&#x30fc;&#x30eb;&#x5927;&#x5b66;</a> <a>no:Yale University</a> <a>nn:Yale University</a> <a>pnb:&#x06cc;&#x06cc;&#x0644; &#x06cc;&#x0648;&#x0646;&#x06cc;&#x0648;&#x0631;&#x0633;&#x0679;&#x06cc;</a> <a>pl:Yale University</a> <a>pt:Universidade Yale</a> <a>ro:Universitatea Yale</a> <a>qu:Yale Yachay Suntur</a> <a>ru:&#x0419;&#x0435;&#x043b;&#x044c;&#x0441;&#x043a;&#x0438;&#x0439; &#x0443;&#x043d;&#x0438;&#x0432;&#x0435;&#x0440;&#x0441;&#x0438;&#x0442;&#x0435;&#x0442;</a> <a>simple:Yale University</a> <a>sk:Yalova univerzita</a> <a>sl:Univerza Yale</a> <a>sr:Jejl</a> <a>fi:Yalen yliopisto</a> <a>sv:Yale University</a> <a>ta:&#x0baf;&#x0bc7;&#x0bb2;&#x0bcd; &#x0443;&#x043d;&#x0456;&#x0432;&#x0435;&#x0440;&#x0441;&#x0438;&#x0442;&#x0435;&#x0442;</a> <a>ug:&#x064a;&#x0627;&#x0644;&#x06d0; &#x0626;&#x06c7;&#x0646;&#x0649;&#x06cb;&#x06d0;&#x0631;&#x0633;&#x0649;&#x062a;&#x06d0;&#x062a;&#x0649;</a> <a>vi:&#x0110;&#x1ea1;i h&#x1ecd;c Yale</a> <a>zh:&#x8036;&#x9c81;&#x5927;&#x5b66;</a></p>
name <p><strong>Columbia Business School</strong> (<strong>CBS</strong>) is the <a>business school</a> of <a>Columbia University</a> in <a>Manhattan</a>, <a>New York City</a>.
name <p>Columbia Business School is known for its close ties to <a>Wall Street</a> and the seminal work completed in the field of <a>Finance</a> by professors <a>Benjamin Graham</a> and <a>David Dodd</a>.
name <p>In 1945, Columbia Business School authorized the awarding of the <a>Master of Business Administration</a> degree (MBA).
name Glenn Hubbard</a> became Columbia Business School's eleventh dean.
name <p>Today, Columbia Business School is primarily housed in Uris Hall, a recently renovated 1960s structure at the center of Columbia's <a>Morningside Heights</a> campus.
name <p>In October 2010, Columbia Business School announced that alumnus <a>Henry Kravis</a>, the billionaire co-founder of private-equity firm <a>Kohlberg Kravis Roberts</a> (KKR &amp; Co.), pledged $100 million to fund expansion of Columbia Business School, the largest gift in its history.
name name=&quot;Columbia Business School&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; </p>
name name=&quot;http&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; Among the most popular electives at Columbia Business School are the Economics of Strategic Behavior, Financial Statement Analysis and Earnings Quality, Launching New Ventures, Modern Political Economy, and the Seminar in Value Investing.&lt;ref
name According to <em><a>Forbes</a></em> magazine, 90% of billionaires with MBAs who derived their fortunes from finance obtained their master's degree from one of three schools: <a>Harvard Business School</a>, Columbia Business School, or <a>The Wharton School</a> at the <a>University of Pennsylvania</a>.&lt;ref&gt;<a>Forbes:
name Columbia Business School offers the following areas of focus:&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>As part of its <a>MBA curriculum</a>, Columbia Business School offers the Value Investing Program at the prestigious <a>Heilbrunn Center for Graham &amp; Dodd Investing</a>, for a handful of selected business school students.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name <p>Columbia Business School's <a>Entrepreneurship Program</a> strives to provide students with the skills required for venturing and providing opportunities for them to start an entrepreneurial career in four career paths: entrepreneurship in new ventures, entrepreneurship in large organizations, private equity financing and social entrepreneurship.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name name=&quot;Columbia Business School&quot;/&gt;</p>
name <p>Columbia Business School's <a>Executive MBA (EMBA) Program</a> is a 20-month graduate program designed specifically for businesspeople that are looking to enhance their education without interrupting their careers.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name <p>Columbia Business School's Executive Education programs offer graduate Executive Certificate Programs such as the <a>Columbia Senior Executive Program</a> (CSEP),&lt;ref name=&quot;CSEP Program&quot;&gt;[<a>http://www4.gsb.columbia.edu/execed/programs/detail/10407/Columbia+Senior+Executive+Program</a>&quot;CSEP
name <p>Columbia Business School&#x2019;s eminence is rooted in the strength, leadership and experience of its 136 full-time faculty members,&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; including <a>Joseph Stiglitz</a>, the 2001 <a>Nobel laureate</a> in economics who also teaches at the university's <a>School of International and Public Affairs</a>; <a>Ray Fisman</a>, the Lambert Family Professor of Social Enterprise; and <a>Bernd Schmitt</a>, the Robert D. Calkins Professor of International Business.
name <p>Research centers, special programs, institutes, and cross-disciplinary areas at Columbia Business School include:&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>Held each year on the first Monday in May, the Annual Dinner is a highlight of the Columbia Business School calendar and brings together more than 1,000 business leaders, faculty members, students, alumni and friends for an evening of support for the School's many programs and initiatives.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name <p>Since 1977, two awards have been presented at each Annual Dinner, the Distinguished Leadership in Business Award and the Distinguished Leadership in Government Award, to honorees whose careers exemplify the professional, ethical, and leadership principles that define Columbia Business School.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>The <a>Columbia Business School Follies</a> is a student club that works throughout each semester to put together a production in which students write, choreograph, and perform <a>comedy skits</a>.
name <p>Columbia Business School has over 39,000 living alumni.&lt;ref&gt;<a>http://www4.gsb.columbia.edu/about/facts/alumni</a>&lt;/ref&gt;
name For a further listing of notable Columbia Business School Alumni see: <a>Columbia Business School alumni</a> and <a>List of Columbia University people</a>.</p>

name <p>{{Infobox university |name            = Jagiellonian University |native_name     = Uniwersytet Jagiello&#x0144;ski |image_name      = POL Jagiellonian University logo.svg
name <p>The <strong>Jagiellonian University</strong> (, often shortened to <em>UJ</em>; historical names: , University of Krakow, Krak&#x00f3;w Academy, The Main Crown School, Main School of Krak&#x00f3;w) was established in 1364 by <a>Casimir III the Great</a> in <a>Krak&#x00f3;w</a>.
name <p>In 1817 it was renamed <em>Jagiellonian University</em> to commemorate Poland's <a>Jagiellonian dynasty</a>, which had revived the University of Krakow after it had fallen upon hard times.&lt;ref
name name=&quot;officialhistory&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; In 2006 <em><a>The Times Higher Education Supplement</a></em> ranked Jagiellonian University as the top Polish university.&lt;ref&gt;Times
name Jagiellonian University was the first university in Europe to establish independent chairs in <a>Mathematics</a> and <a>Astronomy</a>.</p>

name <p>It was granted university status as &quot;Manchester Metropolitan University&quot; by the <a>Privy Council</a> on 15 September 1992 under the provisions of the <a>Further and Higher Education Act, 1992</a>.
name The Students' Union MMUnion exists to represent all members at the Manchester Metropolitan University and students on accredited external courses.

name <p>The <a>Archives of the University of Glasgow</a> are the central place of deposit for the records of the University, created and accumulated since its foundation in 1451.</p>

name <p>The Johns Hopkins University Library system houses more than 3.6 million volumes.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name <p>The Johns Hopkins University Press is the publishing division of the Johns Hopkins University.
name Since 1993, the Johns Hopkins University Press has run <a>Project MUSE</a>, a large online collection of over 250 full-text, peer-reviewed journals in the humanities and social sciences.
name <p>The <strong>University of Glasgow</strong> is the <a>fourth-oldest university</a> in the <a>English-speaking world</a> and one of Scotland's four <a>ancient universities</a>.
name <p>Since 1870, the main University campus has been located on <a>Gilmorehill</a> in the West End of the city.&lt;ref&gt;<a>University of Glasgow :: Location, maps and travel :: Location, maps and travel&lt;!-- Bot generated title --&gt;</a>&lt;/ref&gt; Additionally, there are a number of university buildings elsewhere in the city, a facility at <a>Loch Lomond</a>, the <a>University Marine Biological Station Millport</a> and the <a>Crichton Campus</a> in <a>Dumfries</a> (which is jointly operated alongside a number of other institutions).</p>
name <p>[[Image:University of Glasgow Gilbert Scott Building - Feb 2008-2.jpg|thumb|left|The
name The University of Glasgow was founded in 1451 A.D by a <a>papal bull</a> of <a>Pope Nicholas V</a>, at the suggestion of <a>King James II</a>, giving Bishop <a>William Turnbull</a> permission to add the university to the city's cathedral.&lt;ref&gt;<a>University of Glasgow - Who, Where and When</a>, retrieved 22 April 2006 &lt;/ref&gt; It is the second-oldest university in Scotland, and the fourth-oldest in the English-speaking world.
name <p>[[Image:Kelvingrove Art Gallery and Museum from the University of Glasgow Tower.jpg|thumb|left|The
name view over the [[Kelvingrove Art Gallery and Museum]] from the University of Glasgow tower]] The University's teaching quality was assessed in 2009 to be among the top 10 in the United Kingdom, along with its reputation as a &quot;research powerhouse&quot;, whose income from annual research contracts also placing among the top 10 the UK.
name The university overall generates a total income of over &#x00a3;421,000,000 per year- also amongst the top 10 in the UK.&lt;ref name=&quot;autogenerated3&quot;&gt;<a>University of Glasgow :: Facts and figures :: Facts and figures&lt;!--
name The University aims to be recognised as one of the UK's top 10 universities and as one of the world's top 50 research-intensive universities.&lt;ref&gt;<a>University of Glasgow - Building on Excellence</a>&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name Twenty-three subject areas, and 96 per cent of staff, were awarded 5 or 5* ratings in the 2001 <a>Research Assessment Exercise</a>.&lt;ref&gt;<a>University of Glasgow - Facts and Figures 2005 - Research</a>, retrieved 22 April 2006 &lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name As well as this there is the Garscube Estate in <a>Bearsden</a>, housing the <a>Veterinary School</a> and much of the University's sports facilities, the <a>Dental School</a> in the city centre, and the Crichton campus in Dumfries, operated jointly by the University of Glasgow, the <a>University of the West of Scotland</a> and the <a>Open University</a>.
name <p><a>right|thumb|200px|&lt;center&gt;The University of Glasgow in 1650.</a>
name <p>[[Image:Tower of The University of Glasgow.jpg|thumb|250px|The
name Scotland - Universities - The University of Glasgow</a>&lt;/ref&gt; An illustration of the Main Building currently features on the reverse side of the current series of <a>&#x00a3;100 notes</a> issued by the <a>Clydesdale Bank</a>.&lt;ref
name <p>The University's <a>Hunterian Museum</a> resides in the Main Building, and the related Hunterian Gallery is housed in buildings adjacent to the University Library.&lt;ref&gt;<a>University of Glasgow - Facts and Figures 2005 - Visitors</a>, retrieved 22 April 2006 &lt;/ref&gt; The latter includes &quot;The Mackintosh House&quot;, a rebuilt terraced house designed by, and furnished after, architect <a>Charles Rennie Mackintosh</a>.</p>
name <p>&lt;!-- Deleted image removed: <a>left||thumb|374px|Wolfson Medical School</a>  --&gt; The Wolfson <a>Medical School</a> Building, with its award-winning glass-fronted atrium, opened in 2002,&lt;ref&gt;<a>University of Glasgow - Wolfson Medical School Building</a>, retrieved 22 April 2006 &lt;/ref&gt; and in 2003, the St Andrews Building was opened, housing the Faculty of Education.
name The <a>Crichton campus</a>, designed to meet the needs for tertiary education in an area far from major concentrations of population, is operated jointly by the University of Glasgow, the <a>University of the West of Scotland</a> and the <a>Open University</a>.
name It offers a modular undergraduate curriculum, leading to one of a small number of liberal arts degrees, as well as providing the region's only access to postgraduate study.&lt;ref&gt;<a>University of Glasgow, Crichton Campus, Dumfries</a>&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>As well as these teaching campuses the University has halls of residence in and around the North-West of the city, accommodating a total of approximately 3,500 students.&lt;ref&gt;<a>University of Glasgow - Facts and Figures 2005 - Accommodation</a>, retrieved 22 April 2006 &lt;/ref&gt; These are the Murano Street halls in Maryhill; Wolfson halls on the Garscube Estate; Queen Margaret halls, in <a>Kelvinside</a>; Cairncross House and Kelvinhaugh Gate, in <a>Yorkhill</a>.
name <p>The University's constitution, academic regulations, and appointments are authoritatively described in the University calendar,&lt;ref&gt;<a>University of Glasgow - University Calendar</a>&lt;/ref&gt; while other aspects of its story and constitution are detailed in a separate &quot;history&quot; document.&lt;ref&gt;<a>Who,
name Where and When: The History &amp; Constitution of the University of Glasgow</a>&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name The current principal is Professor <a>Anton Muscatelli</a> who replaced Sir <a>Muir Russell</a> in October 2009.&lt;ref&gt;<a>University of Glasgow - University News - New Principal for the University of Glasgow</a>, retrieved 2 October 2009 &lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name The current Secretary of Court is Mr. David Newall.&lt;ref&gt;<a>University of Glasgow - Facts and Figures 2005 - Senior officers</a>, retrieved 22 April 2006 &lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>[[Image:AdamSmith.jpg|thumb|right|[[Adam Smith]]]] There are currently four <a>Colleges</a> within the University of Glasgow, each containing a number of Schools.
name <p>Many distinguished figures have taught, worked and studied at the University of Glasgow, including six Nobel laureates and two <a>Prime Ministers</a>, <a>Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman</a> and <a>Andrew Bonar Law</a>.
name <p><a>thumb|right|250px|The Glasgow University Union's building at the bottom of University Avenue</a>  In addition to the Students' Representative Council, students are commonly members of one of the University's two <a>students' union</a>s, the Glasgow University Union (GUU) and the Queen Margaret Union (QMU).&lt;ref&gt;<a>University of Glasgow - Facts and Figures 2005 - Student organisations and activities</a>, retrieved 22 April 2006 &lt;/ref&gt;  These are largely social and cultural institutions, providing their members with facilities for debating, dining, recreation, socialising, and drinking, and both have a number of meeting rooms available for rental to members.

name <p>{{Infobox University | name = Hiram College | image = <a>center|100px</a> | motto = <em>Fiat Lux</em> | mottoeng = <a>Let there be light</a> | established = March 1, 1850 | type = <a>Private</a>, <a>Liberal Arts College</a> | endowment = <a>US$</a>54.9
name <p><strong>Hiram College</strong> ( ) is a private <a>liberal arts college</a> located in <a>Hiram, Ohio</a>.
name Founded by Amos Sutton Hayden of the <a>Disciples of Christ</a> Church in 1850, the institution has, since its first days, been nonsectarian and coeducational, and throughout its existence Hiram College has sustained this egalitarian tradition of educating men and women from diverse backgrounds.
name Hiram College is accredited by <a>The Higher Learning Commission</a> of the <a>North Central Association of Colleges and Schools</a>.
name The school attained collegiate rank in 1867 and changed its name to Hiram College.&lt;ref
name <p>Three years after the Institute attained collegiate rank and became known as Hiram College, Burke A. Hinsdale, who had been a student of Garfield's, was appointed president.
name Because of the fairly brief terms of the two presidents who preceded him, Hinsdale is known as the first permanent president of Hiram College.
name <p>In September 2004, <a>Thomas V. Chema</a> was appointed as the 21st president of Hiram College.</p>
name <p><a>thumb|250px|left|Hiram College Athletic Complex</a> <a>100px|thumb|right|Athletics logo</a> <a>100px|thumb|right|Athletics logo</a> </p>
name The Hiram College basketball team, competing as the United States national team, won the <a>1904 Olympic</a> gold medal in <a>St.
name <p>The Hiram College undergraduate chapter of the <a>Association for Computing Machinery</a> is a club for technology enthusiasts and students with interest in computer science.
name The Hiram College Association for Computing Machinery meets periodically throughout the academic year.</p>
name <p>Established in 1929, Phi Gamma Epsilon (or &quot;Phi Gams&quot;) is currently the oldest existing Greek social club at Hiram College.
name <a>thumb|250px|right|The Kennedy Center</a> Another one of the social clubs at Hiram College is Delta Chi Lambda.
name <p>Terrier Productions is Hiram College's film and video production club.
name <p>Hiram College created its first marching band in Spring of 2006 emerging from an already established pep band.
name The first marching band in Hiram College history sprang from student initiative.
name Ohio Historical Marker Image:Copy_of_Picture_055a1.jpg|Oliver Plaza Image:Hiram College Library.jpg|
name   <li><a>Hiram College</a> Official site</li>
name   <li><a>Hiram College Study Abroad</a></li>

name <p>{{Infobox university |name=Emory University |image_name= Emory University Seal.png |caption= The seal of Emory University |motto= <em>Cor prudentis possidebit scientiam</em> |mottoeng= The wise heart will possess knowledge |established=1836 |type=<a>Private</a> |affiliation = <a>United Methodist Church</a>&lt;ref name=&quot;William Joseph Whalen - Hospitals &amp; Universities&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;General Board of Higher Education &amp; Ministry&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; |calendar = Semester |president=<a>James W. name <p><strong>Emory University</strong> is a private research university located in the metropolitan <a>Atlanta</a> area of <a>Druid Hills, Georgia</a>.
name The school initially struggled financially until a generous land-grant by <a>Asa Candler</a>, the president of the <a>Coca-Cola Company</a>, allowed the small college to move to metropolitan Atlanta in 1915 and become rechartered as Emory University.</p>
name <p><strong></strong> <a>200px|left|thumb|Glenn Memorial United Methodist Church near the main entrance of Emory University</a></p>
name name=&quot;english&quot;&gt;English, Thomas H. <em>Emory University 1915&#x2013;1965: A Semicentennial History</em> (Atlanta: Emory University, 1966).&lt;/ref&gt;
name <p><a>175px|left|thumb|Administration Building</a>The College of Arts and Sciences is the undergraduate institution of Emory University with 66 majors, 53 minors, 17 joint concentrations, and 10 interdepartmental programs leading to a bachelor's degree.
name The <a>Oxford College of Emory University</a>, located in <a>Oxford, Georgia</a>, enrolls about 700 students.
name The <a>Emory University School of Medicine</a> enrolls approximately 425 medical students, 1,000 residents and fellows, and 350 allied health students.
name <p>There are six degree programs within the <a>Emory University School of Medicine</a>: M.D., M.D./PhD, Physician Assistant (MMSc), Medical Imaging (BMSc), Anesthesiology and Patient Care (MMSc), and Physical Therapy (DPT).
name <p>Students in the <a>Emory University School of Law</a> may earn a Doctor of Law degree (JD), a Doctor of Judicia Science (SJD) or one of four dual degrees with the Goizueta Business School, Candler School of Theology, or Rollins School of Public Health.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name Degrees Awarded (2009-2010)|publisher=Emory University|date=2010-09-01 |accessdate=2010-10-20}}&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>Many of the graduate schools of Emory University were ranked as some of the best and most competitive in their fields by <em>U.S. News and World Report</em> in 2010.
name <p>[[Image:Thompson dooley.jpg|120px|right|thumb|Dooley, the unofficial [[mascot]] of Emory University]] Traditions at Emory include Dooley, the &quot;Spirit of Emory&quot; and the unofficial mascot of the university.
name Dooley's Week culminates with Dooley's Ball, a grand celebration that takes place in the center of campus on McDonough Field held in celebration of Dooley and Emory University.
name <h3>Emory University Transforming Community Project</h3>
name <p>In 2005, the Emory University president&#x2019;s office began a five-year program called the Transforming Community Project (TCP).
name The first five years of TCP's work engaged all sectors of the Emory University community in a process of discovery and dialogue about Emory&#x2019;s racial history.
name campus between main building and [[mensa]] (the university canteen)]] The University of Cologne is a statutory corporation (K&#x00f6;rperschaft des &#x00f6;ffentlichen Rechts), operated by the Federal State of <a>North Rhine-Westphalia</a>. </p>
name <li>The 2005 independent film <em>Kathy T</em> (also known as <em>Kathy T Gives Good Hoover</em>), about a college student whose life becomes more exciting after he reads some graffiti about Kathy T and decides to track her down, was written and directed by Emory University professor of film studies Ken Lieberman.
name <li>Scenes from <em><a>The Simple Life of Noah Dearborn</a></em>, a 1999 made-for-TV movie about a 91-year-old carpenter that must protect his land from being turned into a strip mall were shot on Emory University&#x2019;s Druid Hills campus.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</li>

name {{Infobox university |name            =Los Angeles Pierce College |native_name     = |latin_name      = |image           =<a>200px</a> |established     =1947 |type            =Public <a>community college</a> |endowment       = |staff           = |faculty         = |president       =Robert Garber |provost         = |principal       = |rector          = |chancellor      = |vice_chancellor = |dean            = |head_label      = |head            = |students        =23,000 |undergrad       = |postgrad        = |doctoral        = |profess         = |city            =<a>Woodland Hills</a>&lt;br&gt;<a>Los Angeles</a> |state           =<a>CA</a> |country         =<a>USA</a> |campus          =Urban - 426 acres (1.72 km&#x00b2;), in the <a>Chalk Hills</a> |free_label      = |free            = |colors          =Scarlet and White |colours         = |mascot          =Brahma Bull |nickname        =The Brahmas |affiliations    =<a>LACCD</a>; <a>WSC</a> |footnotes       = |website         =<a>www.piercecollege.edu</a>
name <p><strong>Los Angeles Pierce College</strong>, also known as <strong>Pierce College</strong>, <strong>Pierce</strong>, is a two-year <a>community college</a> that serves more than 23,000 students in the northern <a>Chalk Hills</a> of <a>Woodland Hills</a>, a community within the <a>San Fernando Valley</a> region of the <a>city of Los Angeles</a>, <a>California</a>.</p>
name Nine years later, in 1956, the school was renamed to <em>Los Angeles Pierce College</em>, retaining the name of its founder, Dr. Pierce, as well as his commitment to agricultural and veterinary study.
name [[Image:RustyTankAndBarn.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The western [[rural]] Farm Area, at Los Angeles Pierce College in <a>Woodland Hills</a>.]]
name <p>The Associated Students Organization (ASO) is the official Student Government of the 23,000 students at Los Angeles Pierce College.

name <p><strong>Lehigh University</strong> is a <a>private</a>, co-educational university located in <a>Bethlehem, Pennsylvania</a>, in the <a>Lehigh Valley</a> region of the United States.
name While the College of Arts and Sciences is the largest college today, home to roughly 40% percent of the university's students,&lt;ref name=&quot;class_summary&quot;&gt;<a>Class Summary</a>&lt;/ref&gt; the university is historically known for engineering&lt;ref name=&quot;academicinfo&quot;&gt;<a>Introduction to Lehigh University at AcademicInfo.com</a>&lt;/ref&gt; and business.

name <p>The <strong>University of California, Irvine</strong> (<strong>UCI</strong> or <strong>UC Irvine</strong>), founded in 1965, is one of the ten general campuses of the <a>University of California</a>, located in <a>Irvine</a>, <a>California</a>, USA.
name <p>UCI also maintains the UC Irvine Health Sciences system with its flagship <a>UCI Medical Center</a> in the <a>city of Orange</a>, the <a>University of California, Irvine, Arboretum</a>, and a portion of the <a>University of California Natural Reserve System</a>.</p>
name <p>The University of California, Irvine was one of three new campuses established in the 1960s under the <a>California Master Plan for Higher Education</a> with the <a>San Diego</a> and <a>Santa Cruz</a> campuses.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite

name <p><a>bg:&#x041a;&#x0430;&#x043b;&#x0438;&#x0444;&#x043e;&#x0440;&#x043d;&#x0438;&#x0439;&#x0441;&#x043a;&#x0438; &#x0443;&#x043d;&#x0438;&#x0432;&#x0435;&#x0440;&#x0441;&#x0438;&#x0442;&#x0435;&#x0442;, &#x042a;&#x0440;&#x0432;&#x0430;&#x0439;&#x043d;</a> <a>de:University of California, Irvine</a> <a>es:Universidad de California en Irvine</a> <a>eo:Universitato de Kalifornio &#x0109;e Irvine</a> <a>fa:&#x062f;&#x0627;&#x0646;&#x0634;&#x06af;&#x0627;&#x0647; &#x06a9;&#x0627;&#x0644;&#x06cc;&#x0641;&#x0631;&#x0646;&#x06cc;&#x0627;&#x060c; &#x0627;&#x0631;&#x0648;&#x0627;&#x06cc;&#x0646;</a> <a>fr:Universit&#x00e9; de Californie &#x00e0; Irvine</a> <a>ko:&#xce98;&#xb9ac;&#xd3ec;&#xb2c8;&#xc544; &#xb300;&#xd559;&#xad50; &#xc5b4;&#xbc14;&#xc778;</a> <a>is:Kaliforn&#x00ed;uh&#x00e1;sk&#x00f3;li &#x00ed; Irvine</a> <a>it:Universit&#x00e0; della California (Irvine)</a> <a>he:&#x05d0;&#x05d5;&#x05e0;&#x05d9;&#x05d1;&#x05e8;&#x05e1;&#x05d9;&#x05d8;&#x05ea; &#x05e7;&#x05dc;&#x05d9;&#x05e4;&#x05d5;&#x05e8;&#x05e0;&#x05d9;&#x05d4; &#x05d1;&#x05d0;&#x05d9;&#x05e8;&#x05d5;&#x05d5;&#x05d9;&#x05df;</a> <a>nl:Universiteit van Californi&#x00eb; - Irvine</a> <a>ja:&#x30ab;&#x30ea;&#x30d5;&#x30a9;&#x30eb;&#x30cb;&#x30a2;&#x5927;&#x5b66;&#x30a2;&#x30fc;&#x30d0;&#x30a4;&#x30f3;&#x6821;</a> <a>pnb:&#x06cc;&#x0648;&#x0646;&#x06cc;&#x0648;&#x0631;&#x0633;&#x0679;&#x06cc; &#x0622;&#x0641; &#x06a9;&#x06cc;&#x0644;&#x06cc;&#x0648;&#x0641;&#x0648;&#x0631;&#x0646;&#x06cc;&#x0627; &#x0627;&#x0631;&#x0648;&#x0627;&#x0626;&#x0646;</a> <a>pl:University of California, Irvine</a> <a>fi:Kalifornian yliopisto, Irvine</a> <a>zh:&#x723e;&#x7063;&#x52a0;&#x5dde;&#x5927;&#x5b78;</a></p>
name <p>{{Infobox university |name           = Michigan Technological University |image          = <a>160px</a> |caption        = Seal of Michigan Technological University |motto          = Create the Future |established    = 1885 |type           = <a>Public</a> |endowment      = <a>US$</a>63.6
name <p><strong>Michigan Technological University</strong> (<a>abbr.</a>
name In the final years of his presidency the school changed from a college to a university, changing its name a final time to Michigan Technological University.&lt;ref
name The name Michigan Technological University was chosen in order to retain the nickname of Michigan Tech that had already been in use since 1927.
name Along with the new name, Michigan Technological University, the school gained new constitutional status in 1964.
name <p>Michigan Technological University proposed to begin the construction of an environmentally friendly building in the summer of 1996.
name   <li><strong>Douglass Houghton Hall</strong>, commonly called DHH, is the smallest and oldest residence hall at Michigan Technological University.
name <p>Students attending Michigan Technological University have a wide range of activities to participate in, whether or not they are living in the <a>residence halls</a>.
name <p>Michigan Technological University's Enterprise Program is considered by many to be the University's defining feature.
name <p>The Pavlis Institute for Global Technological Leadership was formed at Michigan Technological University in 2006.
name <p><a>Category:Michigan Technological University</a> <a>Category:Educational institutions established in 1885</a> <a>Category:North Central Association of Colleges and Schools</a> <a>Category:Schools of mines</a> <a>Category:Universities and colleges in Michigan</a> <a>Category:Houghton County, Michigan</a> <a>Category:Technical universities and colleges</a> <a>Category:Oak Ridge Associated Universities</a> <a>Category:Association of Public and Land-Grant Universities</a> <a>Category:American Association of State Colleges and Universities</a> <a>Category:Forestry education</a></p>
name <p><a>de:Michigan Technological University</a> <a>id:Universitas Teknologi Michigan</a> <a>no:Michigan Technological University</a> <a>zh:&#x5bc6;&#x897f;&#x6839;&#x7406;&#x5de5;&#x5927;&#x5b78;</a></p>
name <p>{{Infobox University |name           = Carnegie Mellon University |image_name     = CarnegieMellonSeal.png
name |logo           = <a>200px</a> }}  <strong>Carnegie Mellon University</strong> (also known as <strong>Carnegie Mellon</strong> or simply <strong>CMU</strong>) is a <a>private</a> <a>research university</a> in <a>Pittsburgh</a>, <a>Pennsylvania</a>.
name In 1967, the <a>Carnegie Institute of Technology</a> merged with the <a>Mellon Institute of Industrial Research</a> to form Carnegie Mellon University.
name In 1965, it merged with the <a>Mellon Institute of Industrial Research</a> to become Carnegie Mellon University.
name The period starting with the construction of the Graduate School of Industrial Administration building (1952) and ending with Wean Hall (1971) saw the institutional change from Carnegie Institute of Technology to Carnegie Mellon University.
name panoramic view of Carnegie Mellon University's Pittsburgh campus from the College of Fine Arts Lawn.&lt;br/&gt;From left to right: College of Fine Arts, Hunt Library, Baker and Porter Hall, Hamerschlag Hall, <a>University of Pittsburgh</a>'s Cathedral of Learning (in the background), Wean Hall and Doherty Hall, Purnell Center, and the University Center.
name <p>In addition to its Pittsburgh campus, Carnegie Mellon has a branch campuses in the <a>Middle East</a>, <a>Carnegie Mellon University in Qatar</a>, which offers a full undergraduate curriculum with degree programs in computer science, business administration and information systems.
name <p>The Carnegie Mellon University campus in Pittsburgh served as the locale for many of the on-campus scenes in the 2000 film <em><a>Wonder Boys</a></em>, starring <a>Michael Douglas</a> and <a>Tobey Maguire</a>.
name <p><a>thumb|250px|right|The Hunt Library at Carnegie Mellon University is the largest library on the Pittsburgh Campus</a></p>
name   <li><strong>The <a>School of Computer Science</a></strong>: Carnegie Mellon University helped define, and continually redefines, the field of <a>computer science</a>.
name <p>Carnegie Mellon University Libraries include Hunt Library, the Engineering and Science Library, the <a>Mellon Institute</a> Library, the Posner Center, and the Qatar Library.
name The Hunt Institute for Botanical Documentation (HIBD), a research division of Carnegie Mellon University, and its library collections are located on the top floor of Hunt Library, but are not part of the University Library System.&lt;ref
name <p>The <strong><a>Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center</a></strong> (PSC) is a joint effort between Carnegie Mellon University, <a>University of Pittsburgh</a>, and <a>Westinghouse Electric Company</a>.
name PSC was founded in 1986 by its two scientific directors, Dr. Ralph Roskies of the University of Pittsburgh and Dr. Michael Levine of Carnegie Mellon University.
name <p>The <strong><a>Software Engineering Institute</a></strong> (SEI) is a <a>federally funded research and development center</a> sponsored by the U.S. Department of Defense and operated by Carnegie Mellon University, with offices in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA; Arlington, Virginia, and Frankfurt, Germany.
name Mountaineer and Author <a>Aron Ralston</a> also graduated from Carnegie Mellon University.</p>
name <p>The Greek tradition at Carnegie Mellon University began nearly 100 years ago with the founding of the first fraternity on campus, <a>Theta Xi</a>, in 1912.
name <p>Currently, Carnegie Mellon University has ten active Fraternities: Alpha Epsilon Pi, Beta Theta Pi, Delta Tau Delta, Kappa Sigma, Pi Kappa Alpha, Sigma Alpha Epsilon, Sigma Nu, Sigma Phi Epsilon, Sigma Tau Gamma and Sigma Chi (colony).</p>

name In 1994 the <a>University College London Hospitals NHS Trust</a> was established.
name In August 2008 UCL formed <a>UCL Partners</a>, the largest <a>academic health science centre</a> in Europe, with <a>Great Ormond Street Hospital for Children NHS Trust</a>, <a>Moorfields Eye Hospital NHS Foundation Trust</a>, <a>Royal Free Hampstead NHS Trust</a> and <a>University College London Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust</a>.&lt;ref

name <p>The <strong>University of Vienna</strong> () is a <a>public university</a> located in <a>Vienna</a>, <a>Austria</a>.
name In 2010, according to University Ranking by Academic Performance (URAP),&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; University of Vienna is the best university in Austria and 158th university in the world.</p>
name <p><a>thumb|240px|left|University of Vienna, main building, seen from across the Ringstra&#x00df;e</a> The University was founded on March 12, 1365 by <a>Rudolf IV, Duke of Austria</a> and his two brothers, <a>Albert III, Duke of Austria</a> and <a>Leopold III, Duke of Austria</a>, hence the additional name &#x201c;Alma Mater Rudolphina&#x201d;.
name After the <a>Charles University</a> in <a>Prague</a> and <a>Jagiellonian University</a> in <a>Krakow</a>, the University of Vienna is the third oldest university in <a>Central Europe</a> and the oldest university in the German-speaking world.</p>
name Approval was finally received from the Pope in 1384 and the University of Vienna was granted the status of a full university, including the Faculty of Catholic Theology.
name <p>Following the <a>Anschluss</a>, the annexation of Austria into Greater Germany by the Nazi regime, in 1938 the University of Vienna was reformed under political aspects and a huge number of teachers and students were dismissed for political and &quot;racial&quot; reasons.&lt;ref&gt;<a>http://gedenkbuch.univie.ac.at/index.php?L=2</a> Memorial Book for the Victims of National Socialism at the University of Vienna in 1938&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p><a>thumb|240px|Main Ceremonial Chamber (<em>Gro&#x00df;er Festsaal</em>) in the Main Building</a> The academic facilities of the University of Vienna occupy more than sixty locations throughout the city of Vienna.
name The nearby <a>Campus of the University of Vienna</a> forms an additional, more spacious, focus of the University.
name <p>The University of Vienna was placed 85th in the <a>Times Higher Education's</a> World University Rankings in 2007, rising from 87th place in 2006.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name <p>The University of Vienna, like all universities and academies in Austria, once featured a system of democratic representation.
name The reforms also separated the medical departments into separate medical schools, such as the <a>Medical University of Vienna</a>.</p>
name <p><a>Nobel Prize</a> Laureates who taught at the University of Vienna include <a>Robert B&#x00e1;r&#x00e1;ny</a>, <a>Julius Wagner-Jauregg</a>, <a>Hans Fischer</a>, <a>Karl Landsteiner</a>, <a>Erwin Schr&#x00f6;dinger</a>, <a>Victor Franz Hess</a>, <a>Otto Loewi</a>, <a>Konrad Lorenz</a> and <a>Friedrich Hayek</a>.</p>
name <p>The University of Vienna was the cradle of the <a>Austrian School</a> of economics.
name The founders of this &#x00e9;cole who studied and later instructed at the University of Vienna included <a>Carl Menger</a>, <a>Eugen von B&#x00f6;hm-Bawerk</a>, <a>Friedrich von Wieser</a>, <a>Joseph Schumpeter</a>, <a>Ludwig von Mises</a> and <a>Friedrich Hayek</a>.</p>
name <p>Other famous scholars who have taught at the University of Vienna are: <a>Theodor W. Adorno</a>, <a>Manfred Bietak</a>, <a>Theodor Billroth</a>, <a>Ludwig Boltzmann</a>, <a>Franz Brentano</a>, <a>Anton Bruckner</a>, <a>Rudolf Carnap</a>, <a>Conrad Celtes</a>, <a>Viktor Frankl</a>, <a>Sigmund Freud</a>, <a>Eduard Hanslick</a>, <a>Edmund Hauler</a>, <a>Hans Kelsen</a>, <a>Adam Franti&#x0161;ek Koll&#x00e1;r</a>, <a>Johann Josef Loschmidt</a>, <a>Fran Miklo&#x0161;i&#x010d;</a>, <a>Oskar Morgenstern</a>, <a>Otto Neurath</a>, <a>Johann Palisa</a>, <a>Pope Pius II</a>, <a>Baron Carl von Rokitansky</a>, <a>August Schleicher</a>, <a>Moritz Schlick</a>, <a>Ludwig Karl Schmarda</a>, <a>Joseph von Sonnenfels</a>, <a>Josef Stefan</a>, <a>Leopold Vietoris</a>, <a>Jalile Jalil</a> and <a>Carl Auer von Welsbach</a></p>
name <p>The University Library of the University of Vienna comprises the Main Library and the 50 departmental libraries at the various university locations throughout <a>Vienna</a>.
name <p>Kalamazoo College is a member of the <a>Great Lakes Colleges Association</a>.

name | logo                 = &lt;center&gt;<a>183px|upright|Logo of Duke University</a>&lt;/center&gt; }} <strong>Duke University</strong> is a <a>private</a> <a>research university</a> located in <a>Durham, North Carolina</a>, <a>United States</a>.
name Duke University is also ranked 14th in the 2010 <a>QS World University Rankings</a>.&lt;ref
name <a>William Preston Few</a>, the president of Trinity College, insisted that the university be named Duke University to honor the family's generosity and to distinguish itself from the myriad of other colleges and universities carrying the &quot;Trinity&quot; name.

name <p><a>Duke University Medical Center</a>, located directly north of West Campus, combines one of the top-rated hospitals and one of the top-ranked <a>medical schools</a> in the U.S. Founded in 1930, the Medical Center occupies 8 million square feet (700,000&nbsp;m&#x00b2;) in 99 buildings on 210&nbsp;acres (8.5&nbsp;km&#x00b2;).&lt;ref&gt;<a>DukeMedNews</a>.
