name <p>The <strong>University of Idaho</strong> is the state of <a>Idaho</a>'s oldest public university, located in the rural city of <a>Moscow</a> in <a>Latah County</a> in the <a>northern portion</a> of the state.
name The University of Idaho (officially abbreviated <strong>UI,</strong> but commonly referred to as the <strong>U of I</strong>) was the state's sole university for 71 years, until <a>1963</a>, and hosts the state's only <a>law school</a>, established in 1909 and accredited by the <a>ABA</a> in 1925.</p>
name       <li>- College of Engineering established in cooperation with the College of Mines&lt;ref name=autogenerated1&gt;<a>1907-1957 Historical Events, Centennial 1907 - 2007 College of Engineering, University of Idaho&lt;!--

name <p><a>thumb|250px|North entrance to the University of Idaho Arboretum and Botanical Garden</a> Referred to as &quot;Tree City&quot; or &quot;The Arb&quot; by UI students, the <a>Arboretum</a> is a 65 acre (26 hectare) site adjacent to the golf course which features display gardens, ponds, and a variety of trees and plants from <a>Asia</a>, <a>Europe</a>, and <a>North America</a>.</p>

name <p>   <strong>Kalamazoo College</strong>, also known as <strong>K College</strong> or simply <strong>K</strong>, is a <a>private</a> <a>liberal arts college</a> in <a>Kalamazoo</a>, <a>Michigan</a>, <a>United States</a>.
name <p>James Stone, the first president of Kalamazoo College, led the school from 1842 through 1863 and was responsible for instituting the high academic standards that allowed the College to receive its charter.
name <p>The first known student of African descent to attend Kalamazoo College was ex-slave Rufus Lewis Perry.
name Kalamazoo College also served as a pioneer in <a>coed education</a>, granting its first degree to a woman, Miss Catherine V. Eldred, in 1870.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>In 1877, Kalamazoo College students published the first edition of <em>The Index</em>, a student-run newspaper that continues to publish today.
name <p>Kalamazoo College's reputation as an academic powerhouse and a leader in international education was built during the presidency of <a>Weimer Hicks</a>, who served from 1954 to 1971.&lt;ref name=&quot;kpl.gov&quot;/&gt;
name As part of the original &quot;K Plan,&quot; Kalamazoo College students could attend school year-round.
name <p>Kalamazoo College is among the 100 oldest colleges and universities in the United States.
name <p>Students at Kalamazoo College must fulfill specific degree requirements in order to graduate.
name Ninety-five percent of Kalamazoo College's faculty have doctorates or terminal degrees in their fields.&lt;ref
name <p>On January 3, 2006, Kalamazoo College opened the new Upjohn Library Commons which includes the completely renovated skeleton of the older library, and an extension which adds to its volume capacity.</p>
name <p>Kalamazoo College is an academic leader among national liberal arts colleges and emphasizes the importance of an experiential education.
name Kalamazoo College is also unique in that it requires its students to take comprehensive exams in their major field of study before graduating.
name Kalamazoo College is the only undergraduate institution in the United States that requires both a senior project and a comprehensive examination.</p>
name <p>Kalamazoo College initiated the service-learning program in the 1997.
name In 2008, Kalamazoo College had twenty-three on-going service-learning programs.
name <p><a>US News &amp; World Report</a> America's Best Colleges 2003 ranked Kalamazoo College's study-abroad program number one in the country.
name Nearly 85% of Kalamazoo College students spend at least one term abroad and the college maintains partnerships with over 50 foreign universities on six continents.
name <p>In 2009, the Center Career Development merged with the <a>Guilds of Kalamazoo College</a> to create the <a>Center for Career and Professional Development</a>.
name The CCPD's mission is to create meaningful connections to the world of work, empowering Kalamazoo College students to explore, identify and pursue their diverse interests, values and passions, and to develop a framework of skills, networks and knowledge for successful lifelong career planning and professional development.
name <p>A recent study by Higher Education Data Sharing lists Kalamazoo College in the top 1 percent of colleges and universities whose graduates go on to earn a <a>Ph.D</a>.
name According to this study, Kalamazoo College is ranked number nine among all private colleges and&#x2014;when compared with all academic institutions&#x2014;it ranks number fourteen in Ph.Ds per capita.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name Among all undergraduate institutions, Kalamazoo College was #1 per capita in 2005 for recruitment of Peace Corps volunteers.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name Kalamazoo College competes in the following sports:</p>
name <p>The Kalamazoo College men&#x2019;s tennis team has won 72 consecutive Michigan Intercollegiate Athletic Association championships (1936&#x2013;2010) with a record of 426-2 in the MIAA from 1935 - 2007.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name <p>Men's swimming and diving at Kalamazoo College has an impressive history.
name The swimming and diving team is the second most successful athletic program at Kalamazoo College, after the men's tennis team, and it is also one of the top-10 most-successful teams in the MIAA with  25 MIAA championships.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>In 2001, the Kalamazoo College men's basketball team was at the center of a lengthy dispute regarding the outcome of a January 20 game with league rival <a>Olivet College</a>.
name With Olivet leading 70-69, Kalamazoo College center Kevin Baird made a shot at the buzzer that was initially waved off by referees.
name The referees reviewed videotape of the game and determined that Baird had, in fact, released his shot before the buzzer and then awarded Kalamazoo College a 71-70 victory.
name name=&quot;Time-Travel: History of Kalamazoo College&quot;&gt;<a>&quot;Time-Travel: History of Kalamazoo College&quot;</a>, Kalamazoo College.
name <p>Kalamazoo College has become a leading institution in the area of recycling and environmental awareness.
name In 2005, Kalamazoo College came to national prominence with a 3rd-place finish in the Grand Champion category.
name While annually placing in the top 5 in a variety of categories, in 2008 Kalamazoo College placed 1st in both the Grand Champion and Stephen K Gaski Per Capita Classic competitions.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name <p>Kalamazoo College signed the President's Climate Commitment in 2007 and has completed a greenhouse gas emissions inventory.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name <h2>Presidents of Kalamazoo College</h2>
name <p> In 2005 Dr. <a>Eileen Wilson-Oyelaran</a> became Kalamazoo College's 17th President and first female president, as well as the first African-American president of the school.

name <p>{{Infobox University |name            = California State University |native_name     = |latin_name      = |image_name      = California State University Seal.png |image_size      = 176px |motto           = <em>Vox Veritas Vita</em> (<a>Latin</a>) |mottoeng        = &quot;Voice Truth Life&quot; (Speak the truth as a way of life.)
name <p>The <strong>California State University</strong> (<strong>CSU</strong>) is a <a>public university</a> <a>system</a> in the <a>state</a> of <a>California</a>.
name It is incorporated as <strong>The Trustees of the California State University</strong>.
name The California State University system headquarters are at 401 Golden Shore in <a>downtown Long Beach</a>.&lt;ref&gt;<a>Home
name <em>California State University</em>.
name <p>Today's California State University system is the direct descendant of the <a>California State Normal School</a> (now <a>San Jose State University</a>), a <a>normal school</a> established by the California Legislature on May 2, 1862.
name <p>In 1972 the system became The California State University and Colleges, and all of the campuses were renamed with the words &quot;California State University&quot; in their names.
name Former San Diego State University student body president Calvin Robinson wrote the bill, signed into law by Ronald Reagan, that allowed every California State University the option to revert the schools back to their pre-1972 names: San Jose State, San Diego State, San Francisco State, etc.
name <p><a>thumb|right|250px|Office of the Chancellor in Long Beach</a> The governance structure of the California State University is largely determined by state law.
name The California State University is ultimately administered by the 25 member <a>Board of Trustees of the California State University</a>.
name The Trustees appoint the <a>Chancellor of the California State University</a>, who is the <a>chief executive officer</a> of the system, and the Presidents of each campus, who are the chief executive officers of their respective campuses.</p>
name <p>The <a>Academic Senate of the California State University</a>, made up of elected representatives of the faculty from each campus, recommends academic policy to the Board of Trustees through the Chancellor.</p>
name <p>The California State University is administered by the 25 member Board of Trustees (BOT).
name   <li>two students from the California State University appointed by the Governor</li>
name   <li>a representative of the alumni associations of the state university selected for a two-year term by the alumni council of the California State University</li>
name The delegation of authority from the BOT to the Chancellor has historically been controlled by a BOT resolution titled &quot;Statement of General Principles in the Delegation of Authority and Responsibility&quot; of August 4, 1961, and is now controlled by the Standing Orders of the Board of Trustees of the California State University.
name <p>The California State University's permanent, collective endowment has grown to $874 million U.S. dollars as of the close of the 2006-2007 academic year.&lt;ref&gt;<a>2006-2007

name As a result of recent legislation (SB 724 and AB 2382), the California State University may now offer the <a>Ed.D</a> (also known as the <a>Doctor of Education</a> or &quot;education doctorate degree&quot;) and <a>DPT</a> (Doctor of Physical Therapy) degrees to its graduate students.
name Additionally, the California State University (CSU) offers Ph.D degrees and some professional doctorates (for instance, audiology, Au.D) as a &quot;joint degree&quot; in combination with other institutions of higher education, including &quot;joint degrees&quot; with the <a>University of California (UC)</a> and accredited private universities.
name Thus, the CSU system has been referred to by former California State University authorities as &quot;The People's University.&quot;&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>

name <p>  The <strong>American Film Institute</strong> is an independent <a>non-profit organization</a> created by the <a>National Endowment for the Arts</a>, which was established in 1967 when President <a>Lyndon B. Johnson</a> signed the National Foundation on the Arts and the Humanities Act.
name <p>The American Film Institute re-opened the <a>AFI Silver</a> theatre in <a>Silver Spring, Maryland</a>, near <a>Washington, D.C.</a>, in April 2003.
name <p>The American Film Institute was founded in 1967 as a national arts organization to preserve the legacy of America&#x2019;s film heritage, educate the next generation of filmmakers and honor the artists and their work.

name <p>The <strong>United States Naval Academy</strong> (also known as <strong>USNA</strong>, <strong>Annapolis</strong>, or <strong>Navy</strong>) is a four-year <a>coeducational</a> <a>federal service academy</a> located in <a>Annapolis</a>, <a>Maryland</a>, United States.
name <p><a>thumb|right|Rotunda steps leading to Memorial Hall</a> The United States Naval Academy's campus is located in <a>Annapolis</a>, <a>Maryland</a>, at the confluence of the <a>Severn River</a> and the <a>Chesapeake Bay</a>.</p>
name The decision to establish an academy on land may have been in part a result of the <a>Somers</a> Affair, an alleged mutiny involving the Secretary of War's son that resulted in his execution at sea. <a>Commodore</a> <a>Matthew Perry</a> had a considerable interest in naval education, supporting an apprentice system to train new seamen, and helped establish the curriculum for the United States Naval Academy.
name The first superintendent of the <a>United States Naval Observatory</a>, Commander <a>Matthew Fontaine Maury</a>, advocate&lt;ref&gt;<a>http://www.history.navy.mil/library/online/maury_mat_bene.htm</a>&lt;/ref&gt; of the creation of the United States Naval Academy, after whom Maury Hall is named, similarly served in the <a>Confederate States Navy</a>.</p>
name Honorary Advisor, ABETS, Combustion, Gasification &amp; Propulsion Laboratory of Aerospace Engineering, Indian Institute of Science.</li>

Michael (University of Arizona) |title=&quot;Revolutionary Change at Evolutionary Speed&quot;: Women and the United States Naval Academy |journal=International Journal of Naval History |volume=1 |issue=1 |month=April | year=2002}}&lt;/ref&gt; <em>The Log</em> was once featured in <em><a>Playboy Magazine</a></em> for its parody of the famous periodical,&lt;ref&gt;The Log parodied a national magazine once each year&lt;/ref&gt; called &quot;Playmid.&quot; &quot;Playmid&quot; was an issue of <em>The Log</em> in 1989 and was ordered destroyed by Rear Admiral <a>Virgil I. Hill</a>, the Academy Superintendent at the time, but a handful of copies did survive, including the one which <em>       </em> later showed.
name Webb's response read in part, &quot;I am completely comfortable with the roles of women in today's military.... To the extent that my writings subjected women at the Academy or the active armed forces to undue hardship, I remain profoundly sorry.&quot;&lt;ref&gt;<a>http://www.timesdispatch.com/servlet/Satellite?pagename=RTD/MGArticle/RTD_BasicArticle&amp;cid=1149190613022&amp;c=MGArticle</a> &lt;/ref&gt; In a political advertisement for Allen five female graduates of the United States Naval Academy said the article helped <a>foster an air of hostility and harassment towards females within the academy</a>.</p>

name <p>{{Infobox university |name            =Chalmers University of Technology |native_name     =Chalmers tekniska h&#x00f6;gskola |latin_name      = |image           =<a>225px|Logo of Chalmers University of Technology</a> |motto           =Avancez |established     =1829 |type            =Private University |city            =<a>Gothenburg</a> |state           = |country         =<a>Sweden</a> |enrollment      = |students     = 8,400 (<a>FTE</a>, 2008)&lt;ref&gt;<a>Swedish Higher Education Authority (<em>H&#x00f6;gskoleverket</em>) - statistics for 2008 (Swedish), page 121</a>&lt;/ref&gt; |doctoral        =1,000 |staff           =2,500 |president       =Prof.
name }} <strong>Chalmers University of Technology</strong> (, often shortened to <strong>Chalmers</strong>), is a <a>university</a> in <a>Gothenburg</a>, <a>Sweden</a>, that focuses on research and education in technology, natural science and architecture.
name <p>Chalmers is an <a>aktiebolag</a> with 100 shares &#x00e0; 1000 <a>SEK</a>&lt;ref&gt;<a>Statues of Chalmers University of Technology Foundation, paragraph 3</a> (this is a translation of the <a>swedish text</a>.)&lt;/ref&gt;,
name all of which is owned by a private foundation (<a>Chalmers University of Technology Foundation</a>) which appoints the university board and the president.
name The foundation has its members appointed by the Swedish government (4 to 8 seats), the departments appoints one member, the <a>student union</a> appoints one member and the president automatically gains one chair.&lt;ref&gt;<a>Statues of Chalmers University of Technology Foundation, paragraph 5</a>&lt;/ref&gt; Each department is led by a department head, usually a member of the faculty of that department.

name |logo = <a>150px</a> }} <strong>Princeton University </strong> is a <a>private</a> <a>research university</a> located in <a>Princeton</a>, <a>New Jersey</a>, <a>United States</a>.
name <p>Founded in 1746 in <a>Elizabeth, New Jersey</a>, as the College of New Jersey, the university moved to Newark in 1747, then to Princeton in 1756 and was renamed Princeton University in 1896.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name <p>In 1896, the college officially changed its name from the College of New Jersey to Princeton University to honor the town in which it resides.
name <p> <a>thumb|200px|right|McCarter Theater</a>The Tony-award-winning&lt;ref&gt;<a>The American Theatre Wing's Tony Awards - Official Website by IBM</a>&lt;/ref&gt; <a>McCarter Theatre</a> was built by the <a>Princeton Triangle Club</a>, a student performance group, using club profits and a gift from Princeton University alumnus Thomas McCarter.
name <p> The <a>Princeton University Art Museum</a> was established in 1882 to give students direct, intimate, and sustained access to original works of art that complement and enrich instruction and research at the university.
name <p> <a>thumb|200px|right|Princeton University Chapel</a> <a>Princeton University Chapel</a> is the third-largest college chapel in the world, behind those of <a>Valparaiso University</a> and <a>King's College, Cambridge</a>, <a>England</a>.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name Construction on the Princeton University Chapel began in 1924 and was completed in 1927 at a cost of $2.4 million.
name name= &quot;Princeton University adopts its Sustainability Plan in February 2008&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; Princeton has committed to reducing its carbon dioxide emissions to 1990 levels by 2020 without the purchase of offsets.&lt;ref
name name= &quot;Princeton University Dining Services&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; The student organization &quot;Greening Princeton&quot; seeks to encourage the University administration to adopt environmentally friendly policies on campus.&lt;ref
name <p>With an endowment of US$14.4 <a>billion</a>, Princeton University is among the wealthiest universities in the world.
name The Trustees of Princeton University, a 40-member board, is responsible for the overall direction of the University.
name In February 2007, Princeton became the 12th major library system to join Google's ambitious project to scan the world's great literary works and make them searchable over the Web.&lt;ref name=&quot;NewsMax&quot;&gt;&quot;<a>Princeton University Joins Google Literature-Scan Project</a>&quot;.
name <p>From 2001 to 2010, Princeton University was ranked either first or second among national universities by <em><a>U.S. News &amp; World Report</a></em> (USNWR), holding the #1 spot for 9 of those 10 years.&lt;ref&gt;August
name <p>In the &quot;America's Best Colleges&quot; rankings by <em><a>Forbes</a></em> in 2008, Princeton University was ranked first among all national colleges and universities.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
name <p>In <em>Princeton Review<strong>s rankings of &quot;softer&quot; aspects of students' college experience, Princeton University was ranked first in &quot;Students Happy with Financial Aid&quot; and third in &quot;Happiest Students&quot;, behind Clemson and Brown Universities.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</strong></em></p>
name <p>Princeton University also participates in the (<a>NAICU</a>)'s <a>University and College Accountability Network (U-CAN)</a>.
name <p>Princeton University has an IBM <a>BlueGeneL</a> supercomputer, called <em>Orangena</em>, which was ranked as the 89th fastest computer in the world in 2005 (<a>LINPACK</a> performance of 4713 compared to 12250 for other U. S. universities and 280600 for the top-ranked supercomputer, belonging to the <a>U.
name &quot;Rowing at Princeton&quot;, Princeton University Rowing Association.&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
name The game, between Rutgers College (now <a>Rutgers University</a>) and the College of New Jersey (now Princeton University), took place on November 6, 1869 at College Field (now the site of the College Avenue Gymnasium at Rutgers University) in New Brunswick, New Jersey.
name <p>Notable among a number of songs commonly played and sung at various events such as <a>commencement</a>, <a>convocation</a>, and athletic games is Princeton Cannon Song, the Princeton University <a>fight song</a>.</p>
name <p>&quot;<a>Old Nassau</a>&quot; has been Princeton University's anthem since 1859.
name <p> Princeton University has been and is home to a renowned group of scholars, scientists, writers, chief justices, and statesmen who include four United States presidents, two of whom graduated from the university.

name <p>The <strong>Indian Institute of Science</strong> (<strong>IISc</strong>) is a research institution of higher learning located in <a>Bangalore</a>, <a>India</a>.
name <p> <a>Category:Universities and colleges in Karnataka</a> <a>Category:Education in Bangalore</a> <a>Category:Research institutes in India</a> <a>Category:Multidisciplinary research institutes</a> <a>Category:Tata institutions</a> <a>Category:Kingdom of Mysore</a> <a>Category:Educational institutions established in 1909</a> <a>Category:Engineering universities and colleges</a> <a>Category:Technical universities and colleges</a> <a>Category:Indian Institute of Science</a> <a>Category:Association of Commonwealth Universities</a></p>
name <p><a>ar:&#x0627;&#x0644;&#x0645;&#x0639;&#x0647;&#x062f; &#x0627;&#x0644;&#x0647;&#x0646;&#x062f;&#x064a; &#x0644;&#x0644;&#x0639;&#x0644;&#x0648;&#x0645;</a> <a>de:Indian Institute of Science</a> <a>fr:Indian Institute of Science</a> <a>gu:&#x0aad;&#x0abe;&#x0ab0;&#x0aa4;&#x0ac0;&#x0aaf; &#x0ab5;&#x0abf;&#x0a9c;&#x0acd;&#x0a9e;&#x0abe;&#x0aa8; &#x0ab8;&#x0a82;&#x0ab8;&#x0acd;&#x0aa5;&#x0abe;</a> <a>hi:&#x092d;&#x093e;&#x0930;&#x0924;&#x0940;&#x092f; &#x0935;&#x093f;&#x091c;&#x094d;&#x091e;&#x093e;&#x0928; &#x0938;&#x0902;&#x0938;&#x094d;&#x0925;&#x093e;&#x0928;</a> <a>it:Indian Institute of Science</a> <a>kn:&#x0cad;&#x0cbe;&#x0cb0;&#x0ca4;&#x0cc0;&#x0caf; &#x0cb5;&#x0cbf;&#x0c9c;&#x0ccd;&#x0c9e;&#x0cbe;&#x0ca8; &#x0cb8;&#x0c82;&#x0cb8;&#x0ccd;&#x0ca5;&#x0cc6;</a> <a>ml:&#x0d07;&#x0d28;&#x0d4d;&#x0d24;&#x0d4d;&#x0d2f;&#x0d7b; &#x0d07;&#x0d7b;&#x0d38;&#x0d4d;&#x0d31;&#x0d4d;&#x0d31;&#x0d3f;&#x0d31;&#x0d4d;&#x0d31;&#x0d4d;&#x0d2f;&#x0d42;&#x0d1f;&#x0d4d;&#x0d1f;&#x0d4d; &#x0d13;&#x0d2b;&#x0d4d; &#x0d38;&#x0d2f;&#x0d7b;&#x0d38;&#x0d4d;</a> <a>mr:&#x092d;&#x093e;&#x0930;&#x0924;&#x0940;&#x092f; &#x0935;&#x093f;&#x091c;&#x094d;&#x091e;&#x093e;&#x0928; &#x0938;&#x0902;&#x0938;&#x094d;&#x0925;&#x093e;</a> <a>ja:&#x30a4;&#x30f3;&#x30c9;&#x7406;&#x79d1;&#x5927;&#x5b66;&#x9662;</a> <a>fi:Intian tiedeinstituutti</a> <a>ta:&#x0b87;&#x0ba8;&#x0bcd;&#x0ba4;&#x0bbf;&#x0baf; &#x0b85;&#x0bb1;&#x0bbf;&#x0bb5;&#x0bbf;&#x0baf;&#x0bb2;&#x0bcd; &#x0b95;&#x0bb4;&#x0b95;&#x0bae;&#x0bcd;</a> <a>te:&#x0c07;&#x0c02;&#x0c21;&#x0c3f;&#x0c2f;&#x0c28;&#x0c4d; &#x0c07;&#x0c28;&#x0c4d;&#x200c;&#x0c38;&#x0c4d;&#x0c1f;&#x0c3f;&#x0c1f;&#x0c4d;&#x0c2f;&#x0c42;&#x0c1f;&#x0c4d; &#x0c06;&#x0c2b;&#x0c4d; &#x0c38;&#x0c48;&#x0c28;&#x0c4d;&#x0c38;&#x0c4d;</a> <a>zh:&#x5370;&#x5ea6;&#x79d1;&#x5b78;&#x7406;&#x5de5;&#x5b78;&#x9662;</a></p>
name <pre>|name              = Mendel University in Brno
name <p>}} <strong>Mendel University in Brno</strong> is located in <a>Brno</a>, <a>Czech Republic</a>.
name Reid was elected President of the Board &lt;ref name=&quot;Petersen&quot;&gt;Keith C. Petersen, <em>Educating in the American West: One Hundred Years at Lewis-Clark State College</em>, 1893-1993, &#x00a9; Lewis-Clark State College, Confluence Press, Lewiston, Idaho  (1993).&lt;/ref&gt;, a position he held until his death in 1902.</p>

image_size <p><a>thumb|right|200px|Kottman Hall: Home of the School of Environment and Natural Resources</a> <a>thumb|Drinko Hall: Home of Ohio State University Michael E. Moritz College of Law</a> Ohio State University comprises the following colleges and schools:</p>
image_size <p><a>thumb|200px|South Campus Gateway</a> Ohio State operates 31 on-campus residence halls divided into three geographic clusters: South Campus (site of the university's original dormitories), North Campus (largely constructed during the post-war enrollment boom) and Olentangy Area or &quot;The Towers.&quot;
image_size <p><a>thumb|200px|Enarson Hall (Original Ohio Union)</a> The <a>Ohio Union</a> was the first student union built by an American public university.

established <h3>King's College: 1754&#x2013;1784</h3>
established Classes began on July&nbsp;17, 1754 in Trinity Church yard, with Johnson as the sole faculty member.
established A few months later, on October&nbsp;31, 1754, Great Britain's <a>King George II</a> officially granted a royal charter for the college.
established <p>  The <strong>American Film Institute</strong> is an independent <a>non-profit organization</a> created by the <a>National Endowment for the Arts</a>, which was established in 1967 when President <a>Lyndon B. Johnson</a> signed the National Foundation on the Arts and the Humanities Act.
established <p>The American Film Institute was founded in 1967 as a national arts organization to preserve the legacy of America&#x2019;s film heritage, educate the next generation of filmmakers and honor the artists and their work.
established <p>The school was founded in 1949 under the name <strong>United Baptist Bible Training School</strong> (UBBTS), and served as both a <a>secondary school</a> and a Bible school.
established <p><a>Category:Universities and colleges in New Brunswick</a> <a>Category:Education in Moncton</a> <a>Category:Educational institutions established in 1949</a></p>
established |established=1764 |type=<a>Private</a> |calendar=Semester |endowment=<a>US $</a>2.8
established [[Ezra Stiles]] copy of the Brown University Charter of 1764]]</p>
established Founded in 1764 prior to <a>American independence</a> from the <a>British Empire</a> as the <em>College in the English Colony of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations</em> early in the reign of <a>King George III</a> (1760&#x2013;1820), Brown is the third oldest institution of higher education in <a>New England</a> and <a>seventh oldest</a> in the United States.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
established On March 3, 1764, a charter was filed to create the College in <a>Warren, Rhode Island</a>, reflecting the work of both Stiles and Manning.
established <p>In 1764, Edwards joined several others as an original fellow or trustee for the chartering of the College in the English Colony of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations (the former name for Brown University), the first Baptist college in the original <a>thirteen colonies</a> and one of the <a>Ivy League</a> universities.[<a>http://www.brown.edu/Administration/Corporation/downloads/charter-of-brown-university.pdf</a>]</p>
established He also served as the first chancellor of Brown (at the time called the College in the English Colony of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations) from 1764 to 1785.
established <p> Founded in 1764, The College is the oldest school of Brown University.
established This is the where the University was relocated in 1770 after it was first established in <a>Warren, Rhode Island</a>, in 1764.
established <p><a>Category:Association of American Universities</a> <a>*</a> <a>Category:Educational institutions established in the 1760s</a> <a>Category:1764 establishments</a> <a>Category:Ivy League</a> <a>Category:Colonial colleges</a> <a>Category:Rhode Island in the American Revolution</a> <a>Category:Non-profit organizations based in the United States</a> <a>Category:National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities members</a> <a>Category:New England Association of Schools and Colleges</a> <a>Category:Universities and colleges in Rhode Island</a> <a>Category:Education in Providence, Rhode Island</a> <a>Category:Buildings and structures in Providence, Rhode Island</a> <a>Category:Georgian architecture</a> <a>Category:Architectural styles</a> <a>Category:Colonial architecture in the United States</a> <a>Category:Visitor attractions in Providence County, Rhode Island</a></p>
established Founded in 1889, Barnard has been affiliated with Columbia since 1900.&lt;ref
established The college was named after <a>Frederick Augustus Porter Barnard</a>, an American educator and mathematician, who served as the president of the then-<a>Columbia College</a> from 1864 to 1889.
established <p>Barnard's original 1889 home was a rented <a>brownstone</a> at 343 Madison Avenue, where a faculty of six offered instruction to 14 students in the School of Arts, as well as to 22 &quot;specials&quot;, who lacked the entrance requirements in Greek and so enrolled in science.
established It also houses an archival collection of official and student publications, photographs, letters and other material that documents Barnard&#x2019;s history from its founding in 1889 to the present day.

established |image_size      = 230px |motto           = <em>Petimus Credimus</em> (<a>Latin</a>) |mottoeng        = We seek, we trust |established     = 1927 |type            = <a>Private</a>, <a>Christian</a> |endowment       = |staff           = 1,450 |alumni          = |faculty         = 281&lt;ref name=&quot;Greenville Journal 2009&quot;&gt;<em>Greenville Journal</em>, December 11, 2009, 27.&lt;/ref&gt; |president       = <a>Stephen Jones</a> |provost         = |principal       = |rector          = |chancellor      = <a>Bob Jones III</a> |vice_chancellor = |dean            = |head_label      = |head            = |students        = 3,950&lt;ref name=&quot;Greenville Journal 2009&quot;/&gt; |undergrad       = 3,450 |postgrad        = 500 |doctoral        = |profess         = |city            = <a>Greenville</a> |state           = <a>South Carolina</a> |country         = <a>USA</a> |campus          = <a>Suburban</a>,  |free_label      = |free            = |colors          = Blue and white |mascot          = |nickname        = |affiliations    = |footnotes       = |website         = <a>www.bju.edu</a>
established <p>The university was founded in 1927 by <a>Bob Jones, Sr.</a> (1883&#x2013;1968), an <a>evangelist</a> and contemporary of <a>Billy Sunday</a>.
established <p>The creed was written in 1927 by journalist and prohibitionist <a>Sam Small</a>, and students and faculty recite it at chapel services four days a week.</p>
established Established in 1927 near <a>Panama City</a>, on the Florida panhandle, Bob Jones College moved to <a>Cleveland, Tennessee</a> in 1933, and to its present campus in <a>Greenville, South Carolina</a> in 1947, where it became Bob Jones University.&lt;ref&gt;On the move to Greenville see, <a>John Matzko</a>, &quot;'This Is It, Isn't It, Brother Stone?' The Move of Bob Jones University from Cleveland, Tennessee, to Greenville, 1946-47,&quot; <em>South Carolina Historical Magazine</em>, 108 (July 2007), 235-256.

established <p>The University was founded in 1829 following a donation by <a>William Chalmers</a> (1748&#x2013;1811), a director of the <a>Swedish East India Company</a>, whose ships sailed across the world to supply Europe with goods from the East.

established It was founded in 1754 as King's College by <a>royal charter</a> of <a>George II of Great Britain</a>, and is one of only three United States universities to have been established under such authority.
established Founded and chartered as King's College in 1754, Columbia is the sixth-oldest such institution in the United States (by date of founding; fifth by date of chartering).
established Drexel University was founded in 1891 as the Drexel Institute of Art, Science and Industry by Philadelphia financier and philanthropist <a>Anthony J. Drexel</a> to provide educational opportunities in the &#x201c;practical arts and sciences&#x201d; for women and men of all backgrounds.
established Since its founding in 1891 the university has had more than 100,000 alumni.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>

established Founded in 1848, in <a>Northwood</a>, <a>Ohio</a>, the college moved to its present location in 1880, where it continues to educate a student body of about 1400 traditional undergraduates in over 30 majors, as well as graduate students in a handful of <a>master's</a> programs.
established <p>Geneva College was founded in 1848 in <a>Northwood</a>, <a>Ohio</a>, by John Black Johnston, a <a>minister</a> of the RPCNA.

established <p>{{Infobox University |name            = Hunter College |image           = <a>Hunter motto</a> |latin_name      =  |motto           = <em>Mihi cura futuri</em> &lt;br /&gt;(&quot;Mine is the care of the future&quot;) |tagline         =  |established     = 1870 |type            = <a>Public</a> |endowment       = $49 million &lt;ref&gt;<a>http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/new-york-ny/hunter-college-2689</a>&lt;/ref&gt; |staff           =  |president       = <a>Jennifer Raab</a> |provost         = Vita Rabinowitz |students        =  |undergrad       = 15,566 |postgrad        = 5,743 |doctoral        =  |profess         =  |city            = <a>New York City</a> |state           = <a>NY</a> |country         = <a>USA</a> |campus          = Urban |colors          = Purple and Gold &lt;span style=&quot;background-color:#330066;width:50px;border:1px solid #000000&quot;&gt;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&nbsp;&lt;span style=&quot;background-color:#FCB825;width:50px;border:1px solid #000000&quot;&gt;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&lt;/span&gt; |nickname        = Hawks |footnotes       =  |website         = <a>www.hunter.cuny.edu</a>
established <p><strong>Hunter College</strong>,  established in 1870 by Thomas Hunter, is a public university and one of the constituent colleges of the <a>City University of New York</a> (CUNY) system, located on <a>Manhattan</a>'s <a>Upper East Side</a>.&lt;ref
established Hunter descends from the <strong>Female Normal and High School</strong> (later renamed the <strong>Normal College of the City of New York</strong>), organized in <a>New York City</a> in 1870.
established <p><a>Category:Former women's universities and colleges in the United States</a> <a>Category:Hunter College</a> <a>Category:Association of Public and Land-Grant Universities</a> <a>Category:American Association of State Colleges and Universities</a> <a>Category:Universities and colleges in New York City</a> <a>Category:Educational institutions established in 1870</a> <a>Category:Universities and colleges in New York</a> <a>Category:Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools</a> <a>Category:Upper East Side</a> <a>Category:Universities and colleges in Manhattan</a></p>

established <p>Founded in 1858 and <a>coeducational</a> from its start, ISU is <a>classified</a> as a Research University with very high research activity (RU/VH) by the <a>Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching</a>.&lt;ref
established State University Time Line, 1858-1874</a>.
established <p> {{Infobox university |name = Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur |motto = &#x0924;&#x092e;&#x0938;&#x094b; &#x092e;&#x093e; &#x091c;&#x094d;&#x092f;&#x094b;&#x0924;&#x093f;&#x0930;&#x094d;&#x0917;&#x092e;&#x092f; (<em>tamaso m&#x0101; jyotirgamaya</em>) |mottoeng = Lead me from darkness to light |image_name = IIT Kanpur Logo.svg |image_size = 175px |established = 1959 |campus =  |type = <a>Education</a> and <a>research</a> <a>institution</a> |chairman = M Anandakrishnan |director = <a>Sanjay Govind Dhande</a> |city = <a>Kanpur</a> |state = <a>Uttar Pradesh</a> |country = <a>India</a> |undergrad = 2,800 |postgrad = 2,500 |staff = 1200 |website = <a>www.iitk.ac.in</a> }}</p>
established <p>The <strong>Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur</strong> () (also known as <strong>IIT Kanpur</strong> or <strong>IITK</strong>) is an <a>Indian Institutes of Technology</a>, set up in <a>Kanpur</a> in 1959.
established <p>IIT Kanpur was established by an Act of <a>Parliament</a> in 1959.
established The institute was started in December 1959 in a room in the canteen building of the <a>Harcourt Butler Technological Institute</a> at Agricultural Gardens in Kanpur.
established <p> <a>Category:Educational institutions established in 1959</a> <a>Category:Engineering colleges in Uttar Pradesh</a> <a>Category:Indian Institutes of Technology</a> <a>Category:Education in Kanpur</a> <a>Category:Kanpur</a></p>
established The school was founded by William Egbert in 1892 as a conservatory of music.
established <p>Ithaca College was founded as the Ithaca Conservatory of Music in 1892 when a local violin teacher, William Grant Egbert, rented four rooms and arranged for the instruction of eight students.

established <p><strong>James Madison University</strong> (also known as <strong>JMU</strong>, <strong>Madison</strong>, or <strong>James Madison</strong>) is a <a>public</a> <a>coeducation</a>al <a>research</a> <a>university</a> located in <a>Harrisonburg</a>, <a>Virginia</a>, <a>U.S.</a> Founded in 1908 as the State Normal and Industrial School for Women at Harrisonburg, the university has undergone four name changes until settling with James Madison University.&lt;ref
established <p>Founded in 1908 as a <a>women's college</a>, university was established by the <a>Virginia General Assembly</a>.
established   <li><a>Julian Ashby Burruss</a> (1908&#x2013;1919)</li>
established <p><a>Category:Former women's universities and colleges in the United States</a> <a>Category:Public universities</a> <a>Category:Universities and colleges in Virginia</a> <a>Category:American Association of State Colleges and Universities</a> <a>Category:Educational institutions established in 1908</a> <a>Category:Universities and colleges accredited by the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools</a> <a>Category:Education in Harrisonburg, Virginia</a></p>
established <p>{{Infobox university |name= Kansas State University  |image= <a>210px</a> |motto= Rule by Obeying Nature's Laws |established= 1863 |type= <a>Public</a>, <a>State</a>, <a>Land-grant</a>, <a>University</a> |president= <a>Kirk H. Schulz</a> |city= <a>Manhattan</a> |state= <a>Kansas</a> |country= <a>U.S.</a> |students= 23,588 (Fall 2010)&lt;ref name = Enrollment&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; |undergrad= 18,778&lt;ref name= Factbook&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; |postgrad= 4,366 |faculty= 1,305&lt;ref name= Factbook/&gt; |endowment= <a>$</a>259.8
established <p>Kansas State University, originally named Kansas State Agricultural College, was founded on February 16, 1863, during the <a>American Civil War</a>, as a <a>land-grant institution</a> under the <a>Morrill Act</a>.&lt;ref
established name=Griffin/&gt;  Finally, upon the third attempt on February 16, 1863, the state accepted Manhattan's offer to donate the Blue Mont College building and grounds and established the state's land-grant college at the site &#x2013; the institution that would become Kansas State University.&lt;ref
established <p>When the college opened for its first session in September 1863, it became only the <a>third public institution of higher learning to admit women and men equally</a> in the United States.

established <p>KAIST was established under the name of Korea Advanced Institute of Science (KAIS) under a special law on February 16, 1971, as the first research oriented graduate school in science and engineering in Korea.

established |established= 1666 |type= Public |city=  <a>Lund</a> |country= <a>Sweden</a> |image_name= Lund University seal.svg
established The university was founded in 1666 and is the second oldest <a>Swedish university</a>, but can arguably trace its roots back to 1438, when a <a>studium generale</a> was founded in Lund.&lt;ref&gt;<a>Historik - Lunds universitet</a>&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
established <p>After the <a>Treaty of Roskilde</a> in 1658, the <a>Scanian lands</a> came under the possession of the Swedish Crown, which quickly founded the Lund University in 1666 as the means of Swedification.
established <p><a>thumb|University Library</a> Lund University library was established in 1666 at the same time as the university and is one of Sweden's oldest and largest.

established <p>Established by the <a>Sisters of Charity of Saint Vincent de Paul</a> in 1873, the Mount was one of the only institutions of higher education for women in Canada at a time when women could not vote.
established |president     = Leslie E. Wong |established   = 1899 |type          = <a>Public</a> |website       = <a>www.nmu.edu</a>
established <p><strong>Northern Michigan University</strong> is a 4 year college <a>public university</a> established in 1899 located in <a>Marquette</a>, in <a>Michigan</a>'s <a>Upper Peninsula</a>.
established <p>Northern Michigan University, NMU for short, was established in 1899 by the <a>Michigan Legislature</a> as Northern State Normal School with the original purpose of providing teacher preparation programs in Michigan's then-wild and sparsely populated <a>Upper Peninsula</a>.
established When it opened its doors in 1899, Northern enrolled thirty-two students who were taught by six faculty members utilizing rented rooms in Marquette City Hall.
established   <li>Northern State Normal, 1899</li>

established It was founded in 1870 as a <a>land-grant university</a> and is currently the <a>third largest university campus</a> in the <a>United States</a>.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
established <p> Ohio State University was founded in 1870 as a <a>land-grant university</a> in accordance with the <a>Morrill Act of 1862</a> under the name of Ohio Agricultural and Mechanical College.
established In 1878, and in light of its expanded focus, the college permanently changed its name to the now-familiar &quot;Ohio State University&quot;, with &quot;The&quot; as part of its official name,&lt;ref&gt;<a>Ohio State University Timeline 1870 TO 1899</a>, Ohio State University Archives&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;Ohio 3335&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; although the state code that declares the &quot;The&quot; neglects it in sections&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; including in the title of the section that originally declares it.&lt;ref
established <p>Although development had been hindered in the 1870s by hostility from the state's agricultural interests and competition for resources from <a>Miami University</a> and <a>Ohio University</a>, both issues were eventually resolved.

established <p>Occidental College was founded on April 20, 1887, by a group of <a>Presbyterian</a> clergy and laymen, including <a>James George Bell</a>.
established please see talk page before changing --&gt; |established    = May 6, 1869 |type           = <a>Public</a>&lt;br /&gt; <a>Flagship</a>&lt;br/&gt;<a>Land-Grant</a>&lt;br /&gt; <a>Sea-Grant</a>&lt;br/&gt; <a>Space-Grant</a> |calendar       = Semester |endowment      = <a>$</a>1.457
established Purdue was founded on May 6, 1869, as a <a>land-grant university</a> when the <a>Indiana General Assembly</a>, taking advantage of the <a>Morrill Act</a>, accepted a donation of land and money from <a>Lafayette</a> businessman <a>John Purdue</a> to establish a college of science, technology, and agriculture in his name.&lt;ref
established On May 6, 1869, it was decided that the college would be founded near the city of <a>Lafayette</a> and legislators established the institution as Purdue University, in the name of the institution&#x2019;s principal benefactor.&lt;ref
established |established = 1746 |type = <a>Private</a> |calendar=  Semester |endowment = <a>US$</a>14.4
established |postgrad= 2,479 |faculty = 1,172 |staff = 1,103  |city = <a>Borough of Princeton</a>,&lt;br/&gt;<a>Princeton Township</a>,&lt;br/&gt;<a>Plainsboro</a>,&lt;br/&gt;<a>West Windsor</a> |state = <a>New Jersey</a> |country = <a>USA</a> |campus = <a>Suburb</a>an, &lt;br/&gt;(Princeton Borough and Township)  |former_names = College of New Jersey (1746&#x2013;1896) |athletics =38 varsity teams&lt;br&gt;<a>Ivy&nbsp;League</a>&lt;br&gt;<a>NCAA</a> <a>Division I</a> |colors         = <a>Orange</a> and <a>black</a>  |affiliations = <a>MAISA</a>; <a>AAU</a> |nickname = <a>Tiger</a>s |website = <a>princeton.edu</a>
established <p>Founded in 1746 in <a>Elizabeth, New Jersey</a>, as the College of New Jersey, the university moved to Newark in 1747, then to Princeton in 1756 and was renamed Princeton University in 1896.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
established A <a>Log College</a> was operated by <a>William</a> and <a>Gilbert Tennent</a>, the Presbyterian ministers, in <a>Bucks County, Pennsylvania</a>, from 1726 until 1746; it was once common to assert a connection between it and the College of New Jersey, which would justify Princeton pushing its founding date back to 1726.
established Massey Rhind]] (1892), Alexander Hall, Princeton University]] <a>New Light</a> <a>Presbyterians</a> founded the College of New Jersey, later Princeton University, in 1746 in order to train ministers dedicated to their views.
established <p><a>*</a> <a>Category:Ivy League</a> <a>Category:Educational institutions established in the 1740s</a> <a>Category:1746 establishments</a> <a>Category:Colonial colleges</a> <a>Category:Eastern Pennsylvania Rugby Union</a> <a>Category:Universities and colleges in New Jersey</a> <a>Category:National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities members</a> <a>Category:Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools</a> <a>Category:Association of American Universities</a> <a>Category:Universities and colleges in Mercer County, New Jersey</a></p>
established <p>{{Infobox University |name = Reed College |image = <a>120px|Reed Griffin</a> |caption = Mascot of Reed College |established = 1908 |type = <a>Private</a> <a>liberal arts college</a> |president = <a>Colin Diver</a> |city = <a>Portland</a> |state = <a>Oregon</a> |country = <a>United States</a> |coor=  |mascot=<a>Griffin</a> |undergrad = 1,442 (1,402 full-time; 40 part-time)&lt;ref name=&quot;Headcount&quot; &gt;{{cite web | title = Historical Enrollment (Fall Census Headcount) | publisher = Institutional Research, Reed College | url = <a>http://web.reed.edu/ir/enrollment_hist.html</a> }}&lt;/ref&gt; |postgrad = 29  |faculty = 135 |endowment = $311.1 million (June 2009)&lt;ref&gt;National Association of College and University Business Officers (NACUBO), 2010.
established Founded in 1908, Reed is a residential college with a campus located in Portland's <a>Eastmoreland</a> neighborhood, featuring architecture based on the <a>Tudor</a>-<a>Gothic</a> style,&lt;ref name=&quot;coat-of-arms&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; and a forested canyon wilderness preserve at its center.
established The <strong>Reed Institute</strong> (the legal name of the college) was founded in 1908, and Reed College held its first classes in 1911.

established |motto           =Vetenskap och Konst (&quot;Science and Art&quot;) |established     =1827 |type            =Public University |city            =<a>Stockholm</a> |country         =<a>Sweden</a> |students     = 11,950 (<a>FTE</a>, 2009)&lt;ref&gt;<a>Swedish Higher Education Authority (<em>H&#x00f6;gskoleverket</em>) - Annual report 2010 (Swedish), page 106ff</a>&lt;/ref&gt; |doctoral        =1,500 |staff           =3,100 |faculty         =500 |rector          =Prof.
established KTH was founded in 1827 as Sweden's first <a>polytechnic</a> and is one of Scandinavia's largest institutions of higher education in technology, (the largest by certain definitions).
established <p>KTH was founded in 1827 under the name Technological Institute (<em>Teknologiska institutet</em>), following the establishment of polytechnical schools in many European countries the early years of the 19th century, often based on the model of <a>&#x00c9;cole Polytechnique</a> in <a>Paris</a> in 1794.</p>

established |established       = 1861
established <p>The <strong>University of Washington</strong> (<strong>UW</strong>, commonly called <strong>U-Dub</strong>) is a public research <a>university</a>, founded in 1861 in <a>Seattle, Washington</a>, <a>United States</a>.
established <p><a>left|thumb|The original University building on Denny's Knoll, c. 1870</a> In 1861, scouting began for an appropriate  site in Seattle to serve as the campus for a new university.
established <p>UW opened officially on November 4, 1861, as the <strong>Territorial University of Washington</strong>.

established The university was founded in 1811 as <strong>The Royal Frederick University</strong> (in Norwegian <em>Det Kongelige Frederiks Universitet</em> and in Latin <em>Universitas Regia Fredericiana</em>) and was modelled after the recently established <a>University of Berlin</a>.
established Until the founding of the University in 1811, the <a>University of Copenhagen</a> was the only university of <a>Denmark-Norway</a>.

established <p><strong>Uppsala University</strong> () is a research <a>university</a> in <a>Uppsala</a> and is the oldest university in <a>Scandinavia</a>, founded in 1477.&lt;ref&gt;Ridder-Symoens,
established Sten, <em>A history of Uppsala University 1477-1977</em> (Almqvist &amp; Wiksell 1976)]&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
established Uppsala's bull, which granted the university its corporate rights, was issued by <a>Pope Sixtus IV</a> in 1477, and established a number of provisions.
established <em>A History of Uppsala University 1477-1977</em> (Almqvist &amp; Wiksell 1976).

established Dissenting Colgate trustees, faculty, and students founded the University of Rochester, receiving a charter from the <a>Regents of the University of the State of New York</a> on January 31, 1850.

established USC was founded in 1880, making it California's oldest private research university.</p>
established <p>When USC opened in 1880, tuition was $15.00 per term and students were not allowed to leave town without the knowledge and consent of the university president.

established Founded in 1883, the university has the <a>fifth-largest</a> single-campus enrollment in the nation as of fall 2009 (and had the largest enrollment in the country from 1997&ndash;2003), with over 50,000 undergraduate and graduate students and 16,500 faculty and staff.
established In 1883, another two million were granted, with income from the sale of land and <a>grazing rights</a> going to The University of Texas and Texas A&amp;M.&lt;ref
established The university opened its doors on September 15, 1883.</p>
established   <li><a>College of Liberal Arts</a> (1883)</li>
established The first Greek chapter on campus was the Texas Beta chapter of Phi Delta Theta and was founded on October 15, 1883, less than a month after the opening of the University.

established <h2>The Mechanics' Institute (1824&#x2013;1882)</h2>
established <p>The foundation of UMIST can be traced to 1824 during the <a>Industrial Revolution</a> when a group of Manchester businessmen and industrialists met in a <a>public house</a>, the <em>Bridgewater Arms</em>, to establish the <em><a>Mechanics' Institute in Manchester</a></em>, where artisans could learn basic science, particularly <a>mechanics</a> and <a>chemistry</a>.&lt;ref
established <p>The meeting, convened by <a>George William Wood</a> on 7 April 1824,&lt;ref name=&quot;kargonmain&quot;/&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;Wrigley&quot;&gt;  &lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;UMIST_history&quot;&gt; </pre>
established   <li>Sir <a>Benjamin Heywood</a>, a prosperous banker, acted as President of the Mechanics' Institute for the period 1824&#x2013;1841&lt;ref name=&quot;kargonmain&quot;/&gt;; his son, <a>Oliver</a> subsequently became President.&lt;ref
established cite web | url=<a>http://www.facebook.com/group.php?gid=2379644107</a> | title=University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology (UMIST) 1824 | work=Facebook group }}&lt;/ref&gt; The largest of these groups has more than 2,000 members.
established   <li>Cardwell, D. S. L. (ed.) (1974) <em>Artisan to Graduate: Essays to Commemorate the Foundation in 1824 of the Manchester Mechanics' Institution</em>, Manchester: Manchester University Press, ISBN 0-7190-1272-4</li>
established |name=University of Chicago |motto=<em>Crescat scientia; vita excolatur</em> (<a>Latin</a>) |mottoeng=Let knowledge grow from more to more; and so be human life enriched&lt;ref name=&quot;Motto Translation&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; |established=1890 |type=<a>Private</a> nondenominational coeducational |calendar= Quarter |president=<a>Robert Zimmer</a> |city=<a>Chicago</a> |state=<a>Illinois</a> |campus=<a>Urban</a>, 211&nbsp;acres (85&nbsp;ha)&lt;ref name=&quot;ffj&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; |undergrad=5,134&lt;ref name=&quot;tcf&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; |postgrad=10,304&lt;ref name=&quot;tcf&quot; /&gt; |faculty=2,168&lt;ref name=&quot;ffj&quot; /&gt; |staff=14,772 (including employees of the <a>University of Chicago Medical Center</a>)&lt;ref name=&quot;ffj&quot; /&gt; |athletics = <a>NCAA</a> <a>Division III</a> <a>UAA</a> |nickname=<a>Maroons</a> |mascot=<a>Phoenix</a>&lt;ref name=&quot;traditions&quot;/&gt; |affiliations = <a>Association of American Universities</a> <a>Committee on Institutional Cooperation</a> |endowment=<a>US $</a>5.578
established It was founded by the <a>American Baptist Education Society</a> with a donation from oil magnate and philanthropist <a>John D. Rockefeller</a> and incorporated in 1890.

established creating Collegiate School, which became <a>Yale College</a>, 9 October 1701]] <strong>Yale University</strong> is a <a>private</a> <a>Ivy League</a> <a>university</a> located in <a>New Haven, Connecticut</a>.
established Founded in 1701 in the <a>Colony of Connecticut</a>, the university is the third-oldest institution of <a>higher education</a> in the United States.</p>

established <p>Yale traces its beginnings to &quot;An Act for Liberty to Erect a Collegiate School&quot;, passed by the General Court of the <a>Colony of Connecticut</a> on October 9, 1701 in an effort to create an institution to train ministers and lay leadership for Connecticut.

established It was established in 1916 to provide business training and professional preparation for undergraduate and graduate Columbia University students.
established Barton Hepburn</a>, then president of <a>Chase Manhattan Bank</a>, founded the School in 1916 with 11 full-time faculty members and an opening class of 61 students, including 8 women.

established It was founded in 1919 as &quot;Southern Campus&quot; and is the second oldest of the ten campuses affiliated with the <a>University of California</a> system.
established They met resistance from Berkeley alumni, Northern California members of the state legislature, and Benjamin Ide Wheeler, President of the University of California from 1899 to 1919, who were all vigorously opposed to the idea of a southern campus.
established On May 23, 1919, the Southern Californians' efforts were rewarded when Governor <a>William D. Stephens</a> signed Assembly Bill 626 into law, which turned the campus into the <a>Southern Branch of the University of California</a> and added its general undergraduate program, the College of Letters and Science.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;

established Located in <a>Glasgow</a>, the university was founded in 1451 and is presently one of seventeen British higher education institutions ranked amongst the top 100 of the world.&lt;ref&gt;<a>QS
established The University of Glasgow was founded in 1451 A.D by a <a>papal bull</a> of <a>Pope Nicholas V</a>, at the suggestion of <a>King James II</a>, giving Bishop <a>William Turnbull</a> permission to add the university to the city's cathedral.&lt;ref&gt;<a>University of Glasgow - Who, Where and When</a>, retrieved 22 April 2006 &lt;/ref&gt; It is the second-oldest university in Scotland, and the fourth-oldest in the English-speaking world.
established <p>The University has been without its original Bull, issued by Pope Nicholas V in 1451, since the mid-sixteenth century.
established <p>The <a>Archives of the University of Glasgow</a> are the central place of deposit for the records of the University, created and accumulated since its foundation in 1451.</p>
established <p>At the University's foundation in 1451, there were four original <a>faculties</a>: Arts, Divinity, Law and Medicine.

established The university was founded as Emory College in <a>1836</a> in <a>Oxford, Georgia</a> by a small group of <a>Methodists</a> and was named in honor of <a>John Emory</a>, a well-known Methodist <a>bishop</a>.
established <p>In 1836, a small group of Methodists from <a>Newton County</a> contemplated the establishment of a new town and college.
established <p>On December 10, 1836, the <a>Georgia General Assembly</a> granted the Georgia Methodist Conference a charter to Emory College, named for <a>John Emory</a>, a popular bishop who had presided at the 1834 conference but had died in a carriage accident in 1835.&lt;ref

established |caption = <a>Seal</a> of the University of California, Irvine | image_size      = 180px | established     = 1965 | type            = <a>Public</a>, <a>Land</a>, <a>Space Granted</a> <a>Research University</a> | calendar        = Quarter  | endowment       = <a>US $</a>206.2
established <p>The <strong>University of California, Irvine</strong> (<strong>UCI</strong> or <strong>UC Irvine</strong>), founded in 1965, is one of the ten general campuses of the <a>University of California</a>, located in <a>Irvine</a>, <a>California</a>, USA.
established Unlike most other University of California campuses, UCI was not named for the city it was built in; at the time of the university's founding (1965), the current city of <a>Irvine</a> (established in 1975) did not exist.
established Soon after UC Irvine opened in 1965, the City of Irvine became incorporated and established in 1971 and 1975, respectively.&lt;ref
established <p>On June 20, 1964, U.S. President <a>Lyndon B. Johnson</a> dedicated UC Irvine before a crowd of 15,000 people, and on October 4, 1965 the campus began operations with 1,589 students, 241 staff members, 119 faculty, and 43 teaching assistants.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;

established Founded in 1826, UCL was the first university institution to be founded in London and the first in England to be established on an entirely secular basis, to admit students regardless of their religion and to <a>admit women on equal terms with men</a>.&lt;ref
established <p>UCL was founded in 1826 under the name &quot;<strong>London University</strong>&quot; as a <a>secular</a> alternative to the religious universities of <a>Oxford</a> and <a>Cambridge</a>.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
established A teaching and research collection, it is named after <a>Robert Edmund Grant</a>, UCL's first professor of comparative anatomy and zoology from 1828, now mainly noted for having tutored the undergraduate <a>Charles Robert Darwin</a> at the <a>University of Edinburgh</a> in the 1826&#x2013;1827 session.

established <p> {{Infobox university |name          = University of Idaho |image         = <a>University of Idaho Seal|180px</a> |motto         = <em>A Legacy of Leading</em> |established   = January 30, 1889 |type          = <a>Public</a> <a>Land Grant</a>&lt;br&gt; &amp; <a>Flagship</a> <a>University</a> |endowment     = $210.3 million &lt;ref&gt;[<a>http://www.uidahofoundation.org/uidahofoundation/financialhighlights</a>]&lt;/ref&gt;
established <p>The university was formed by the territorial legislature of Idaho on January 30, 1889, and opened its doors on October 3, 1892 with an initial class of 40 students.
established <p>On January 30, 1889, <a>Governor Edward Stevenson</a> of the <a>Idaho Territory</a> signed the territorial legislature's Council Bill No. 20, which officially established the UI as the upcoming state's <a>land-grant</a> institution.
established Founded in 1833, the college is among the 100 oldest in the country.
established <p>Kalamazoo College was founded in 1833 by a group of Baptist ministers as the Michigan and Huron Institute.
established Its charter was granted on April 22, 1833, the first school chartered by the Legislative Council of the Territory of Michigan.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;

established The California State Normal School was itself derived from the City of San Francisco's <a>Minns Evening Normal School</a> (founded in 1857) a normal school legislature dropped the word &quot;California&quot; from the name of the San Jose and Los Angeles schools, renaming them &quot;State Normal Schools.&quot;

established <p><a>Category:Association of Public and Land-Grant Universities</a> <a>Category:American Association of State Colleges and Universities</a> <a>*</a> <a>California State University system</a> <a>Category:Educational institutions established in 1857</a> <a>C</a> <a>Category:Universities and colleges in California</a> <a>Category:Schools accredited by the Western Association of Schools and Colleges</a></p>
established It was founded in 1893, and has an annual enrollment of approximately 3,500 students.
established <p>On January 27, 1893, Idaho Governor <a>William J. McConnell</a> signed an Act authorizing the establishment of the Lewiston State Normal School in Lewiston.&lt;ref&gt;James
established There was a catch, however: &quot;Provided the mayor and common council of that city on or before May 1, 1893, donate ten acres, within the city limits and known as part of the city park, and authorizing the said mayor and council to convey to the trustees of said normal school the said tract of land,&quot; etc.</p>
established Reid was elected President of the Board &lt;ref name=&quot;Petersen&quot;&gt;Keith C. Petersen, <em>Educating in the American West: One Hundred Years at Lewis-Clark State College</em>, 1893-1993, &#x00a9; Lewis-Clark State College, Confluence Press, Lewiston, Idaho  (1993).&lt;/ref&gt;, a position he held until his death in 1902.</p>

website There is no <a>dean&#x2019;s list</a> or honor roll per se, but students who maintain a GPA of 3.5 or above for an entire academic year receive academic commendations, which are noted on their transcripts, at the end of the spring semester.&lt;ref&gt;<a>http://www.reed.edu/academic/gbook/acad_pol/eval_student.html</a>&lt;/ref&gt;
website Reed also claims to have experienced very little grade inflation over the years, noting, for example,  that only seven students graduated with a perfect 4.0 GPA in the period from 1983 to 2007&quot;.&lt;ref name=&quot;grades&quot;&gt; &lt;/ref&gt; (Transcripts are accompanied by a card explaining Reed's relatively tough grading system, so as to not penalize students applying to graduate schools.)&lt;ref&gt;<a>Retrieved on 13 September 2008</a>&lt;/ref&gt; And though Reed does not award <a>Latin honors</a> to graduates, Reed does confer several awards for academic achievement at the time of commencement, including naming students to <a>Phi Beta Kappa</a>.&lt;ref&gt;<a>http://www.reed.edu/academic/gbook/acad_pol/awards.html</a>&lt;/ref&gt;</p>

calendar Stanford hosts monthly informal dances (called Jammix) and large quarterly dance events, including Ragtime Ball (fall), the Stanford Viennese Ball (winter), and Big Dance (spring).
calendar <li><a>Midnight Breakfast</a>: During Winter quarter dead week, Stanford faculty serves breakfast to students in several locations on campus (you might see a vice-provost refilling orange juice, etc.)</li>
calendar <li><a>The Game</a>: Is a scavenger hunt put on by dorm staff usually in the spring and summer quarters.</li>

calendar These funds include &quot;special fees&quot;, which are decided by a Spring Quarter vote by the student body.
calendar Each year, SWIB organizes over 25 events and workshops, hosts a winter and spring conference, and provides mentorship and spring quarter internships.</li>
calendar <p>NFL quarterbacks <a>Jim Plunkett</a>, <a>Trent Edwards</a> and <a>John Elway</a>, NFL receivers <a>Gordon Banks</a> and <a>Ed McCaffrey</a>, NFL Fullback <a>Jon Ritchie</a>, runner <a>Ryan Hall</a>, MLB starting pitcher <a>Mike Mussina</a>, MLB left-fielder <a>Carlos Quentin</a>, MLB infielder <a>Jed Lowrie</a>, Grand Slam winning tennis players <a>John McEnroe</a> (did not graduate) (singles and doubles) and (doubles) <a>Bob</a> and <a>Mike Bryan</a>, professional golfer <a>Tiger Woods</a> (did not graduate), <a>New Zealand Football</a> and <a>Blackburn Rovers</a> Defender <a>Ryan Nelsen</a>, Olympic swimmers <a>Jenny Thompson</a>, <a>Summer Sanders</a> and <a>Pablo Morales</a>, Olympic figure skater <a>Debi Thomas</a>, Olympic water polo players <a>Tony Azevedo</a> and <a>Brenda Villa</a>, Olympic softball player <a>Jessica Mendoza</a>, Heisman finalist <a>Toby Gerhart</a>, and actress <a>Reese Witherspoon</a> (did not graduate) are alumni.</p>

calendar <li><strong>Dandelion Day</strong>, colloquially known as <strong>D-Day</strong>, is a day late in the spring semester that was established as an annual respite around final exams with extensive celebrations, often accompanied by a carnival and musical guests.
calendar   <li><strong>Mela</strong> is an annual event held late in the spring semester celebrating Indian culture and dance.
calendar <li>A <strong>Pillow Fight</strong> occurs annually on the academic quad at the conclusion of the spring semester .</li>

calendar <p>The university operates on an <a>academic quarter system</a> with three primary academic quarters beginning in late September and ending in mid June.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
calendar Demand is very high for this special program and there is a waitlist each quarter.
calendar <p>Two other popular campus events include the Pumpkin Drop and the Watermelon Drop, which take place during <a>Halloween</a> and at the end of the third (Spring) <a>academic quarter</a>, respectively.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;

calendar |name=University of Chicago |motto=<em>Crescat scientia; vita excolatur</em> (<a>Latin</a>) |mottoeng=Let knowledge grow from more to more; and so be human life enriched&lt;ref name=&quot;Motto Translation&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; |established=1890 |type=<a>Private</a> nondenominational coeducational |calendar= Quarter |president=<a>Robert Zimmer</a> |city=<a>Chicago</a> |state=<a>Illinois</a> |campus=<a>Urban</a>, 211&nbsp;acres (85&nbsp;ha)&lt;ref name=&quot;ffj&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; |undergrad=5,134&lt;ref name=&quot;tcf&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; |postgrad=10,304&lt;ref name=&quot;tcf&quot; /&gt; |faculty=2,168&lt;ref name=&quot;ffj&quot; /&gt; |staff=14,772 (including employees of the <a>University of Chicago Medical Center</a>)&lt;ref name=&quot;ffj&quot; /&gt; |athletics = <a>NCAA</a> <a>Division III</a> <a>UAA</a> |nickname=<a>Maroons</a> |mascot=<a>Phoenix</a>&lt;ref name=&quot;traditions&quot;/&gt; |affiliations = <a>Association of American Universities</a> <a>Committee on Institutional Cooperation</a> |endowment=<a>US $</a>5.578
calendar <p>The University runs on a <a>quarter system</a> in which the academic year is divided into four terms: Summer (June&#x2013;August), Autumn (September&#x2013;December), Winter (January&#x2013;March), and Spring (April&#x2013;June).&lt;ref name=&quot;calendar&quot;/&gt; Full-time undergraduate students take three to four courses every quarter&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=<a>http://collegecatalog.uchicago.edu/pdf_10/academic-regulations.pdf</a>|title=Academic
calendar Regulations and Procedures|accessdate=August 13, 2009|format=PDF|publisher=The University of Chicago|quote=Students register for three or four courses per quarter.
calendar Over the typical four-year program (twelve quarters), a student normally registers for at least six four-course quarters and as many as six three-course quarters.}}
calendar &lt;/ref&gt; for approximately eleven weeks before their quarterly academic breaks.
calendar In the spring quarter of 2009, the University enrolled 3,633 graduate students: 485 in the Biological Sciences Division, 1,076 in the Humanities Division, 732 in the Physical Sciences Division, and 1,340 in the Social Sciences Division.&lt;ref
calendar The total enrollment for these six professional schools was 5,086 students in the 2009 spring quarter: 2,878 students in the business school, 344 in the Divinity School, 452 in the medical school, 269 in the Harris School, 494 in SSA, and 649 in the Law School.&lt;ref

calendar <p>In the 2009 Spring Quarter, the University of Chicago enrolled 4,920 students in the College, 3,633 students in its four graduate divisions, 5,088 students in its professional schools, and 14,000 students overall.&lt;ref&gt;
calendar &lt;/ref&gt; In the 2009 Spring Quarter, <a>international student</a>s comprised about 18% of the overall study body, at least 23% of students were domestic ethnic minorities, and 45% were female.&lt;ref

city It is the site of the university's Convention Centre, the premier conference centre of Melbourne's western suburbs.</p>
city   <li>UCSF has its own fully functional police department, which carries out policing duties for its two major campuses as well as all satellite sites within the city and in South San Francisco.</li>
city <p>The Student Village is a University owned residential complex providing accommodation for 510 students on 12 hectares of parkland only 9 km from the centre of Melbourne.
city It is a 35km drive to the centre of Melbourne with easy access to the Calder and Tullamarine freeways.</p>
city <p> <a>San Francisco</a> <a>Category:University of California, San Francisco</a> <a>Category:Educational institutions established in 1873</a> <a>Category:Universities and colleges in San Francisco, California</a> <a>Category:Schools of medicine in California</a> <a>Category:Schools accredited by the Western Association of Schools and Colleges</a></p>

city <p> {{Infobox university |name            = University of California,&lt;br&gt;San Francisco |motto           = <em>Fiat lux</em> (Latin) |mottoeng        = <a>Let there be light</a> |image_name      = UCSF Seal.png |established     = 1873 |type            = <a>Public</a> |endowment       =  $1.11&nbsp;billion (June 30, 2009)&lt;ref&gt;<a>UC Annual Endowment Report</a> <em>Office of the Treasurer of The Regents</em> Retrieved March 31, 2010.
city *The endowment of the University of California, San Francisco Foundation is $438.7&nbsp;million.
city |staff           = |faculty         = 1,686 |chancellor      = <a>Susan D. Desmond-Hellmann</a> |postgrad        = 2,998 (Fall 2008)&lt;ref&gt;<a>The University of California: Statistical Summary of Students and Staff</a>&lt;/ref&gt; |doctoral        = |city            = San Francisco |state           = California |country         = United States |campus          = Urban, 135 acres (0.55&nbsp;km&#x00b2;),&lt;br&gt;plus <a>Mission Bay</a> Campus&lt;br&gt;43 acres (0.17&nbsp;km&#x00b2;) |colors          = <a>UCSF Teal</a>  |mascot          = |nickname        = |affiliations    = <a>University of California</a> |website         = <a>UCSF.edu</a>
city |logo            = <a>150px</a> }} The <strong>University of California, San Francisco</strong> (<strong>UCSF</strong>) is one of the world's leading centers of health sciences research, patient care, and education.
city UCSF is administered separately from <a>Hastings College of Law</a>, another <a>UC</a> institution located in San Francisco.
city <p><a>thumb|UCSF in 1908, with the streetcar that used to run on Parnassus Avenue</a> UCSF traces its history to Dr. Hugh H. Toland, a <a>South Carolina</a> surgeon who found great success and wealth after moving to San Francisco in 1852.&lt;ref&gt;<a>Hugh
city name=UCSF01&gt;<a>A History of UCSF: San Francisco's First Medical Institutions</a>, UCSF, <em>Accessed October 6, 2010.</em>&lt;/ref&gt;
city <p><a>thumb|Saunders Court, Parnassus campus</a> UCSF operates four major campus sites within the city of San Francisco and one in <a>Fresno</a>,&lt;br&gt;as well as numerous other minor sites scattered through San Francisco and the <a>Bay Area</a>.</p>
city <p><a>thumb|Mission Bay, UCSF</a> <a>thumb|Mission Bay Community Center</a> UCSF's <a>Mission Bay</a> Campus, also located in San Francisco, is the largest ongoing biomedical construction project in the world.&lt;ref&gt;<a>New
city Gift Creates Professorship for UCSF Chancellor, Furthers Construction of Mission Bay Campus</a>&lt;/ref&gt; Byers Hall serves as the headquarters for the California Institute for Biomedical Research (QB3), a cooperative effort between the UC campuses at San Francisco, Berkeley, and Santa Cruz.
city The <a>San Francisco General Hospital</a> campus cares for the indigent population of San Francisco and contains San Francisco's only <a>Level I trauma center</a>.
city The hospital itself is owned and operated by the city of San Francisco, but many of its doctors carry UCSF affiliation and maintain research laboratories at the hospital campus.
city <p>UCSF is also affiliated with the San Francisco <a>VA</a> Hospital and the <a>J.
city <p>[[Image:Hippocrates I.jpg|thumb|[[Hippocrates]] statue, Parnassus Ave. in front of the Robert H. Crede Ambulatory Care Center]] University of California, San Francisco is unique in that it performs only biomedical and patient-centered research in its Schools of Medicine, <a>Pharmacy</a>, <a>Nursing</a>, and <a>Dentistry</a>, and the Graduate Division, and their hundreds of associated laboratories.
city Ranking of World Universities by Broad Subject Fields &#x2013; 2008</a>&lt;/ref&gt; The professional schools of the University of California, San Francisco are among the top in the nation, according to current (2006) <em>US News and World Report</em> graduate school and other rankings.
city <p>In <em>San Francisco Magazine's</em> 2003 survey of the &quot;Best Doctors&quot; in the Bay Area, 55 percent of those honored were UCSF faculty.</p>
city   <li>With a work force of 18,600 people and annual economic impact of $2&nbsp;billion, UCSF is San Francisco's second largest employer</li>
city <p><a>bg:&#x041a;&#x0430;&#x043b;&#x0438;&#x0444;&#x043e;&#x0440;&#x043d;&#x0438;&#x0439;&#x0441;&#x043a;&#x0438; &#x0443;&#x043d;&#x0438;&#x0432;&#x0435;&#x0440;&#x0441;&#x0438;&#x0442;&#x0435;&#x0442;, &#x0421;&#x0430;&#x043d; &#x0424;&#x0440;&#x0430;&#x043d;&#x0446;&#x0438;&#x0441;&#x043a;&#x043e;</a> <a>de:University of California, San Francisco</a> <a>es:Universidad de California en San Francisco</a> <a>fa:&#x062f;&#x0627;&#x0646;&#x0634;&#x06af;&#x0627;&#x0647; &#x06a9;&#x0627;&#x0644;&#x06cc;&#x0641;&#x0631;&#x0646;&#x06cc;&#x0627;&#x060c; &#x0633;&#x0627;&#x0646;&#x0641;&#x0631;&#x0627;&#x0646;&#x0633;&#x06cc;&#x0633;&#x06a9;&#x0648;</a> <a>fr:Universit&#x00e9; de Californie &#x00e0; San Francisco</a> <a>ko:&#xce98;&#xb9ac;&#xd3ec;&#xb2c8;&#xc544; &#xb300;&#xd559;&#xad50; &#xc0cc;&#xd504;&#xb780;&#xc2dc;&#xc2a4;&#xcf54;</a> <a>is:Kaliforn&#x00ed;uh&#x00e1;sk&#x00f3;li &#x00ed; San Francisco</a> <a>nl:Universiteit van Californi&#x00eb; - San Francisco</a> <a>ja:&#x30ab;&#x30ea;&#x30d5;&#x30a9;&#x30eb;&#x30cb;&#x30a2;&#x5927;&#x5b66;&#x30b5;&#x30f3;&#x30d5;&#x30e9;&#x30f3;&#x30b7;&#x30b9;&#x30b3;&#x6821;</a> <a>no:University of California, San Francisco</a> <a>pnb:&#x06cc;&#x0648;&#x0646;&#x06cc;&#x0648;&#x0631;&#x0633;&#x0679;&#x06cc; &#x0622;&#x0641; &#x06a9;&#x06cc;&#x0644;&#x06cc;&#x0648;&#x0641;&#x0648;&#x0631;&#x0646;&#x06cc;&#x0627; &#x0633;&#x0627;&#x0646; &#x0641;&#x0631;&#x0627;&#x0646;&#x0633;&#x0633;&#x06a9;&#x0648;</a> <a>zh:&#x820a;&#x91d1;&#x5c71;&#x52a0;&#x5229;&#x798f;&#x5c3c;&#x4e9e;&#x5927;&#x5b78;</a></p>
