city <p>{{Infobox university |name              = University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology (UMIST) |native_name       =  |image_name        = umist-logo.png
city |image_size        = 164x164 |caption           =  |latin_name        =  |motto             =  |mottoeng          = By Knowledge and Work |established       = 1824 |closed            = 2004 |type              =  |affiliation       =  |endowment         =  |officer_in_charge =  |chairman          =  |chancellor        =  |president         =  |vice-president    =  |superintendent    =  |provost           =  |vice_chancellor   =  |rector            =  |principal         =  |dean              =  |director          =  |head_label        =  |head              =  |faculty           =  |staff             = 1500 (2003) |students          =  |undergrad         = 4800 (2002) |postgrad          = 1700 (2002) |doctoral          =  |other             =  |city              = Manchester |state             =  |province          =  |country           = United Kingdom |coor              =  |campus            =  |former_names      = Manchester Mechanics' Institute; Manchester Municipal School of Technology; Manchester College of Science and Technology |free_label        =  |free              =  |sports            =  |colors            =  |colours           =   |nickname          =  |mascot            =  |athletics         =  |affiliations      = <a>1994 Group</a>  |website           =  |logo              =  |footnotes         =  }}</p>
city [[Sackville Street (Manchester)|Main Building]] from Aytoun Street / Whitworth Street]]</p>
city <p>The <strong>University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology</strong> (<strong>UMIST</strong>) was a <a>university</a> based in the centre of the <a>city</a> of <a>Manchester</a> in <a>England</a>.
city On 1 October 2004, it merged with the <a>Victoria University of Manchester</a> (commonly called the University of Manchester) to form a new entity also called The <a>University of Manchester</a>.
city Previously its degrees were awarded by the <a>Victoria University of Manchester</a>.
city <p><a>thumb|right|250px|Manchester Mechanics' Institute, Cooper Street in 1825</a></p>
city <p>The foundation of UMIST can be traced to 1824 during the <a>Industrial Revolution</a> when a group of Manchester businessmen and industrialists met in a <a>public house</a>, the <em>Bridgewater Arms</em>, to establish the <em><a>Mechanics' Institute in Manchester</a></em>, where artisans could learn basic science, particularly <a>mechanics</a> and <a>chemistry</a>.&lt;ref
city name=&quot;kargonmain&quot;&gt;Kargon (1977) <em>pp</em>20-24&lt;/ref&gt; Hundreds of such institutions  were founded in towns and cities throughout the country and while many of the fine <a>Victorian building</a>s built to house them remain, Manchester's alone survived as an independent institution serving some of its original educational aims throughout the 20th century.&lt;ref
city name=&quot;hartwell&quot;&gt;Hartwell (2001)&lt;/ref&gt; By this time the institution was called the <em>Manchester Municipal School of Technology</em> or fondly known as <em>The Tech</em>.&lt;ref
city name=&quot;cardwell&quot;&gt;Cardwell (1974)&lt;/ref&gt; As a project of the Manchester City Council it includes in the decoration many portrayals of the city's <a>coat of arms</a>.</p>
city Similarly in the 1920s it pioneered academic training in Management, with the formation of a Department of Industrial Administration funded by an endowment from <a>asbestos</a> magnate <a>Sir Samuel Turner</a>.&lt;ref&gt;Geoffrey Tweedale, Philip Hansen, Magic Mineral to Killer Dust: Turner &amp; Newall and the asbestos hazard, Oxford University Press, 2000, ISBN 0-19-829690-8, p. 7&lt;/ref&gt; But perhaps a more significant advance was the foundation in 1905 of a <em>Faculty of Technology</em>, answerable academically to its 'younger sister' the <a>Victoria University of Manchester</a> and awarding <a>BSc</a> and <a>MSc</a> degrees, the beginnings of UMIST as a University and the first technology faculty in the country.</p>
city <p>After the recent merger with <a>Victoria University of Manchester</a> the UMIST Main Building was renamed as the &quot;Sackville St. Building&quot;.</p>
city <p>In 1918, the institution changed name again to <em>Manchester Municipal College of Technology</em>.
city During 1955 and 1956 the Manchester College of Science and Technology achieved independent university status under its own <a>Royal Charter</a> and became separately funded from the <a>University Grants Committee</a>.</p>
city <p><a>thumbnail|The UMIST emblem as used in the late 20th century (based on the arms of the Institute, derived from the coat of arms of the lords of the manor of Manchester)</a></p>
city It overlooks Melbourne's historic <a>Flinders Street Station</a>, the <a>Yarra River</a> and the Southbank precinct.
city <p><a>|thumb|left|200px|Victoria University City Campus in Queens Street</a> The City Queen Campus occupies two heritage buildings in the heart of Melbourne's legal precinct.
city <p>By 1966 all non-degree courses were moved to the <a>Manchester Polytechnic</a> which is now known as <a>Manchester Metropolitan University</a>, and in 1966 the name finally changed to the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology on the initiative of Acting Principal <a>Frank Morton</a>.&lt;ref name=TCE&gt;<em>The Chemical Engineer</em> 11 March 1999, page 30 &quot;Frank Morton&quot; (obituary)&lt;/ref&gt; UMIST and the <a>Victoria University of Manchester</a> retained close ties for the second half of the 20th century, with UMIST students being awarded, or having the choice of, a University of Manchester degree until full autonomy in 1993.</p>
city <p>UMIST was the Faculty of Technology of the Victoria University of Manchester, an interesting situation because the University of Manchester held its own science and engineering courses.
city <p>Congregation ceremonies were held at the University of Manchester on Oxford Road, but in 1991 the first congregation ceremony was held in the Great Hall at UMIST itself in the Sackville Street Building.</p>
city <p>Students of UMIST were actually students of both UMIST and the Victoria University with graduation certificates stating the university issuing the degree as &quot;The Victoria University of Manchester&quot;.
city <p>UMIST students were entitled to use the facilities of Manchester University, including the <a>John Rylands University Library</a> at the Oxford Road site and sports facilities and social clubs organised by the students' unions.
city In fact, first year UMIST undergraduates were often placed into Manchester University halls of residence.</p>
city The tradition continues in The University of Manchester [<a>http://www.bogle.org.uk</a>]</p>
city <p>UMIST was instrumental in the founding of  what is now the  <a>Museum of Science and Industry in Manchester</a>.
city <p>UMIST, together with the <a>Victoria University of Manchester</a> ceased to exist on 1 October 2004, when they were combined in a new single <a>University of Manchester</a> hoping to combine the strengths and traditions of both.</p>
city No plans have been announced for the sale of any former Victoria University of Manchester buildings.
city <p>In the estates strategy for 2010-2020 for the University of Manchester [<a>http://documents.manchester.ac.uk/display.aspx?DocID=8186</a>] it is stated that essentially all of the former UMIST campus, described as the &quot;area north of the Mancunian Way,&quot; is to be disposed of.
city <p>Until the late 1980s, UMIST's official alumni organisation was called the Manchester Technology Association, a name which was a relic of UMIST's past incarnation as 'The Tech'.
city <p>In 2004, at the time of the university merger, the UMIST Association also merged with its equivalent organisation at the Victoria University of Manchester.
city cite web | url=<a>http://www.facebook.com/group.php?gid=2379644107</a> | title=University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology (UMIST) 1824 | work=Facebook group }}&lt;/ref&gt; The largest of these groups has more than 2,000 members.
city <p>UMIST moved to its present location just south of <a>Manchester</a> city centre at the end of the 19th century.
city The new edifices were designed by leading <a>Manchester</a> architects and were all built out of concrete.
city   <li><a>:Category:People associated with the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology</a></li>
city   <li>Cardwell, D. S. L. (ed.) (1974) <em>Artisan to Graduate: Essays to Commemorate the Foundation in 1824 of the Manchester Mechanics' Institution</em>, Manchester: Manchester University Press, ISBN 0-7190-1272-4</li>
city   <li>Marshall, J.D. (1964) &quot;John Henry Reynolds, pioneer of technical education in Manchester&quot;, <em>Vocational Aspect</em> 16/35, 176&#x2013;96</li>
city   <li><a>University of Manchester</a></li>
city <p> <a>UMIST</a> <a>Manchester, University of, Institute of Science and Technology</a> <a>Category:History of Manchester</a></p>
city <p><a>es:Instituto de Ciencia y Tecnolog&#x00ed;a de la Universidad de Manchester</a> <a>sv:UMIST</a></p>
city | established     =  1916 | type            =  <a>Public</a> | endowment       =   | chancellor      =  George Pappas | vice_chancellor =  Professor Elizabeth Harman | city            =  Melbourne | state           =  | country         =  Australia | undergrad       =  23,999 (2008) &lt;ref name=&quot;AnnualReport08&quot;&gt;<a>Victoria University Annual Report 2008</a>&lt;/ref&gt; | postgrad        =  4,568 (2008) &lt;ref name=&quot;AnnualReport08&quot; /&gt; | other           =  28,587 TAFE (2008) &lt;ref name=&quot;AnnualReport08&quot; /&gt; | staff           =  2,854 (2008) &lt;ref name=&quot;AnnualReport08&quot; /&gt; | campus          =  Urban | affiliations    =  <a>ASAIHL</a> | website         =  <a>www.vu.edu.au</a>
city <p><strong>Victoria University</strong> (VU) is a multi-sector tertiary institution (higher education and <a>TAFE</a>) based in Melbourne, Australia with 10 campuses.</p>
city <p>The Faculty of Arts, Education and Human Development works at the front line of cultural enquiry and social engagement, developing the social, physical and educative well being of those living in Melbourne's western region, and cultivating critical analysis and thought.
city   <li>Australian undergraduates: relatively young, relatively high Socio-Economic Indexes for Areas (SEIFA) score but lower than Melbourne mean, part-time employment, full-time</li>
city   <li>Full time workers: relatively high SEIFA score but lower than Melbourne mean, employed, mainly on full-time basis, part-time studies</li>
city <p>Victoria University emphasises research and research training that is of relevance to the community,industry and government &#x2013; both nationally and internationally, but particularly in the western region of Melbourne.
city <p>Victoria University campuses are located across Melbourne's western suburbs and the city centre.
city <p>City Flinders is located across two buildings at 300 Flinders Street and 301 Flinders Lane in central <a>Melbourne.</a>
city <p>VU was formed by a series of amalgamations with institutions across the west of Melbourne and has undergone several name changes.</p>
city   <li>Western Melbourne Institute of TAFE</li>
city   <li>Melbourne College of Decoration (Painting, Decorating and Signwriting Programs only)</li>
city   <li>Western Melbourne Institute of TAFE</li>
city <p><a>Category:Australian vocational education and training providers</a> <a>Category:Universities in Melbourne</a> <a>Category:TAFE Colleges in Melbourne</a> <a>Category:Association of Commonwealth Universities</a></p>
city <p>{{infobox University |image_name= Rustenborg.jpg |name=         Odense University |native_name=  Odense Universitet |latin_name=   Universitas Othiniensis |motto=        Fructus Increscit Opera Novo In Agro  |established=  1966 |type=         Public |staff=        1,000 |students=     19,000 (Spread over the full SDU) |city=         Odense |country=      Denmark |campus=       Urban |website=      <a>http://www.sdu.dk/E/Odense.html</a>
city }} <strong>Odense University</strong>, now <strong>Syddansk Universitet Odense</strong> (or <strong>SDU Odense</strong> in abbreviated form), has been part of the <a>University of Southern Denmark</a> since 1998 of which it forms the biggest campus.
city It is the university of <a>Odense</a>, <a>Denmark</a>'s third largest city, and the island of <a>Funen</a>.
city Approximately 800 researchers and 12,000 students (counting both <a>undergraduate</a>s and <a>postgraduate</a>s) are enrolled at SDU Odense.
city <p>Being an epitome of <a>Danish functionalist architecture</a>, SDU Odense has been <a>nickname</a>d <em>Rustenborg</em> (which roughly translates as <em>The Rusty Castle</em>) by students and staff, because it is built from gray concrete slabs covered with oxidized metal plates.
city <p>SDU Odense is considered the main campus of the <a>University of Southern Denmark</a>, both because of its relative size and because the central administration of the university is situated there.
city Odense is also by far the biggest campus of the SDU - both in terms of physical size and the number of students, staff, departments and degrees.</p>

state <p> {{Infobox university |name            = University of California,&lt;br&gt;San Francisco |motto           = <em>Fiat lux</em> (Latin) |mottoeng        = <a>Let there be light</a> |image_name      = UCSF Seal.png |established     = 1873 |type            = <a>Public</a> |endowment       =  $1.11&nbsp;billion (June 30, 2009)&lt;ref&gt;<a>UC Annual Endowment Report</a> <em>Office of the Treasurer of The Regents</em> Retrieved March 31, 2010.
state *The endowment of the University of California, San Francisco Foundation is $438.7&nbsp;million.
state In addition, funds owned by the University of California system but designated for UCSF total $671.9&nbsp;million.
state |staff           = |faculty         = 1,686 |chancellor      = <a>Susan D. Desmond-Hellmann</a> |postgrad        = 2,998 (Fall 2008)&lt;ref&gt;<a>The University of California: Statistical Summary of Students and Staff</a>&lt;/ref&gt; |doctoral        = |city            = San Francisco |state           = California |country         = United States |campus          = Urban, 135 acres (0.55&nbsp;km&#x00b2;),&lt;br&gt;plus <a>Mission Bay</a> Campus&lt;br&gt;43 acres (0.17&nbsp;km&#x00b2;) |colors          = <a>UCSF Teal</a>  |mascot          = |nickname        = |affiliations    = <a>University of California</a> |website         = <a>UCSF.edu</a>
state |logo            = <a>150px</a> }} The <strong>University of California, San Francisco</strong> (<strong>UCSF</strong>) is one of the world's leading centers of health sciences research, patient care, and education.
state Though one of the ten campuses of the <a>University of California</a>, it is unique for being the only University of California campus dedicated solely to graduate education, and this in health and <a>biomedical science</a>s.
state <p>The <a>University of California</a> was founded in 1868, and by 1870 Toland Medical School began negotiating an affiliation with the new public university.&lt;ref
state name = UCSF02/&gt;  In March 1873, the <a>trustee</a>s of Toland Medical College deeded it to the <a>Regents of the University of California</a>, and it became &quot;The Medical Department of the University of California.&quot;&lt;ref
state It also houses the UCSF neurology outpatient practice that serves as a referral center of most of Northern California and <a>Reno</a>, Nevada.</p>
state Gift Creates Professorship for UCSF Chancellor, Furthers Construction of Mission Bay Campus</a>&lt;/ref&gt; Byers Hall serves as the headquarters for the California Institute for Biomedical Research (QB3), a cooperative effort between the UC campuses at San Francisco, Berkeley, and Santa Cruz.
state The headquarters of the new <a>California Institute for Regenerative Medicine</a> are also located nearby in the Mission Bay neighborhood.</p>
state <p>[[Image:Hippocrates I.jpg|thumb|[[Hippocrates]] statue, Parnassus Ave. in front of the Robert H. Crede Ambulatory Care Center]] University of California, San Francisco is unique in that it performs only biomedical and patient-centered research in its Schools of Medicine, <a>Pharmacy</a>, <a>Nursing</a>, and <a>Dentistry</a>, and the Graduate Division, and their hundreds of associated laboratories.
state Ranking of World Universities by Broad Subject Fields &#x2013; 2008</a>&lt;/ref&gt; The professional schools of the University of California, San Francisco are among the top in the nation, according to current (2006) <em>US News and World Report</em> graduate school and other rankings.
state In addition, the UCSF Medical Center in 2007 was ranked by <em>US News and World Report</em> the 7th-best hospital in the nation,&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; making it the highest-ranked medical center in northern California.</p>
state Medical Center and [[Sutro Tower]]]] In 2007, <em>US News and World Report</em> named the <a>UCSF Medical Center</a> the seventh-best hospital in the nation, making it the highest-ranked medical center in Northern California.
state 16 &#x2013; among the highest-rated children's medical service in California.</p>
state <p>In the magazine's &quot;America's Best Hospitals&quot; survey, the UCSF Medical Center ranked best in Northern California &#x2013; as well as among the best in the nation &#x2013; in the following specialties: <a>endocrinology</a>, <a>neurology</a>/<a>neurosurgery</a>; <a>gynecology</a>; cancer; <a>kidney disease</a>; <a>ophthalmology</a>; respiratory disorders; <a>rheumatology</a>; <a>urology</a>; digestive disorders; <a>ear, nose, and throat</a>; <a>psychiatry</a>; <a>heart</a> and <a>heart surgery</a>; and <a>pediatrics</a>.&lt;ref&gt;<a><em>US

country Founded in 1764 prior to <a>American independence</a> from the <a>British Empire</a> as the <em>College in the English Colony of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations</em> early in the reign of <a>King George III</a> (1760&#x2013;1820), Brown is the third oldest institution of higher education in <a>New England</a> and <a>seventh oldest</a> in the United States.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
country He was a signatory to the <a>United States Declaration of Independence</a> on behalf of the state of Rhode Island.
country <p>In 1786, President <a>James Manning</a> was elected and served as representative for Rhode Island to the seventh session of the <a>United States in Congress Assembled</a>, held in <a>New York</a>.
country In that capacity, he served on the Grand Committee, which proposed fundamental amendments to the Articles of Confederation and presaged the <a>Constitution of the United States</a>.&lt;ref&gt;<a>Proposed
country Concentrations Completed: Selected Years</a>&lt;/ref&gt; Brown is one of the few schools in the United States with an undergraduate concentration (major) in <a>Egyptology</a>.

country |logo = <a>center|225px</a> }} The <strong>Leland Stanford Junior University</strong>, commonly referred to as <strong>Stanford University</strong> or <strong>Stanford</strong>, is a <a>private research university</a> located in <a>Stanford, California</a>, United States with a strong emphasis on scientific, technological and social science research.
country In the <a>2008 Summer Olympics</a> in <a>Beijing</a>, Stanford athletes won 25 medals, including 8 gold medals, more than any other university in the United States.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
country <p>Stanford was founded by <a>Leland Stanford</a>, a <a>railroad</a> magnate, <a>United States Senator</a>, and former <a>California Governor</a>, and his wife, <a>Jane Stanford</a>.
country He had been in charge of American relief efforts in Europe after World War I before his election as president of the United States in 1928.

country <p>The undergraduate student government of UC Davis is the <a>Associated Students of UC Davis</a> (ASUCD), and has an annual operating budget of 10.5 million dollars, making it the best-funded student government in the United States.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
country <p> In 2011 U.S. News and World Report ranked UC Davis as the 9th best public university in the United States, and the 4th best of the UC schools (tied with <a>UCSB</a>), after <a>UC Berkeley</a>, <a>UCLA</a>, and <a>UCSD</a>.
country It consists of sixty universities in the United States (both public and private) and two universities in Canada.</p>

country <p> Midshipmen at the Academy wear service dress uniforms similar to those of U.S. Navy officers, with shoulder-board and sleeve insignia varying by school year or midshipmen officer rank.

country <p>  The <strong>University for Peace</strong> (<strong>UPEACE</strong>) was established in <a>Costa Rica</a> in <a>1980</a>&lt;ref name=&quot;UN_ARES3555&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; &quot;to provide humanity with an international institution of higher education for peace and with the aim of promoting among all human beings the spirit of understanding, tolerance and <a>peaceful coexistence</a>.&quot;&lt;ref
country <p>At present, the UPEACE Costa Rica campus has 192 students from 55 countries, making it one of the most diverse universities in the world for its size.
country <p>The vision of UPEACE is to become a network of collaborating UPEACE centres and activities in different regions, guided from its headquarters in Costa Rica and cooperating with a large number of universities, NGOs and other partners on education and research for peace.
country UPEACE is in the process of seeking accreditation through the Costa Rican official body SINAES.
country <p>The Costa Rica campus of UPEACE sits on more than three square kilometres of beautiful land some 30 kilometers southwest&lt;ref&gt;<a>http://www.upeace.org/about/campus/</a>&lt;/ref&gt; of the capital, <a>San Jos&#x00e9;</a>.
country <p>UPEACE has eight one-year masters program at its Costa Rica campus: <a>International Law and Human Rights</a>, <a>International Law and the Settlement of Disputes</a>, <a>Gender and Peace Building</a>, <a>International Peace Studies</a>, <a>Peace Education</a>, <a>Environmental Security and Peace</a>, and <a>Media, Peace and Conflict</a>.
country <p>In addition to its Costa Rica headquarters, the UPEACE system includes offices in <a>Geneva</a> and New York City, the <a>Africa Regional Program office</a> in Addis Ababa, the Latin America and the Caribbean Regional Program office in Costa Rica.
country <p>The university's <a>Centre for Executive Education</a>, is offering short courses to professional audiences who come to Costa Rica for an intensive week.
country UPEACE/US projects include DCPEACE, an initiative to empower teachers, youth, and families with the skills and knowledge necessary to effectively serve as peacebuilders in their communities and PeaceRooms, a program that connect classrooms of middle school students from Costa Rica and Washington D.C. through the use of innovative virtual networking technology for the purpose of developing core concepts of global citizenship and peace education.<a>UPEACE/US
country <p>The UPEACE Sharing Knowledge for Peace Program (SKP) is a distance learning initiative which ensures that those unable to attend courses in Costa Rica or in one of the other UPEACE locations are reached through state-of-the-art dissemination methods.<a>right|250px|thumb|View
country from Costa Rica Campus</a></p>
country   <li><a>Welcome to Ciudad Colon, Mora Costa Rica</a></li>

country }} <strong>Odense University</strong>, now <strong>Syddansk Universitet Odense</strong> (or <strong>SDU Odense</strong> in abbreviated form), has been part of the <a>University of Southern Denmark</a> since 1998 of which it forms the biggest campus.
country It is the university of <a>Odense</a>, <a>Denmark</a>'s third largest city, and the island of <a>Funen</a>.
country <p>SDU Odense is considered the main campus of the <a>University of Southern Denmark</a>, both because of its relative size and because the central administration of the university is situated there.

country <p>Founded as the Missouri Dental College in 1866, the <a>Washington University School of Dental Medicine</a> was the first dental school west of the Mississippi River and only the sixth dental school in the U.S. The school closed in 1991.</p>
country   <li>Notable recent graduates of the college include:   Missouri Senator <a>Jim Talent</a>, Nevada Senator <a>Chic Hecht</a>, and Nebraska Congressman <a>Hal Daub</a>; <a>George Zimmer</a>, founder of <a>Men's Wearhouse</a>; businessman and adventurer <a>Steve Fossett</a>; <a>Avram Glazer</a>, chairman of <a>Manchester United</a>; Pulitzer Prize-winning journalists <a>Ken Cooper</a>, <a>Bill Dedman</a>, and <a>Hank Klibanoff</a>; <a>Jon Feltheimer</a>, CEO of Lionsgate films; actors <a>Peter Sarsgaard</a> (<em><a>Boys Don't Cry</a></em>, <em><a>An Education</a></em>) and <a>Harold Ramis</a> (<em><a>Ghostbusters</a></em>, <em><a>Caddyshack</a></em>); U.S. Ambassador <a>Sam Fox</a>; baseball player <a>Dal Maxvill</a>; and science-show host <a>Deanne Bell</a> (<em><a>Design Squad</a></em>).</li>

country <p> {{Infobox university |name           = United States Naval Academy |image_name     = United States Naval Academy insignia 2.png |image_size     = 200px |motto          = <em>Ex Scientia Tridens</em> |mottoeng       =  |established    = 10 October 1845 |type           = <a>Federal military academy</a> |Carnegie Class = Baccalaureate Colleges-Arts &amp; Sciences (Public) |head_label     = Superintendent |head           = <a>VADM</a> <a>Michael H. country Graduates are usually <a>commissioned</a> as <a>ensigns</a> in the Navy or <a>Second Lieutenant</a>s in the Marine Corps, and occasionally as officers in the US Air Force, US Army, and U.S. Coast Guard.
country <p>In 2010, <em><a>U.S. News &amp; World Report</a></em> ranked the Naval Academy as #16 in the National Liberal Arts category in the 2011 edition of its Best Colleges ranking report.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
country name=&quot;Admissions&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; The U.S. government pays for tuition, room and board.
country <p><a>thumb|right|U.S. Naval Academy in 1853</a> <a>thumb|right|stereoscopic views of midshipman quarters and mess hall c. 1905</a></p>
country The campus was established at <a>Annapolis</a> on the grounds of the former U.S. Army post <a>Fort Severn</a>.
country In addition, the class of 1984 included the first naturalized Korean-American graduates, all choosing commissions in the U.S. Navy.
country <p>Midshipman officer collar insignia are a series of gold bars, from the rank of Midshipman <a>Ensign</a> (one bar or stripe) to Midshipman <a>Captain</a> (six bars or stripes) in the Brigade of Midshipmen at the U.S. Naval Academy.</p>
country <p><a>thumb|U.S. Naval Academy campus</a> <a>thumb|Plebes (first year students) marching in front of Bancroft Hall</a> <a>thumb|Interior of the Naval Academy chapel</a> The campus (or &quot;Yard&quot;) has grown from a  Army post named <a>Fort Severn</a> in 1845 to a , or , campus in the 21st century.
country The Chapel was featured on the U.S. Postal Service postage stamp honoring the Academy's 150th anniversary in 1995.&lt;ref name=USNAstamp&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; <a>John Paul Jones</a> lies at rest in the crypt beneath the Chapel.</p>
country <li><strong>Preble Hall</strong> houses the <a>U.S. Naval Academy Museum</a>.&lt;ref name=USNAmuseum&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; It was named for <a>Edward Preble</a>.</li>
country Famous flags of the U.S. Navy and captured flags from enemy ships are displayed throughout the academy.
country The Monument was commissioned by the Officers of the U.S. Navy as a tribute to Commander <a>William Lewis Herndon</a> (1813&#x2013;1857) after his loss in the Pacific Mail Steamer <a><em>Central America</em></a> during a hurricane off the North Carolina coast on 12 September 1857.
country <p>The U.S. Naval Academy's varsity sports teams&lt;ref name=USNAathletics&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; have no official name but usually are referred to in media as &quot;the Midshipmen&quot; (since all <a>athletes</a> are, in fact, midshipmen), or more informally as &quot;the Mids.&quot;
country <a>Traditions: U.S. Naval Academy Facts, Figures and History</a> (at &quot;Nickname&quot;).
country In 1926, Navy's football team won the U.S. national championship based on both the <a>Boand</a> and Houlgate mathematical poll systems.&lt;ref
country <p><a>thumb|150px|A bagpiper with the U.S. Naval Academy Pipes and Drums</a> Midshipmen have the opportunity to participate in a broad range of other extracurricular activities including <a>musical performance groups</a> (<a>Drum &amp; Bugle Corps</a>, Men's <a>Glee Club</a>, Women's Glee Club, <a>Gospel Choir</a>, an annual <a>musical</a>, and a <a>bagpipe</a> band, the Pipes &amp; Drums), religious organizations, academic <a>honor societies</a> such as <a>Omicron Delta Epsilon</a> (an economics honor society), <a>Campus Girl Scouts</a>, the <a>National Eagle Scout Association</a>, a radio station (WRNV),&lt;ref&gt;<a>http://www.usna.edu/WRNV/staff.html</a>&lt;/ref&gt;
country There is an intercollegiate <a>debate</a> team.&lt;ref&gt;<a>http://www.usna.edu/PoliSci/activities.php</a>&lt;/ref&gt;  Colleges from along the East Coast attend the annual U.S. Naval Academy Debate Tournament.
country U.S. Military Academy website.
country <p>Following the <a>2003 U.S. Air Force Academy sexual assault scandal</a> and due to concern with <a>sexual assault in the U.S. military</a> the Department of Defense was required to establish a task force to investigate sexual harassment and assault at the United States military academies in the law funding the military for fiscal 2004.

students {{Infobox university |name            =Los Angeles Pierce College |native_name     = |latin_name      = |image           =<a>200px</a> |established     =1947 |type            =Public <a>community college</a> |endowment       = |staff           = |faculty         = |president       =Robert Garber |provost         = |principal       = |rector          = |chancellor      = |vice_chancellor = |dean            = |head_label      = |head            = |students        =23,000 |undergrad       = |postgrad        = |doctoral        = |profess         = |city            =<a>Woodland Hills</a>&lt;br&gt;<a>Los Angeles</a> |state           =<a>CA</a> |country         =<a>USA</a> |campus          =Urban - 426 acres (1.72 km&#x00b2;), in the <a>Chalk Hills</a> |free_label      = |free            = |colors          =Scarlet and White |colours         = |mascot          =Brahma Bull |nickname        =The Brahmas |affiliations    =<a>LACCD</a>; <a>WSC</a> |footnotes       = |website         =<a>www.piercecollege.edu</a>
students <p><strong>Los Angeles Pierce College</strong>, also known as <strong>Pierce College</strong>, <strong>Pierce</strong>, is a two-year <a>community college</a> that serves more than 23,000 students in the northern <a>Chalk Hills</a> of <a>Woodland Hills</a>, a community within the <a>San Fernando Valley</a> region of the <a>city of Los Angeles</a>, <a>California</a>.</p>
students <p>The Associated Students Organization (ASO) is the official Student Government of the 23,000 students at Los Angeles Pierce College.
undergrad As of 2009, the school has an enrollment of 2,124 undergraduate students and 49 graduate students.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>

campus <p>The CSU system is composed of 23 campuses and has over 400,000 students supported by 47,000 faculty members and staff.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</pre>
campus Annual Report</a>&lt;/ref&gt; In addition, each of the 23 campuses of the CSU raise their own funds through donations and other external funding, and each campus controls its own separate endowment funds not counted in the above endowment amount.&lt;ref&gt;<a>Link to CSU Endowment &amp; Fundraising webpage</a>&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
campus <p>The CSU is composed of the following 23 campuses listed here by order of the year founded:</p>

nickname For <a>football</a>, the Aggies compete in Division I <a>FCS</a> (formerly known as Division I-AA), and are members of the <a>Great West Conference</a>, granting UC Davis the distinction of being one of only three UC campuses to field a football team (<a>Cal</a> and <a>UCLA</a> being the other two).
nickname The Aggies are also members of the <a>Mountain Pacific Sports Federation</a> in gymnastics and lacrosse, the <a>Western Intercollegiate Rowing Association</a> in <a>rowing</a>, and an associate member of the <a>Pacific-10 Conference</a> in wrestling.</p>

nickname In 1838, however, the <a>University of Michigan</a> opened the Kalamazoo Branch of the University of Michigan, providing a local competitor to the Literary Institute.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;

nickname Stadium (UC Davis)|Aggie Stadium]]]] :<em>For more information, see <a>UC Davis Aggies</a></em> The UC Davis <a>Aggies</a> (or Ags) compete in NCAA <a>Division I</a> sports in the <a>Big West Conference</a>.
nickname These and other achievements motivated a decision (following a year of heavy discussion by campus administrators, faculty, staff, students, alumni and the local community) in 2003 for the athletics program to re-classify to Division I.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; <a>thumb|Aggies at Stanford (half-time show), September 17, 2005</a> The highlight of the recent 4-year transition to Division I occurred on September 17, 2005, when the Aggies defeated the heavily favored <a>Stanford</a> Cardinal at <a>Stanford Stadium</a> by a score of 20-17 on a TD pass with 8 seconds left in the game.
nickname The Aggies also pulled off an upset against Stanford in basketball just months later, beating the Cardinal 64-58 with a late rally at home on December 4, 2005.
nickname The win in these two major sports and the addition of the Aggies beating the Cardinal in soccer earlier in 2005 as well as a win in wrestling and two wins in baseball pulled the Aggies' win loss record with Stanford to 5-1 for men's sports the 05-06 year.</p>

nickname <p>The Carnegie Mellon Tartans were a founding member of the <a>University Athletic Association</a> of the <a>NCAA Division III</a>.
nickname The Tartans have an especially intense rivalry with the <a>Washington University in St. Louis Football</a> team.</p>
nickname <p>   <strong>Kalamazoo College</strong>, also known as <strong>K College</strong> or simply <strong>K</strong>, is a <a>private</a> <a>liberal arts college</a> in <a>Kalamazoo</a>, <a>Michigan</a>, <a>United States</a>.
nickname Today, it produces more <a>Peace Corps</a> volunteer per capita than any other U.S. academic institution, and ranks in the top 1 percent for number of graduates who go on to earn a Ph.D.&lt;ref name=&quot;acenet.edu&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
nickname In 1850, the Kalamazoo Literary Institute name was restored and in 1855 the school finally received an educational charter from the State of Michigan, establishing explicit recognition of the school as a college.&lt;ref
nickname name=&quot;Willis and Dunbar&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; After receiving its educational charter, the school changed its name to Kalamazoo College.</p>
nickname <p>James Stone, the first president of Kalamazoo College, led the school from 1842 through 1863 and was responsible for instituting the high academic standards that allowed the College to receive its charter.
nickname With the support of the Baptist church, classes at the Kalamazoo Theological Seminary began in 1848 with 11 students.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
nickname name=&quot;Willis and Dunbar&quot;/&gt; In 1845-46, almost half of the 90 students enrolled in Kalamazoo were women.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
nickname A meeting of disgruntled Michigan <a>Whigs</a>, <a>Democrats</a>, and abolitionists at the Stones' Kalamazoo residence set the date for an anti-slavery convention in <a>Jackson, Michigan</a>, which resulted in the formal birth of the Republican Party.</p>
nickname <p>The first known student of African descent to attend Kalamazoo College was ex-slave Rufus Lewis Perry.
nickname Perry attended Kalamazoo Theological Seminary from 1860&#x2013;1861, but left before he received a diploma.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
nickname He was ordained a Baptist minister in Ann Arbor in 1861, and later earned a Ph.D. from State University in Louisville, Kentucky.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
nickname Jamaican-born brothers Solomon and John Williamson were the first black graduates from &quot;K,&quot; receiving their diplomas in 1911.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
nickname Kalamazoo College also served as a pioneer in <a>coed education</a>, granting its first degree to a woman, Miss Catherine V. Eldred, in 1870.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
nickname <p>In 1877, Kalamazoo College students published the first edition of <em>The Index</em>, a student-run newspaper that continues to publish today.
nickname The college also publishes &quot;The Cauldron,&quot; an annual literary-arts journal; and  &quot;The Passage&quot;, an annual compilation of students' work from study abroad.</p>
nickname <p>Kalamazoo College's reputation as an academic powerhouse and a leader in international education was built during the presidency of <a>Weimer Hicks</a>, who served from 1954 to 1971.&lt;ref name=&quot;kpl.gov&quot;/&gt;
nickname Hicks conceived of the &quot;K Plan&quot; program under which most Kalamazoo students spend at least one term abroad and spend at least one term working in an academic internship.
nickname As part of the original &quot;K Plan,&quot; Kalamazoo College students could attend school year-round.
nickname <p><a>thumb|right|Hicks Center and Stetson Chapel</a></p>
nickname <p>Kalamazoo College is among the 100 oldest colleges and universities in the United States.
nickname <p>Students at Kalamazoo College must fulfill specific degree requirements in order to graduate.
nickname Ninety-five percent of Kalamazoo College's faculty have doctorates or terminal degrees in their fields.&lt;ref
nickname <p>On January 3, 2006, Kalamazoo College opened the new Upjohn Library Commons which includes the completely renovated skeleton of the older library, and an extension which adds to its volume capacity.</p>
nickname <p>Kalamazoo College is an academic leader among national liberal arts colleges and emphasizes the importance of an experiential education.
nickname The academic plan &#x2014; known as the &quot;K plan&quot; &#x2014; consists of a rigorous liberal arts education supplemented by one or more terms abroad and internship opportunities during the summer.
nickname All students are required to complete a Senior Individualized Project (SIP), which may take the form of a thesis, an artistic performance, or any other work-intensive project of a student's choosing.
nickname Kalamazoo College is also unique in that it requires its students to take comprehensive exams in their major field of study before graduating.
nickname Kalamazoo College is the only undergraduate institution in the United States that requires both a senior project and a comprehensive examination.</p>
nickname <p>Kalamazoo College initiated the service-learning program in the 1997.
nickname In 2001, Trustee Ronda Stryker dedicated  to her grandmother the Mary Jane Underwood Stryker Institute for Service Learning.
nickname The current director of the Mary Jane Underwood Stryker Institute is Alison Geist.
nickname In 2008, Kalamazoo College had twenty-three on-going service-learning programs.
nickname The programs in service-learning include Community Advocates for Parents and Students; Helping Youth through Personal Empowerment; Academic Mentorship In Giants On-going Success; the Woodward School; Keeping the Doors Open; and Farms to K.</p>
nickname <p><a>US News &amp; World Report</a> America's Best Colleges 2003 ranked Kalamazoo College's study-abroad program number one in the country.
nickname Nearly 85% of Kalamazoo College students spend at least one term abroad and the college maintains partnerships with over 50 foreign universities on six continents.
nickname <p>In 2009, the Center Career Development merged with the <a>Guilds of Kalamazoo College</a> to create the <a>Center for Career and Professional Development</a>.
nickname The CCPD's mission is to create meaningful connections to the world of work, empowering Kalamazoo College students to explore, identify and pursue their diverse interests, values and passions, and to develop a framework of skills, networks and knowledge for successful lifelong career planning and professional development.
nickname <p>A recent study by Higher Education Data Sharing lists Kalamazoo College in the top 1 percent of colleges and universities whose graduates go on to earn a <a>Ph.D</a>.
nickname According to this study, Kalamazoo College is ranked number nine among all private colleges and&#x2014;when compared with all academic institutions&#x2014;it ranks number fourteen in Ph.Ds per capita.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
nickname Among all undergraduate institutions, Kalamazoo College was #1 per capita in 2005 for recruitment of Peace Corps volunteers.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
nickname Kalamazoo College competes in the following sports:</p>
nickname   <li><a>Basketball</a> (M &amp; W)</li>
nickname <p><a>College football</a> has been played at Kalamazoo since 1892, when the school completed a record of 0 wins and 2 losses, both to <a>Olivet College</a>.
nickname The school's first win came two years later in 1894 with a 16&ndash;4 victory over the Kalamazoo <a>YMCA</a>.&lt;ref&gt;{{Cite
nickname web|url=<a>http://www.cfbdatawarehouse.com/data/div_iii/miaa/kalamazoo/yearly_results.php?year=1892</a>|accessdate=December 2, 2010|first=David|last=DeLassus|publisher=<a>College Football Data Warehouse</a>|title=Kalamazoo Yearly Results (1892-1894)}}&lt;/ref&gt;  It was 1895 before the school defeated another college football team with a 12&ndash;8 victory over <a>Alma</a>.&lt;ref
nickname name=cfdw1895&gt;{{Cite web|url=<a>http://www.cfbdatawarehouse.com/data/div_iii/miaa/kalamazoo/yearly_results.php?year=1895</a>|accessdate=December 2, 2010|first=David|last=DeLassus|publisher=<a>College Football Data Warehouse</a>|title=Kalamazoo Yearly Results (1895-1899)}}&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
nickname <p>The Kalamazoo College men&#x2019;s tennis team has won 72 consecutive Michigan Intercollegiate Athletic Association championships (1936&#x2013;2010) with a record of 426-2 in the MIAA from 1935 - 2007.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
nickname Kalamazoo has won seven NCAA Division III national championships and has made 25 consecutive NCAA III tournament appearances.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
nickname <p>Men's swimming and diving at Kalamazoo College has an impressive history.
nickname The team is known for producing individual national champions in the pool and on the boards, and also for maintaining a national presence with regular appearances as a top-10 team at the NCAA Division III national championships.
nickname The swimming and diving team is the second most successful athletic program at Kalamazoo College, after the men's tennis team, and it is also one of the top-10 most-successful teams in the MIAA with  25 MIAA championships.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
nickname   <li>Don Knoechel, NCAA Postgraduate Scholarship 1980</li>
nickname   <li>Markus Boos, GTE Academic All-American 2nd Team 2000</li>
nickname   <li>Evan Whitbeck, NCAA Postgraduate Scholarship 2002</li>
nickname   <li>Scott Whitbeck, NCAA Postgraduate Scholarship 2004</li>
nickname   <li>Robert Dekker, NCAA Postgraduate Scholarship 2009</li>
nickname <li>Mark Fino, Head Coach of Men's and Women's Swimming &amp; Diving at Oberlin College.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</li>
nickname <li>Scott Whitbeck, assistant swim coach at The College of Wooster (2005&#x2013;2007), University Massachusetts Amherst and State University of New York at New Paltz.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</li>
nickname <li>Derek Jansen, Founder of <a>d3swimming.com</a>&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</li>
nickname Kalamazoo's First ever Womans Cross Country MIAA conference Meet Champion and MIAA Conference MVP.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</li>
nickname <h3>Men's basketball</h3>
nickname <h4>Basketball dispute</h4>
nickname <p>In 2001, the Kalamazoo College men's basketball team was at the center of a lengthy dispute regarding the outcome of a January 20 game with league rival <a>Olivet College</a>.
nickname With Olivet leading 70-69, Kalamazoo College center Kevin Baird made a shot at the buzzer that was initially waved off by referees.
nickname The referees reviewed videotape of the game and determined that Baird had, in fact, released his shot before the buzzer and then awarded Kalamazoo College a 71-70 victory.
nickname Kalamazoo then filed a protest with the NCAA, claiming that Olivet's protest was in violation of NCAA bylaws.
nickname On February 1, the NCAA upheld Kalamazoo's counter-protest and again awarded the game to the Hornets.
nickname The dispute between Olivet and Kalamazoo received national attention and Baird's shot was shown repeatedly on <a>ESPN</a>.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
nickname <p>The words to the college fight-song, &quot;All Hail to Kazoo,&quot; were written by A.G. Walton (1911) with music by D.R. Belcher (1909), arranged by Burton Edward Fischer.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
nickname <p><a>thumb|right|Hoben Hall taken from Hicks Center</a></p>
nickname They routinely bring in speakers as well as stage performances, dances, and movie showings.</p>
nickname In Fall Fest, student organizations provide activities for the students, such as pumpkin carving and bobbing for apples.</p>
nickname <p>During the winter quarter, the college holds the annual Monte Carlo night, on which the student body raises money by gambling in a makeshift casino where the professors are the dealers.
nickname <p>Kaleidoscope (formerly known as the Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual, Transgender, and Ally Student Organization, GLBTSO) hosts the Crystal Ball each spring.
nickname A long-standing tradition at K College, this event was created to educate the campus about GLBT issues and celebrate the persons who make up the GLBT community.
nickname While it was originally instituted (despite the Student Commission's rejection) as a day for students to relax and have fun, the <a>1980 Kalamazoo tornado</a> prompted students to spend that year's DOGL helping clean up after the storm and giving back to their community.
nickname The date is determined by the president of the Student Commission and kept secret from the student body, though it is usually on one of the Wednesdays during weeks 7-9.
nickname name=&quot;Time-Travel: History of Kalamazoo College&quot;&gt;<a>&quot;Time-Travel: History of Kalamazoo College&quot;</a>, Kalamazoo College.
nickname <p>Kalamazoo College has become a leading institution in the area of recycling and environmental awareness.
nickname A crew of student workers operates one of the nation's most successful recycling programs and organizes the school's participation in the annual <a>RecycleMania</a> event, a competition among over 400 colleges and universities across the United States.
nickname In 2005, Kalamazoo College came to national prominence with a 3rd-place finish in the Grand Champion category.
nickname While annually placing in the top 5 in a variety of categories, in 2008 Kalamazoo College placed 1st in both the Grand Champion and Stephen K Gaski Per Capita Classic competitions.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
nickname <p>Kalamazoo College signed the President's Climate Commitment in 2007 and has completed a greenhouse gas emissions inventory.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
nickname The college's Hicks Student Center is partially powered by wind and solar energy,&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; and the student group D.I.R.T. (Digging in Renewable Turf) maintains an organic garden on campus.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
nickname Kalamazoo received a B on the 2010 College Sustainability Report Card.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
nickname <h2>Presidents of Kalamazoo College</h2>
nickname <p> In 2005 Dr. <a>Eileen Wilson-Oyelaran</a> became Kalamazoo College's 17th President and first female president, as well as the first African-American president of the school.
nickname Her immediate predecessors are Bernard Palchick, who served as interim president and returned to the administration, and <a>James F. Jones</a>, who departed to become President of <a>Trinity College</a>, in <a>Connecticut</a>.</p>
nickname   <li><a>Walter Clark</a> (1835&#x2013;1836)</li>
nickname   <li><a>James Stone</a> (1843&#x2013;1863)&lt;ref&gt;<em>A Fellowship in Learning: Kalamazoo College, 1833-2008.</em>
nickname page 32 Marlene Crandall Francis 2008 Kalamazoo College&lt;/ref&gt;</li>
nickname   <li><a>Kendall Brooks</a> (1868&#x2013;1887)</li>
nickname   <li><a>Weimer K. Hicks</a> (1953&#x2013;1971)</li>
nickname   <li><a>Bernard Palchick</a> (2004&#x2013;2005) (<em>interim</em>)</li>
nickname   <li><a>Selma Blair</a>, actress (graduated from the <a>University of Michigan</a>, but studied at Kalamazoo from 1990 to 1992)</li>
nickname   <li><a>Nagai Kafu</a>, author</li>
nickname   <li><a>Lisa Kron</a>, Tony-Award-nominated actress and playwright</li>
nickname   <li><a>John E. Sarno</a>, innovator in back-pain therapy</li>
nickname   <li><a>Mark Spitznagel</a>, hedge fund manager</li>
nickname   <li><a>Steven Yeun</a>, actor best known for portraying Glenn in <a>The Walking Dead</a></li>
nickname   <li><a>Mike Vasas</a>, singer/songwriter</li>
nickname   <li>Elizabeth Lindau and Matt Priest, musicians, of the indie-rock band <a>Canasta</a></li>
nickname   <li>Corey Harbaugh, teacher, innovator known for using technology in education</li>

mascot <p>In September 2009 the university unveiled a new look and back story for its mascot, Captain Cane.
mascot Two-thousand coloring books were distributed to children at a September 26, 2009 home football game presenting the story of a brainy TU student's transformation into Captain Cane as the result of an accident involving storm-generated static electricity.
mascot Before this, starting in 1994, Captain Cane was depicted as an <a>anthropomorphized</a> golden <a>hurricane</a> with human attributes such as biceps, clothes, and a perpetual smirk on a swirled over-sized inverted cone-shaped golden head.
mascot From 1978 to 1994, the mascot was known as &quot;Huffy,&quot; who was similar to Captain Cane in appearance.</p>

Molina</a> | website         = <a>www.uci.edu</a>
mascot <p>The anteater was inspired by &quot;Peter the Anteater&quot; from the <a>Johnny Hart</a> comic strip, &quot;<a>B.C.</a>&quot;  Before the voting took place on campus, it is said that the men&#x2019;s water polo team highly encouraged the students to vote for the anteater as the school mascot.
mascot <p>School chants and cheers feature the word &quot;zot&quot; which was the noise Johnny Hart's &quot;Peter the Anteater&quot; made while eating ants.

native_name |logo = <a>center|225px</a> }} The <strong>Leland Stanford Junior University</strong>, commonly referred to as <strong>Stanford University</strong> or <strong>Stanford</strong>, is a <a>private research university</a> located in <a>Stanford, California</a>, United States with a strong emphasis on scientific, technological and social science research.

mottoeng The Latin motto is literally translated as &quot;The voice of one crying in the wilderness&quot;,&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;good&quot;/&gt; but is more often rendered as &quot;A voice crying in the wilderness&quot;,&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; which attempts to translate the <a>synecdoche</a> of the phrase.

free_label <p>In 1902, New York newspaper magnate <a>Joseph Pulitzer</a> donated a substantial sum to the university for the founding of a school to teach journalism.
free_label <p>The <em><a>Columbia Daily Spectator</a></em> is the nation's second-oldest student newspaper;&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; and <em><a>The Blue and White</a></em>,&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; a monthly literary magazine established in 1890, has recently begun to delve into campus life and local politics in print and on its daily blog, dubbed the <em>Bwog</em>.</p>
free_label <p><em><a>The Fed</a></em>&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; a triweekly satire and investigative newspaper; and the <em><a>Jester of Columbia</a></em>,&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; the newly (and frequently) revived campus humor magazine both inject humor into local life.</p>
free_label During the spring semester, graduate students in the Journalism School publish <em><a>The Bronx Beat</a></em>, a bi-weekly newspaper covering the South Bronx.
free_label It is both a watchdog and a friend of the press in all its forms, from newspapers to magazines to radio, television, and the Web.

free_label <p>A variety of sports teams are organized as &quot;club&quot; teams, supported financially by the Student Union as well as by individual members of the team.
free_label During this enquiry, the Senate of the <a>University of Sydney</a> put in a submission which highlighted &#x2018;the immediate need to establish a third university in the metropolitan area&#x2019;.&lt;ref&gt;Liberality of Opportunity, Mansfield and Hutchinson, p. 19&lt;/ref&gt; After much debate a future campus location was selected in what was then a semi-rural part of North Ryde, and it was decided that the future university be named after <a>Lachlan Macquarie</a>, an important early governor of the colony of New South Wales.</p>

free_label |coor            = |logo            = <a>center|150px</a> }} <strong>Simon Fraser University</strong>, commonly referred to as <strong>SFU</strong>, is a <a>Canadian</a> <a>public research university</a> in <a>British Columbia</a> with its main campus on <a>Burnaby Mountain</a> in Burnaby, and satellite campuses in <a>Vancouver</a> and <a>Surrey</a>.
free_label Two satellite campuses are located in <a>Vancouver's</a> Downtown at <a>Harbour Centre</a>, and in <a>Surrey</a>.
free_label <h2>Satellite campuses</h2>
free_label |free_label = Newspaper
free_label <p>The school's independent student newspaper is <em><a>The Daily Orange</a></em>, founded in 1903 and independent since 1971.
free_label <p>South Campus is the site for the athletic programs, including major sports facilities such as <a>Michigan Stadium</a>, <a>Crisler Arena</a>, and <a>Yost Ice Arena</a>.
free_label The University of Michigan Golf Course was included in a listing of top holes designed by what <em><a>Sports Illustrated</a></em> calls &#x201c;golf&#x2019;s greatest course architect.&#x201d;
free_label <a>Intramural sports</a> are popular, and there are recreation facilities for each of the three campuses.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
free_label <p> [[File:MichiganStadium2010UConn.JPG|thumb|A football game at [[Michigan Stadium]]|alt=Crowded stadium with yellow-colored &quot;Michigan&quot; written on a green field]] The University of Michigan's sports teams are called the <a>Wolverines</a>.
free_label They participate in the <a>NCAA's</a> Football Bowl Subdivision (formally <a>Division I-A</a>) and in the <a>Big Ten Conference</a> in all sports except men's <a>ice hockey</a>, which is a member of the <a>Central Collegiate Hockey Association</a>, and woman's water polo, which is a member of the Collegiate Water Polo Association.
free_label In 10 of the past 14 years concluding in 2009, U-M has finished in the top five of the <a>NACDA Director's Cup</a>, a ranking compiled by the <a>National Association of Collegiate Directors of Athletics</a> to tabulate the success of universities in competitive sports.
free_label U-M has fierce rivalries with many teams, including <a>Michigan State</a>, <a>Notre Dame</a>, and <a>Ohio State</a>, the last of which has been referred to by <a>ESPN</a> as the <a>greatest rivalry</a> in American sports.&lt;ref&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;
free_label <p>U-M athletes have starred in Major League Baseball, the <a>National Football League</a> and <a>National Basketball Association</a> as well as other professional sports.
free_label name=&quot;Heisman&quot; /&gt; Professional golfer <a>John Schroeder</a> and Olympic swimmer <a>Michael Phelps</a> also attended the University of Michigan, with the latter studying Sports Marketing and Management.
free_label |image_size=220px |name=University of Rochester |motto=<em><a>Meliora</a></em> (<a>Latin</a>) |mottoeng=Always Better (also, Ever Better) |established=1850 |type=<a>Private</a>, secular |calendar=  Semester |president=<a>Joel Seligman</a> |city = <a>Rochester</a> |state=<a>New York</a> |country=<a>U.S.</a> |undergrad=4,606 |postgrad=4,357 |staff=1,225 |free_label      = Annual Fees |free            = $52,690 (2009&ndash;2010) |campus=<a>Suburb</a>an/<a>Urban</a>,&lt;ref&gt;The <a>Eastman School</a> campus is in downtown Rochester (urban), while the majority of the university is located in a more suburban environment.&lt;/ref&gt;
free_label The newspaper has not been without scrutiny and controversy, and in 1954, the administration attempted to intervene with the previous policy of electing editors by a student council.

free_label <p>UC Berkeley's independent student-run newspaper is <em><a>The Daily Californian</a></em>. Founded in 1871, <em>The Daily Cal</em> became independent in 1971 after the campus administration fired three senior editors for encouraging readers to take back <a>People's Park</a>.</p>

free_label <h3>Athletics</h3>
free_label <p>Participation in athletics is, in general, mandatory at the Naval Academy and most Midshipmen not on an <a>intercollegiate</a> team must participate actively in <a>intramural</a> or club <a>sports</a>.
free_label <p>The U.S. Naval Academy's varsity sports teams&lt;ref name=USNAathletics&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; have no official name but usually are referred to in media as &quot;the Midshipmen&quot; (since all <a>athletes</a> are, in fact, midshipmen), or more informally as &quot;the Mids.&quot;

free_label professor and future <a>Massachusetts Institute of Technology</a> founder <a>William Barton Rogers</a> wrote, &quot;[T]he legislators of the University have, we think, wisely made their highest academic honor&mdash;that of Master of Arts of the University of Virginia&mdash;the genuine test of diligent and successful literary training, and, disdaining such literary almsgiving, have firmly barred the door against the demands of spurious merit and noisy popularity.&quot;
free_label founder, William Barton Rogers, regarded the practice of giving honorary degrees as 'literary almsgiving ... of spurious merit and noisy popularity....' Rogers was a geologist from the University of Virginia who believed in Thomas Jefferson's policy barring honorary degrees at the university, which was founded in 1819.&quot;&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref

affiliation <p><a>left|thumb|Dalhousie College in 1871</a> Dalhousie College was founded in 1818 as a non-denominational university by the <a>9th Earl of Dalhousie</a>, at the time the <a>Governor of Nova Scotia</a>.&lt;ref name=&quot;autogenerated1&quot;&gt;<a>Dalhousie University&lt;!--
affiliation |affiliation       = Jesuit Catholic
affiliation <p>}} <strong>Seattle University (SU)</strong> is a Jesuit Catholic university located in the <a>First Hill</a> neighborhood of <a>Seattle</a>, <a>Washington</a>, USA.&lt;ref&gt;<a>http://www.law.seattleu.edu/Office_and_Administration/Admission/Seattle_Living/Housing.xml</a> &quot;<strong>First Hill</strong>.

affiliation <p>The vision of Seattle University is to be the premier independent university of the Northwest in academic quality, Jesuit Catholic inspiration, and service to society.</p>

head_label <p> {{Infobox university |name           = United States Naval Academy |image_name     = United States Naval Academy insignia 2.png |image_size     = 200px |motto          = <em>Ex Scientia Tridens</em> |mottoeng       =  |established    = 10 October 1845 |type           = <a>Federal military academy</a> |Carnegie Class = Baccalaureate Colleges-Arts &amp; Sciences (Public) |head_label     = Superintendent |head           = <a>VADM</a> <a>Michael H. Miller</a> |city           = <a>Annapolis</a> |state          = <a>Maryland</a> |country        = U.S. |undergrad      = 4,400 |postgrad       =  |staff          = |affiliations   = |campus         = <a>Naval base</a>,  |mascot         = <a>Bill the Goat</a> |free_label     = Athletics |free           = Varsity, club, and intramural programs |colors         = Navy Blue &lt;span style=&quot;color: #000080&quot;&gt;&#x2588;&lt;/span&gt; and Gold &lt;span style=&quot;color: #FDD017&quot;&gt;&#x2588;&lt;/span&gt;| |website= <a>www.usna.edu</a>
head_label Under the immediate charge of the superintendent, the course of study was extended to seven years with the first two and the last two to be spent at the school and the intervening three years at sea.
head_label The first Superintendent, Admiral <a>Franklin Buchanan</a>, joined the <a>Confederate States Navy</a> as its first and primary admiral.
head_label Lieutenant <a>William Harwar Parker</a>,CSN, class of 1848, and instructor at USNA, joined the <a>Virginia State Navy</a>, and then went on to become the Superintendent of the Confederate States Naval Academy.
head_label The first superintendent of the <a>United States Naval Observatory</a>, Commander <a>Matthew Fontaine Maury</a>, advocate&lt;ref&gt;<a>http://www.history.navy.mil/library/online/maury_mat_bene.htm</a>&lt;/ref&gt; of the creation of the United States Naval Academy, after whom Maury Hall is named, similarly served in the <a>Confederate States Navy</a>.</p>
head_label Four years later, Congress authorized the Superintendent to award a Bachelor of Science degree to all living graduates.
head_label <p>In April 1941 superintendent Rear Admiral <a>Russell Wilson</a> refused to allow the school's <a>lacrosse</a> team <a>to play a visiting team</a> from <a>Harvard University</a> because the Harvard team included a <a>black</a> player.
head_label That year a Vice Admiral, <a>Aubrey W. Fitch</a>, became superintendent.
head_label <p>In August 2007, Superintendent Vice Admiral Jeffrey Fowler changed academy policy to limit liberty, required more squad interaction to emphasize that &quot;we are a nation at war.&quot;&lt;ref name=WP20070817&gt;&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
head_label <p>As of 2004, the <a>Superintendent of the Naval Academy</a> reports directly to the <a>Chief of Naval Operations</a>.
head_label The current Superintendent is Vice Admiral <a>Michael H. Miller</a>.</p>
head_label In 1937, an act of Congress extended to the Superintendent of the Naval Academy the authority to award the Bachelor of Science degree to all living graduates.
head_label |author=Gelfand, H. Michael (University of Arizona) |title=&quot;Revolutionary Change at Evolutionary Speed&quot;: Women and the United States Naval Academy |journal=International Journal of Naval History |volume=1 |issue=1 |month=April | year=2002}}&lt;/ref&gt; <em>The Log</em> was once featured in <em><a>Playboy Magazine</a></em> for its parody of the famous periodical,&lt;ref&gt;The Log parodied a national magazine once each year&lt;/ref&gt; called &quot;Playmid.&quot; &quot;Playmid&quot; was an issue of <em>The Log</em> in 1989 and was ordered destroyed by Rear Admiral <a>Virgil I. Hill</a>, the Academy Superintendent at the time, but a handful of copies did survive, including the one which <em>       </em> later showed.
head_label <p>Academy Superintendent Vice Admiral Rodney Rempt issued a statement: &quot;With the benefit of the Defense Task Force's assessment and recommendations, we will continue to strive to establish a climate which encourages reporting of these incidents, so we can support the victim and deal with allegations fairly and appropriately.
head_label Superintendent Rempt has recently been criticized for not allowing former Navy quarterback <a>Lamar Owens</a> to graduate, despite his acquittal on a rape charge.

former_names <p><strong>William Marsh Rice University</strong> (commonly known as <strong>Rice University</strong>) opened in 1912 as <strong>The William Marsh Rice Institute for the Advancement of Letters, Science and Art</strong> is a <a>private</a> <a>coeducational</a> research university located in <a>Houston</a>, <a>Texas</a>, <a>United States</a>.
former_names |former_names      = Seattle College
former_names In 1898, the school was named Seattle College after both the city and <a>Chief Seattle</a>, and it granted its first bachelor's degrees 11 years later.
former_names In 1931, Seattle College created a &quot;night school&quot; for women in order to allow them to attend; this was a highly controversial decision at the time.&lt;ref&gt;<a>http://www.seattleu.edu/history/section2.html</a>&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;<a>http://www.seattleu.edu/history/section3.html</a>&lt;/ref&gt;</p>
former_names <p>In 1948, Seattle College changed its name to Seattle University under Father Albert A. Lemieux, S.J.

closed On 1 October 2004, it merged with the <a>Victoria University of Manchester</a> (commonly called the University of Manchester) to form a new entity also called The <a>University of Manchester</a>.
closed <p>In 2004 <a>Terry Leahy</a>, <a>CEO</a> of <a>Tesco</a> and  alumnus was the last <a>Chancellor</a> of UMIST, and the Vice Chancellor was fittingly a chemical engineer, Prof John Garside.</p>
closed <p>UMIST, together with the <a>Victoria University of Manchester</a> ceased to exist on 1 October 2004, when they were combined in a new single <a>University of Manchester</a> hoping to combine the strengths and traditions of both.</p>
closed <p>In 2004, at the time of the university merger, the UMIST Association also merged with its equivalent organisation at the Victoria University of Manchester.
closed   <li>&#x2014; (2004) &quot;<a>Reynolds, John Henry (1842&#x2013;1927)</a>&quot;, <em><a>Oxford Dictionary of National Biography</a></em>, Oxford University Press, accessed 18 June 2005 (subscription required)</li>

publisher |logo =<a>245px</a> }} The <strong>University of California, Santa Cruz</strong>, also known as <strong>UC Santa Cruz</strong> or <strong>UCSC</strong>, is a <a>public</a>, <a>collegiate</a> <a>university</a>; one of ten campuses in the <a>University of California</a>.
publisher <p>Founded in 1965,&lt;ref name=&quot;overview&quot;&gt;&lt;/ref&gt; UC Santa Cruz began as a showcase for progressive, cross-disciplinary undergraduate education, innovative teaching methods and contemporary architecture.
publisher <p>In April 2010, UC Santa Cruz opened its new $35 million Digital Arts Research Center; a project in planning since 2004.
publisher The heavily-forested area has allowed UC Santa Cruz to operate a <a>recreational vehicle park</a> as a form of student housing.
publisher <p>UC Santa Cruz is currently ranked #71 in the list of Best National Universities in the United States by the <em><a>US News &amp; World Reports</a></em>,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=<a>http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/santa-cruz-ca/ucsc-1321</a>|title=US News.
publisher &lt;ref&gt;  &lt;/ref&gt; In 2009, The Princeton Review (with Gamepro Magazine) ranked UC Santa Cruz's Game Design major among the top 50 in the country.
publisher <p>UC Santa Cruz is also well known for its <a>cannabis</a> culture.
publisher   <li><a>UC Santa Cruz Fire Department</a></li>
publisher Add a link ONLY if it helps improve the reader's understanding of UC Santa Cruz and/or assists in research on the subject.
publisher * Content concerning the Santa Cruz area in general, not UC Santa Cruz in particular</pre>
